The Saddam mask looks like a diseased pear. Cesar's artisans have exaggerated the Iraqi's leader's jowls, cut a deep cleft in his chin and drooped his mustache in a frown of distaste. Highly arched eyebrows top a pair of close-set eyes, both overshadowed by a mock-up of the beret of the Iraqi leader who sparked the Persian Gulf crisis when he seized oil-rich Kuwait Aug. 2. Cesar has produced a few hundred copies of the head-covering get-up in the past two weeks and hopes to have 2,500 on the U.S. market by Oct. 1. The mask will not be offered elsewhere. ``We have to act while the market is still hot,'' said Saudreau. ``This type of mask has an appeal only as long as the subject is in the news. Once the gulf affair is over, people won't want it.'' The company already sells caricatures of President Bush, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and other political figures.

DOC.HEAD: Silicon Valley Investor Thomas Jefferson Davis Jr. Dies
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Jefferson Davis Jr., an investor who helped start many Silicon Valley electronics companies, has died at a convalescent hospital at age 77. Davis died Tuesday, and a cause of death was not given. In 1969, Davis formed the Mayfield Fund, which provided the original financing for more than 125 high-tech companies, including Tandem Computers, Genentech, Businessland and Applied Biosystems. He also developed a procedure by which institutions could take part in venture investment, giving rise to an explosion of investment capital that ultimately led to new technologies and businesses. Davis, a 1938 graduate of Harvard Law School, served as a captain in the U.S. Army and was counsel for the National Labor Relations Board. He founded the International Hospitality Center in San Francisco. Davis is survived by his wife, Shirley, a sister, a brother, six daughters and 11 grandchildren. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Foundation Awards $1.6 Million for Colleges to Diversify
DOC.TEXT: The Ford Foundation has awarded $1.6 million to 19 schools to help address racial strife on college campuses. Under the program announced Wednesday, the 19 schools received grants from $25,000 to $100,000 to create courses and to blend information about different cultures into existing courses. ``Ignorance about other cultures breeds insensitivity and intolerance in young and old alike,'' said Franklin A. Thomas, president of the New York-based foundation. The foundation invited 200 schools to apply and 105 responded. The foundation appointed Edgar F. Beckham to run the program. He is the former dean at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., which has had some recent racial problems. At the University of California at Los Angeles, which received $100,000, the money will be used for a seminar course for students and the public on the ethnic diversity of Los Angeles. At Brandeis University, in Waltham, Mass., which also received $100,000, humanities faculty members will study African and African-American history to include in their courses. Southwest Texas State University in San Marcos, Texas, will use its $76,880 grant to create a curriculum on the Southwest's multicultural heritage. Other schools that received grants were: _Bemidji State University, Bemidji, Minn. _Boston College. _Denison University, Granville, Ohio. _Haverford College, Haverford, Pa. _University of Iowa in Iowa City. _Millsaps College, Jackson, Miss. _Mount St. Mary's College, Los Angeles. _New School for Social Research, New York. _Notre Dame, Notre Dame, Ind. _Pitzer College, Claremont, Calif. _University of the Redlands, Redlands, Calif. _University of Rochester, Rochester, N.Y. _Spring Hill College, Mobile, Ala. _Tulane University, New Orleans. _Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Va. _Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Break Through Rebel Lines to Reach Besieged Jaffna Fort
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE casualty figures; pickup 8th pvs, `The breaking...' ^By DEXTER CRUEZ
DOC.TEXT: Government troops broke the Tamil rebels' three-month siege of a strategic northern fort in a surprise attack today that left 100 rebels and 12 soldiers dead, according to a military statement. Under cover of fire from gunboats and helicopter gunships, 360 soldiers paddled across a lagoon in rubber dinghies before dawn and fought their way into Jaffna Fort, said Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunga. Ten soldiers were also wounded in the battle for the fort, where more than 200 police and soldiers had been trapped, military officials said on condition of anonymity. An air force plane providing air cover crashed into the lagoon after the siege was broken, military officials said, blaming engine problems, they said. The pilot of the single-engine Italian-made Marchetti plane was thought to have died in the crash. There was no immediate word from the Tamil Tiger rebels or any independent report from Jaffna, where communications have been severed since summer while the Sinhalese-controlled government battled guerrillas from the Tamil minority. The 17th century fort had been besieged since June 11 when the Tamil guerrillas broke a cease-fire and renewed their separatist war against the government. ``The assaulting battle group has now successfully relieved the fort and is consolidating and clearing adjacent areas,'' the military statement said. Officials said the army was destroying rebel bunkers around the fort. The breaking of the siege is an important psychological victory for the government forces, but its value is likely to be more symbolic than practical. The rest of Jaffna town is Tiger territory, and so is most of the surrounding Jaffna Peninsula. Jaffna is 185 miles northeast of Colombo. Nevertheless, the massive fort _ a classic of military architecture with a moat, drawbridge, watch towers and 20-foot walls _ symbolizes Sinhalese power in the Tamil-dominated peninsula. During the siege, helicopters dropped food to the men trapped inside. Drinking water was provided in the form of ice blocks, which quickly melted in the tropical heat. At least twice helicopter pilots braved rebel flak to land at the fort and pick up seriously wounded policemen and soldiers. Having taken the fort, the government's next task is to take the town of Jaffna, which has been a Tiger stronghold since the insurrection started in 1983. The government opened talks last year to try to negotiate a peaceful settlement with the Tigers, who say they need a separate homeland to protect the Tamil minority from discrimination by the Sinhalese majority. The government says more than 3,000 people have been killed in the last three months, bringing the death toll of the 7-year-old insurrection to at least 14,000. The northeast is the home of most of Sri Lanka's Tamils, who form 18 percent of the island's population of 16 million. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the people.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Isidore Drifting North in Mid-Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Former Hurricane Isidore weakened to just above the threshold for a tropical storm, and its top sustained winds of 75 mph this morning remained a threat only to shipping in the mid-Atlantic, forecasters said. Isidore first became a hurricane last Thursday, then dropped back to tropical storm status over the weekend before returning to hurricane strength earlier this week. ``Isidore is kinda like an old stray dog you just can't get rid off. It's been out there for eight or nine days now and just won't go away,'' said Max Mayfield, a specialist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``But I think in about three days' time, it'll take off to the northeast and (head) into the far northern Atlantic,'' where the system should become an extra-tropical storm, Mayfield said. ``But it's still going to be around for three to five more days,'' he said. At 6 a.m. EDT, Isidore was centered near 34.8 north latitude and 50.8 west longitude, or about 1,100 miles west southwest of the Azores. The system was drifting north and was expected to keep that course with no pickup in forward speed likely for the next 24 hours. Isidore's hurricane-force winds extended 35 miles from the center and tropical storm-force winds extended up to 175 miles. The tropical storm becomes a hurricane when its top winds reach 74 mph, while a tropical depression reaches tropical storm strength when its winds reach 39 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Church Envoy's Former Security Chief Killed
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed today the head of security for Anglican church envoy Terry Waite, who disappeared in Beirut more than three years ago. The motive for the slaying of Amin Sleit, 36, was not immediately clear, a police spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Sleit was also an official of Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party, a main ally of Syrian forces in Lebanon's civil war. He was shot in the head, neck and chest by two gunmen carrying silencer-equipped pistols who entered his business in West Beirut and opened fire, the police spokesman said. The gunmen escaped in a white Mercedes that was waiting for them, he said. Sleit headed a Socialist Party security group protecting Waite, 51, who disappeared in West Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987. Waite was in Beirut to negotiate the release of Western hostages. Sleit and other security officials had advised Waite against going unescorted to a meeting with representatives of Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War Faction, which claims to hold several American captives. Waite had helped negotiate the release of three Americans before his capture. No group has claimed it is holding Waite. Former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, who was released last month, said Waite has been ill but is alive. ``He was in the same apartment as I was being held in,'' Keenan said in a recent radio interview. ``I know Terry Waite is alive. I know he has been ill and the illness I do not think is serious.'' Jumblatt visited Teheran, Iran, in late August for talks on Waite's possible release, Socialist sources said on condition of anonymity. The Communist-run Voice of the People radio station in Beirut also reported last month that Waite will be the next hostage in Lebanon freed. The radio station said its prediction was based on interviews with Iranian and Syrian officials as well as Lebanese militia commanders. The 13 Western captives, held mainly by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon, include Waite and three other Britons; two West Germans, an Italian and six Americans. Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped March 16, 1985, and is the longest-held foreign captive in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Water District's Rat Roundup Aimed at Saving Endangered Vermin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to fix typo, capitalize Herefords.
DOC.TEXT: Get along little rat! Yippie-yie-aye! Move 'em out! County officials plan a roundup of Stephens' kangaroo rats to relocate the endangered species as the region's biggest water supplier spends at least $500,000 to speed construction of reservoirs, pipelines and other projects. The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California ``is laying plans for a new kind of Western roundup,'' the agency announced. ``No Herefords or longhorns on this drive, though,'' it said. Instead, the district will herd the rats to western Riverside County. The nocturnal, burrow-dwelling critters are more closely related to squirrels than rats. They were placed on California's threatened species list in 1972 and on the federal endangered species list in 1988. Named after 19th century biologist Frank Stephens, they are among several species of kangaroo rats, which all hop on their hind legs. They can grow up to 15 inches long, including an eight-inch tail. The roundup could start within days, and an estimated 100 to 500 rats will be captured in harmless baited live-animal traps, then moved to empty water district property, Robbie Soltz, the district's environmental affairs manager, said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 1 Million Soviets to Israel in Next Two Years
DOC.TEXT: The number of Soviet Jewish emigres could exceed 1 million over the next two years and Israeli officials are struggling for money to handle the possible influx, a newspaper reported today. About 400,000 Soviet immigrants are expected in 1991 and between 400,000 and 650,000 in 1992, the Davar daily newspaper said, quoting testimony before a ministerial committee on immigrant absorption. The figures were based on the estimated 1.2 million Soviet Jews who have applied for exit permits, the paper said. Some officials believe a reported rise in anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union will contribute to the immigrant increase. About 88,000 Soviet Jews have come to Israel so far this year, and the number could reach 150,000 by December, acccording to the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, which handles immigration. But estimates by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and other officials forecast about 1 million Soviet Jews will arrive over the next 10 years. Jewish Agency spokesman Gad Ben-Ari said he expects the pace of immigration to increase, but declined to give specific figures. Another Jewish Agency official, Yehuda Weinraub, said applications for exit permits were not a measure for the rate of immigration. ``It's a very long process from then on before they come here,'' Weinraub said. Davar noted in its reports that figures might fluctuate, citing the amount of anti-Semitic activity in the Soviet Union and how successfully the current immigrants adjust to life in Israel. Michael Kleiner, head of Parliament's Immigrant Absorption Committee, said government officials are trying to downplay the pace of immigration because they are overwhelmed. ``It's wishful thinking that the Soviets are going to arrive slowly over the years,'' said Kleiner of Shamir's rigth-wing Likud bloc. ``Someone who is in a panic over anti-Semitism, doesn't plan to leave in five years, he wants to leave now.'' The Jewish Agency says Israel needs $20 billion to absorb 1 million immigrants, while Kleiner put the figure at $30 billion. ``The problem is that we don't have the resources. There is no logical way how Israel can raise $30 billion over the next two or three years,'' he said. Israel has budgeted $2.3 billion over the next three years for immigrant absorption. The Jewish Agency has funneled $740 million in help from abroad, and the International Israel Bonds campaign pledged to raise $1 billion this year. Israel Televison reported Wednesday night that of the 100,000 Soviet Jews who arrived since last year, only 8,000 have found jobs. The report did not say how many immigrants were in the job market, or how many were children or elderly. Ben-Ari noted that many of the adult newcomers are still enrolled in Hebrew classes and are not yet looking for work. He said that of the 13,000 who arrived last year, more than 50 percent found work.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th item to CORRECT to Dennis sted Denis.
DOC.TEXT: Dennis Hopper's wife, Katherine LaNasa, gave birth to a boy a week earlier than expected while the actor was in Georgia filming the movie ``Paris Trout.'' Henry Lee Hopper was born Tuesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Hopper publicist Robin Berg said Wednesday. Hopper, 54, and La Nasa, a 23-year-old dancer-choreographer, were married in 1989. Hopper has starred in such movies as ``Blue Velvet'' and ``Easy Rider.'' His newest film, ``The Hot Spot'' with Don Johnson, comes out Oct. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Broadcasters To Send Radios to Troops
DOC.TEXT: The National Association of Broadcasters at its annual meeting announced a campaign to send radio receivers and batteries to American troops serving in the Persian Gulf. Westinghouse Broadcasting Company's Group W Radio division will lead a fund-raising campaign and the Armed Forces Radio and Television Service will distribute the radios and batteries, the association said. ``Our goal is to get as many radios to as many troops as we possibly can, with a target of 25,000 receivers with batteries,'' said Lynn Christian, an association senior vice president. ``We think radio can play a very important role keeping our fighting people in touch with the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Jordanian Official Estimates 1 Million Refugees
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 1 million people have fled toward Jordan since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, an Interior Ministry official said today. More than 360,000 refugees are waiting to cross into Jordan, and 40,000 _ mostly Asians _ are living in Jordanian camps, said Salameh Hammad, the ministry's general secretary and chairman of the Jordanian refugee committee. Another 589,000 people, many of them Egyptians, have crossed into Jordan on their way home since the Aug 2. invasion, Hammad said. An estimated 2 million foreigners were living in Iraq and Kuwait before Iraq's attack on its oil-rich neighbor. Many of those not fleeing through Jordan are reported to have escaped through Iran, Saudi Arabia or Turkey. Jordan has spent $30 million to care for the refugees, said Hammad. He appealed to the world to come forth with more aid. He said the most squalid of the refugee camps, Shaalan I, had been closed, with its remaining refugees transferred to better-organized facilities or sent home. The camp, which had held up to 50,000 refugees, will be moved closer to the border to serve as a receiving station, said Hammad. Most of the refugees will be transferred to two new camps near Azraq, 50 miles east of Amman, he said. The new sites have water lines, tents and sanitary facilities. Hammad said Jordan was in dire need of food, medicine, transportation and blankets. ``In winter, people need cover,'' he said. British Overseas Development Minister Lynda Chalker, who toured the camps Wednesday, said there was a pressing need for air transport to repatriate the refugees.

DOC.HEAD: Her Grandchildren Call Sergeant `Grambo'
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: Some soldiers being sent to the Persian Gulf have their children at home to worry about. But Air Force reservist Lorain Kuryla, who is nicknamed ``Grambo,'' also has her five grandchildren. When the United States began sending troops to the gulf after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Kuryla _ an Air Force reservist for 19 years _ didn't hesitate to answer a call for volunteers. ``This is what I've been trained for, and I'm glad for the opportunity to serve my country,'' said Kuryla, who turns 63 on Friday. ``In fact I feel better about going because I have no small children at home to care for,'' she adds. ``I feel it will relieve pressure from young mothers and fathers about being sent.'' ``It's kind of weird to think of my mother with an M-16,'' said her son, Michael Kuryla, 37. ``I can honestly say that my mother wears combat boots.'' Leaving behind her family in west suburban Hillside, Kuryla, a master sergeant from the 928th Tactical Airlift Group, left O'Hare International Airport on Wednesday, bound for the Middle East. Kuryla works in Air Force personnel and will be one of three officers sent to the region to handle records, her son said. The grandchildren were the ones to come up with the ``Grambo'' nickname.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Clears Way for Demolition of Remains Of Honkytonk
DOC.TEXT: Gilley's, the defunct honkytonk made famous by the movie ``Urban Cowboy,'' is on its way to becoming a pile of rubble now that a lawsuit is out of the way. The settlement of a lawsuit between country and western singer Mickey Gilley and Sherwood Cryer, his former partner, will allow Gilley to demolish the remains of the club in this Houston suburb that became a symbol of cowboy culture. The club, badly damaged in an arson fire this year, had been open since the early 1970s. The three-year legal battle ended Wednesday with a settlement leaving nearly all former mutual holdings to Gilley. Cryer also agreed to drop a pending appeal of Gilley's $17 million civil court victory in 1988, and Gilley will drop a 1989 lawsuit accusing Cryer of trying to avoid paying the judgment by shifting assets to friends and relatives. ``It's all done,'' Cryer's attorney, Jake Johnson, said today. ``All of the assets have essentially depreciated down to virtually nothing because of the taxes and liens, depreciation, buyer cleanup and all of that. You can divide nothing by two and you've got one-half of nothing. ``It's just very tragic,'' Johnson said. ``It's like a divorce, a long and bitter divorce.'' David Sacks, an attorney for Gilley, said Gilley will start taking bids on the property where the club stood, and that the demolition will rid the suburb of an eyesore. Under the settlement, Gilley will immediately obtain Gilley's Club, Rodeo Arena and several other clubs and convenience stores in Texas and Tennessee. Nearly all the properties, including Gilley's Club, have significant tax liens, Sacks said, making it difficult to value the settlement. It was unclear whether the sale of the holdings will meet the tax obligations plus court costs, he said. Cryer and Gilley must each pay half of $200,000 in fees owed court-appointed receiver Michael Wood.

DOC.HEAD: Two Powerful Nations Initial Accord To Bind Them Closer Together
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs to UPDATE with West German loan for troop withdrawal, Tass claims journalist denied West German visa
DOC.TEXT: West Germany and the Soviet Union today initialed a landmark 20-year friendship treaty designed to bind the two nations closer together after German unity. It is also intended as the cornerstone for massive German help for the battered Soviet economy. The actual signing of the accord is expected soon between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. On Wednesday, the two Germanys and the four World War II victors _ including the Soviet Union _ signed a separate historic treaty that clears the way for a reshaping of the East-West balance of power by removing the final obstacles to German unity. Just as the day before, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his West German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, took pen in hand today for another historic moment, initialing the new treaty. The document intends to bury any German-Soviet suspicions of each other now that a mighty Western-allied Germany is about to spring up in the center of Europe. The Soviets lost 20 million people during World War II and bitter memories of Nazi aggression linger. After the war, Moscow's Cold War influence over Communist East Germany was the source of frequent tension between Bonn and Moscow. With Germany set to unite on Oct. 3, Bonn and Moscow want to lay a solid foundation for relations that have been steadily improving over the past two years. In the newly initialed treaty, the two sides reaffirm pledges not to use force against one another and restate earlier vows to honor all European nations' borders. The document contrasts sharply with the non-agression pact the Soviets signed with Nazi Germany in 1939 carving up Poland and the Baltics. Less than a month later, Germany invaded Poland to begin World War II. The treaty initialed today says the Soviets and Germans ``will solve their differences only through peaceful means.'' ``Should one of the two sides be attacked (by some other nation), the other side will make available no military help .... to the attacker ... and will introduce measures .. to settle the conflict through the use of the United Nations and other structures of collective security,'' the document states. The treaty says the two nations will ``significantly expand'' their bilateral cooperation, ``especially in the economic, industrial and economic-technological areas.'' Bonn and Moscow are working on three sister treaties to the one initialed Thursday. One of those documents will set out the details of expanded economic cooperation, another deals with technological assistance, and the third with covering the costs for 370,000 Red Army troops that will be withdrawn from East Germany over the next four years. No figures have been released from the first two sister documents. The West Germans announced earlier this week they will be providing the Soviets $7.6 billion to help retrain homecoming Red Army troops leaving East Germany and build them new housing. West Germany today also announced an additional $1.9 billion interest-free loan to the Soviets to help fund the troop withdrawal. Amid the goodwill gestures between the nations, the Soviet news agency Tass has complained about the allegeddenial of a visa for its new West German bureau chief. The West German Foreign Ministry said it could neither confirm nor deny the report that Sergei Sosnovsky was barred from the country. Tass said: ``the denial of a visa to a Soviet journalist representing a world news agency can only leave observers perplexed.''

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Meets With West German Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan was warmly welcomed to the West German capital today, a day after a triumphant visit to the remnants of the Berlin Wall. An honor guard greeted Reagan, 79, and his wife, Nancy, as they arrived in a convoy of black limousines at President Richard von Weizsaecker's spacious official residence overlooking the Rhine River. ``Sunshine for you,'' von Weizsaecker's wife, Marianne, told Reagan before the group disappeared inside for lunch. In Bonn, Reagan will also meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl as part of a 10-day private visit to savor the European political changes of the last year. This trip promised to be far more successful than the West German visits Reagan made as president. His May 1985 attendance at an international economic summit in Bonn was overshadowed by a controversy that erupted when he and Kohl visited a German war cemetery in Bitburg, where Nazi SS officers are buried. During another visit to Bonn in 1982, at the height of the crisis over stationing U.S. nuclear missiles in Western Europe, about 200,000 West Germans massed to tell Reagan to go home. In a speech in Berlin on Wednesday, Reagan said West Germany's agreement in the early 1980s to accept nuclear-tipped cruise missile bases was a major turning point in pressing Moscow to accept a new European order. Like thousands before him, Reagan pounded on the Berlin Wall. Three years ago, he stood at the ugly concrete barrier and challenged Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev to tear it down. Germans applauded and shouted ``We love you Ronnie'' and ``Bravo, Ronnie'' as the Reagans walked through the Brandenburg Gate at the former border between East and West Berlin. Berlin, which has been designated the German capital after the two Germanys are merged Oct. 3, was Reagan's first stop on the trip that will also take him to Poland, the Soviet Union, and Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators To Search Woods in Gainesville Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with search under way, quotes from police spokeswoman, federal grant to help fund the search. No pickup. Will be led after law-enforcement briefing, scheduled for 11 a.m. EDT, if developments warrant.
DOC.TEXT: About 200 soldiers and police began today to scour 10 square miles of dense woodlands where police say a suspect in the slayings of five college students reportedly went on night ``reconnaissance missions.'' The search began about 8:30 a.m. and was expected to last two days as investigators combed the land around the apartment of Edward Lewis Humphrey, one of eight people police say are suspects in the stabbing deaths last month. The terrain included swampy wooded areas and a creek where prison inmates last week cleared away weeds and brush. ``This is just another step in the investigation,'' said Gainesville police spokeswoman Sadie Darnell. ``We're certainly not going to leave anything unchecked.'' Alachua County Sheriff's Office spokesman Lt. Spencer Mann said authorities were conducting ``an article search'' with metal detectors, but refused to be more specific. The search party includes 80 people from the Naval Training Center in Orlando, 20 Florida National Guardsmen from Lake City, and officers from numerous state and local police agencies. Two helicopters and about 10 dog teams were participating, Ms. Darnell said. Investigators said they hoped whatever is found would either confirm or rule out Humphrey, an 18-year-old University of Florida freshman, as a suspect. Neighbors have told investigators Humphrey enjoyed dressing up in military clothes, strapping on a knife and slipping into the woods around his apartment at night for imaginary reconnaissance maneuvers. Humphrey remains jailed on charges of beating up his grandmother. Meanwhile, the U.S. Justice Department approved a $941,639 emergency grant to help pay for the investigation into the slayings. The money will come from a special Emergency Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Fund. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement Wednesday that the ``entire nation is appalled by these slayings. It is imperative that the perpetrator or perpetrators of such heinous crimes be swiftly apprehended and held accountable.'' Earlier this week, police said the hunt for the killer had cost state and local law enforcement agencies nearly $750,000.

DOC.HEAD: 2-Year-Old Shot in Apparent Gang Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jonathon is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old boy shot while playing in his front yard was apparently the deliberate target of gang members, police said. Jonathon Fabian was listed in critical but stable condition with a stomach wound today at Martin Luther King Jr.-Drew Medical Center. Police said gang members apparently were responsible for the shooting and to boy did not appear to be the victim of cross fire or a stray bullet. No motive for an intentional shooting was determined. ``Just when you think you know the limits of the insanity, something like this happens,'' said police spokesman Fred Nixon. ``I have never heard of a deliberate gang shooting where the victim was of such a young age.'' Jonathon was playing in a push-car Tuesday evening in his parent's front yard with his father standing nearby, when two shots were fired, police said. Witnesses told sheriff's investigators that they saw three teen-age boys running away. One carried a gun, the witnesses said. ``I don't know if it was fun target practice or what,'' said sheriff's Detective Craig Ditsch. The toddler's 26-year-old mother, Yvonne Fabian, said her family moved into their Lynwood home only three weeks ago. She said she only recently started allowing Jonathon and his baby sister to play in the front yard. In contrast with the police version, teen-agers on the street said the boy might have been the accidental victim of an escalating war between rival gangs. Jonathon was one of four youths shot in Los Angeles within the span of a few hours Tuesday night.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Landmarking Fought by Church
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has ruled that the city did not violate the Bill of Rights when it refused to allow a Park Avenue church to tear down its community house and build a commercial skyscraper. The ruling Wednesday by the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the landmark status bestowed on St. Bartholomew's Church's Community House by the city Landmarks Preservation Commission. St. Bartholomew's senior warden, Fletcher Hodges, said the ruling would make it difficult for the church and its ministries ``to hold together into the 21st Century.'' He said they would appeal to the Supreme Court within 90 days. The church argued it needed the money from rents it would have made at the skyscraper to repair and maintain the 73-year-old church, described as a notable example of a Venetian adaptation of the Byzantine style. Attorney Gerald D. Fischer, representing some parishioners and civic groups opposed to the skyscraper, said he was delighted with the ruling. ``The church has spent $3 million of the parish's money on an effort to develop their property,'' he said. ``Hopefully this is the end and they will cease on this folly.'' The head of the landmarks commission, Laurie Beckelman, called the ruling ``a total affirmation of our powers.'' The judges wrote that ``it is obvious that the landmarks law has drastically restricted the Church's ability to raise revenues to carry out its various charitable and ministerial programs.'' Nevertheless, they said, the Supreme Court has held that ``neutral regulations that diminish the income of a religious organization'' do not violate the First Amendment guarantee of free exercise of religion. The church also claimed that the landmark law violated the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments, because it severely restricted its ability to use the property without just compensation. But the appeals court disagreed, citing a 1978 Supreme Court ruling that prevented Penn Central from building a high-rise atop Grand Central Terminal. The high court said then that the landmark designation did not constitute an unconstitutional ``taking'' because it did not interfere with the historical use of the property and that use continued to be economically viable. ``The Church can continue its existing charitable and religious activities in its current facilities,'' the judges wrote in denying St. Bartholomew's appeal. St. Bartholomew's, organized in 1835, sought an exemption to the 1967 landmark designation of its Community House in December 1983, asking permission to build a 59-story tower. The landmarks commission denied the request and a second one the following year in which the church proposed a scaled-down, 47-story building. The church filed a third application seeking a ``hardship exception,'' which was denied in 1986 following exhaustive public hearings. A review of church finances in the early 1980s indicated that St. Bartholomew's endowment of $9 million would not maintain the buildings and finance church programs, said Hodges.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Company Sues Iraq Over Blocked Furnace Shipment
DOC.TEXT: DS: ADDS (AP) logo, picks up 2nd graf prv

A company blocked by the U.S. government from shipping high-temperature furnaces to Iraq just days before the invasion of Kuwait filed a $62 million suit today against Saddam Hussein's government. Consarc Corp.... 2nd graf prv.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Warns South Africa At War As Violence Rages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with 9 dead, electricity cut off to townships; picks up 7th pvs, `At least...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JOH1,2
DOC.TEXT: At least nine people were killed today and hundreds of homes burned in another day of black factional fighting. The African National Congress warned that South Africa is in an ``undeclared war.'' The ANC has accused the white-dominated government of siding with more conservative blacks who have been battling ANC supporters for a month in fighting that has left more than 700 dead in townships around Johannesburg. Police officials said seven people were killed and about 400 houses and shacks burned in fighting early today at Tokoza township between rival gangs of Zulus and Xhosas armed with axes, swords and clubs. ``It's flattened. It's completely flattened,'' said a stunned woman who went to one area to search for a friend. Thousands of blacks fled the townships with their possessions piled in wheelbarrows and shopping carts, seeking shelter at hospitals, schools and churches. Natalspruit Hospital officials said 8,000 refugees were huddled on hospital grounds for protection. Police also reported one death in Vosloorus, another Johannesburg-area township, and said a black policeman was fatally stabbed in Soweto. Four policemen have been killed in Soweto, the country's largest township, since Tuesday night. White local authorities cut electricity Thursday to Tokoza and Vosloorus in response to a five-month boycott of bill payments by residents, the government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. reported. Ronnie Mamoepa of the anti-apartheid United Democratic Front said the cutoff would spawn ``a climate which is conducive for the escalation of violence.'' Blacks in the townships have refused to pay rent and electricity charges to protest various grievances. But local governments say they are broke and will cut services until the bills are paid. At least 57 people were killed Wednesday, one of the bloodiest days since factional battles began on Aug. 12, police said. Assault guns and tracer bullets, which start fires, were being used in the fighting, The Star newspaper reported today. Among those killed Wednesday, police said, were 25 Zulu migrant workers hacked to death at a hostel in Tembisa. At least one man was beheaded, police said. Chris Hani, head of the ANC's armed wing, said late Wednesday that the country was in an ``undeclared war'' and the opposition group had to defend people. He did not say what action the ANC might take. ``We have a historical obligation to defend our people,'' he said at a memorial service for victims of the violence.``Our duty now is to mobilize the masses and reconsider our strategy.'' Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement have been battling Xhosas and other blacks supporting the African National Congress. The fighting spread from the eastern province of Natal, where the ANC-Inkatha feud has killed about 5,000 blacks since 1986. President F.W. de Klerk and ANC leader Nelson Mandela held talks earlier this week on trying to stop the violence, but failed to agree. The ANC has accused police of helping instigate the violence, accusations rejected by the government. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose apartheid _ the government's policy of racial separation _ but differ over plans for a future South Africa. The left-leaning ANC favors some degree of government economic control while Inkatha champions free market measures. The two sides are also divided over leadership issues with the strongly Zulu nationalist Inkatha charging the ANC is Xhosa-dominated. Many top ANC leaders are Xhosas, but the organization spurns tribal ties.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Work to Contain Forest Fire in Southern Black Hills
DOC.TEXT: A forest fire in the southern Black Hills moved into Custer State Park early today. More people fled their homes, and the U.S. Forest Service bolstered its firefighting efforts. Park Superintendent Rollie Noem said the fire jumped Highway 87, the park's main north-south road, at about 3 a.m. A lodge and some private homes in the area were evacuated. Forest Service spokeswoman Mary Sue Waxler said the size of the fire was about 3,000 acres. About 350 people were fighting the fire, Waxler said, with 100 more on the way. No injuries and no structural damage were reported. No buildings were threatened but fire trucks were standing by to protect property. On Wednesday, 14 homes were evacuated in the general path of the fire. The fire stopped advancing about 1{ miles from the homes. The number of people who live in the area was not known. But officials said 25 families went to a temporary shelter at the Custer Armory looking for places to stay. Shelter director Mary Hutt said all found rooms either with family or friends. The fire was reported about 10:30 a.m. Wednesday by a state fire lookout. Officials said it was caused by logging equipment in a timber sale area south of Cicero Peak. Cicero Peak is a 6,100-foot mountain about 10 miles south of Custer and 10 miles west of the western border of Custer State Park.

DOC.HEAD: White House Says U.S. Official in Kuwait Acted Properly Before Invasion
DOC.TEXT: The White House today declined to criticize U.S. Ambassador April Glaspie for failing to anticipate that Saddam Hussein would invade Kuwait, saying ``the whole world was misled.'' In her dealings with the Iraqi leader prior to the Aug. 2 invasion, Ms. Glaspie was just reflecting then-U.S. policy of seeking to nurture relations with Baghdad, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Fitzwater said the fact that the U.S. ambassador to Iraq is now desk bound at the State Department does not reflect any lack of faith in her abilities. ``We believe Ambassador Glaspie is an outstanding professional,'' Fitzwater said. However, he did not dispute reports that Saddam had made menacing comments to Ms. Glaspie a week before the invasion suggesting that the United States should not oppose Iraqi aims in the Middle East. The Washington Post reported in today's editions that an Iraqi-supplied transcript of the July 25 meeting suggested that Ms. Glaspie reassured Saddam that the United States had no official position on Iraq's border dispute with Kuwait. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher on Wednesday refused to comment on the remarks in the transcript. ``We won't comment on the content or the authenticity'' of the purported transcript,'' Fitzwater said today. Ms. Glaspie was as surprised by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as were other U.S. officials, Fitzwater said. In fact, she flew to London a day before the invasion on her way to Washington. Once here, she was told not to return to Baghdad. The U.S. Embassy in Baghdad now is headed by Joseph C. Wilson III, a career diplomat. Ms. Glaspie has been working as a senior Iraqi desk officer in Washington. ``The fact is that Saddam Hussein has lied to everyone in the world,'' including Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Jordan's King Hussein, Fitzwater said. ``The whole world was misled in that sense.'' Fitzwater said Ms. Glaspie was part of a U.S. task force keeping a close eye on the situation and that she ``maintains daily contacts with her colleagues in the embassy in Baghdad.'' The spokesman said Iraq probably wanted the ``impression out there'' that it had been reassured by the United States in advance of the invasion that Washington would not intervene in its conflict with Kuwait. But, ``I think it's pretty ludicrous to suggest that any time any place we would find it comfortable to have them invade Kuwait. The basic implication is that somehow the U.S. would be willing to look the other way or would have condoned this kind of action. That is ludicrous and stupid.''

DOC.HEAD: Explosion at Plant Manufacturing Nuclear Power Fuel
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and fire hit a plant in Soviet Central Asia that produces fuel for nuclear power stations, discharging gases into the air before the blaze was extinguished, Tass reported today. No one was killed, although several people were injured by the blast and fire, which occurred Wednesday at the Ulbinsky metallurgical plant in the city of Ust-Kamenogorsk, the news agency reported. The city in the republic of Kazakhstan is about 105 miles east of Semipalatinsk, where the Soviet Union conducts its nuclear weapons tests. The explosion occurred in the basement of a workshop involved in the production of beryl, Tass reported. Beryl is a mineral consisting of a silicate of beryllium and aluminum. The levels of radiation in the area were normal, Tass quoted regional official I. Tutevol as saying. The news agency said a preliminary investigation revealed that levels of beryl were twice the permissible level. Tass, which reported the fire was extinguished in 90 minutes, did not specify how many people were hurt or what kind of injuries they suffered, nor did it say what kind of gases were released. It said no one suffered from poisoning by the discharge, which also was halted after an unspecified time.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Rejects Bush Tape But Promises It Will Be Shown
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's effort to send a videotaped message to the Iraqi people hit a snag today when the Iraqi ambassador refused to accept a copy of the message during a visit to the State Department. But the envoy suggested that once a ``better procedure'' was found for delivery of the tape, it will be shown to the Iraqi people ``in its entirety'' during ``prime time.'' ``We welcome the tape,'' Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat told reporters at the State Department after a meeting with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. al-Mashat said that after he rejected the tape, Eagleburger told him the message would be delivered either by the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad to Iraqi authorities or sent by satellite. The State Department had no immediate comment on al-Mashat's account of the conversation. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said ``We are disappointed ... that he declined to take personal possession of the tape for transmittal to Baghdad.'' Fitzwater, in a written statement, said the State Department would transmit the tape to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad ``within the next day or two'' for delivery to the Iraqi government. The administration plans to release the message worldwide unless Iraq shows the tape on state television within five days. al-Mashat said he ``gave Mr. Eagleburger assurances that we welcome it (the tape). We are going to broadcast it in prime time.'' The Iraqi official also raised the possibility that his government might broadcast it via satellite ``for the whole world.'' Fitzwater said Wednesday that Bush, in the eight-minute tape, uses President Saddam Hussein's own words to discredit him. One example was a November 1988 speech in which Saddam says that one Arab country does not have the right to invade another.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Meets Gorbachev; Talk of Another Summit
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Secretary of State James A. Baker III today that another superpower summit meeting was possible before the end of the year. Baker, winding up a three-day Soviet visit, also took up with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze the remaining roadblocks to arms control treaties the Bush administration wants to conclude by the end of the year. Meeting briefly with reporters at a Kremlin session with Baker, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and 15 American business leaders, Gorbachev was asked by the journalists whether there will be another U.S.-Soviet summit in December. ``I think we are going to meet again, if our ministers do not spoil that,'' Gorbachev said. ``A lot of work has to be done first by the ministers and the ambassadors.'' U.S. officials said Tuesday the United States may be willing to agree to further limits on U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe and certain airplanes in order to finish a treating restricting non-nuclear tanks, artillery and other weapons. The other projected treaty would make deep cuts in long-range nuclear weapons. Asked about U.S. troop levels, Gorbachev replied: ``We will have suggestions about that.'' ``We expect to summarize where we are and to see what issues remain for determination,'' Baker told reporters earlier in the day before a meeting with Shevardnadze. Baker later flew to Damascus, Syria, to try to reinforce U.S. cooperation with Syria against Iraq in the Persian Gulf. Asked by the reporters if the Soviet Union would send troops to Saudi Arabia in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Gorbachev replied: ``I hope that there will be no need to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Young Man Attempts With Bar of Soap; Surrenders
DOC.TEXT: A man using a bar of soap he claimed was a grenade surrendered Thursday after trying to hijack a domestic airliner to Australia, airline officials said. The 27-year-old man brandished a handkerchief-covered object and began screaming that he had a grenade 10 minutes after the Indian Airlines plane took off from the southern city of Coimbatore, the officials said. The object turned out to be a bar of soap, said the officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Boeing 737 was carrying 91 passengers and six crew on the Coimbatore-Bangalore flight, a distance of 142 miles. The officials said the man, identified as T. Mahalingam, barged into the cockpit and demanded that the captain, C.T. Srinivas, fly to Perth, Australia, via Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital. The captain kept talking to the man as the plane approached Bangalore, and he convinced him he could be taken to Colombo after Bangalore. Soon after the plane landed, Mahalingam surrendered to security personnel. Police said Mahalingam was a dropout from an engineering college in Coimbatore.

DOC.HEAD: First International Shark Conference Planned
DOC.TEXT: The declining shark population will top the agenda when experts from around the world attend the first international conference on the widely feared fish. Tim Moore, the environment minister of New South Wales state, said shark numbers are falling worldwide because of too much fishing. He said it's time Australians change their attitude to ``give sharks a fair go.'' About 100 million sharks are harvested from the world's oceans every year, with the level of fishing more than doubling over the last five years, he said Wednesday. Most sharks are killed to supply the Asian shark fin market. The conference, ``Sharks Down Under,'' will be held at Sydney's Taronga Zoo in February with leading shark experts discussing shark conservation and biology. The conference will include a dive into an underwater cave at Seal Rocks on the state's north coast, a shark resting place.

DOC.HEAD: Temple Offers Free Grave Sites to New Believers
DOC.TEXT: At a time when skyrocketing land prices are affecting even cemeteries, a temple in Tokyo is offering free grave plots to people who convert to the Buddhist sect of Tendai. The Saikoji Temple said Thursday it is offering 250 plots, worth $8,700 each, to Tokyo residents on condition they convert to Tendai, the Japanese counterpart of the Chinese Tiantai sect. The grave sites are in a former parking lot inside the temple compound. ``I understand the offer is aimed at helping people in need, because of the acute shortage of graves and cemeteries in big cities like Tokyo,'' said Terataka Kyodo, the wife of the temple's head priest. Most cemeteries in Japan are on the grounds of temples or are maintained by private companies or municipal governments. Many in big cities are nearly full. Each plot is generally used by an entire family. People who want their own graves must first pay a lump sum for perpetual rent, often amounting to tens of thousands of dollars, to the owners of the cemeteries. In addition, regular payments for maintenance must be made, even after death.

DOC.HEAD: Jackpot Hits $100 Million in Florida Lottery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with increase to $100 million; picks up 5th graf, `The nation's...'
DOC.TEXT: Lottery players snapped up tickets at a rate of 300 per second in hopes of hitting the second-biggest jackpot in U.S. history, set today at $100 million. ``I'm getting lost with all the zeroes,'' Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul said as she changed a promotion sign from $96 million. By 11 a.m. today, the Florida Lottery had sold five times as many tickets as its previous record week, Mrs. Paul said. For the fourth day in a row, the pace of sales persuaded the Lottery Department to increase the estimated jackpot. But Mrs. Paul said the total would not be increased again before Saturday night's drawing. The nation's biggest jackpot is $115 million, shared by 14 ticket-holders in Pennsylvania in April 1989. In Florida, a Tampa father and son went to lottery headquarters in Tallahassee and bought 10,000 tickets. ``I saved up for it. I figured it would be a good use,'' said Anthony Giardino, 21, who bought 2,000 tickets. His father, who would not speak to reporters, bought 8,000. It took nearly seven hours to print them all. ``I figured I have a good chance of winning,'' Giardino said. In reality, the odds of winning are 1 in 14 million. In Orlando, office clerk Gary Clark said he didn't see any reason to spend more than twice his weekly allotment for tickets. ``This $10 right here is what's going to get me the big one,'' he said. ``The more everybody spends on this the better, because they'll all be contributing to me.'' At 4 p.m. Wednesday, the state was selling 300 Lotto tickets every second, Lottery Department spokesman Ed George said. By 5 p.m., 9.5 million tickets had been sold for the day, bringing the week's total to about 26.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: The Party's Over; Celebrity Immigrant Left Stranded When Hoopla Ends
DOC.TEXT: Israel's 100,000th immigrant this year was greeted with great fanfare on arrival but said Thursday he and his family were left stranded at the airport when the hoopla was over. ``After the big hubbub was finished, we were the last ones at the airport, and we didn't have a place to stay,'' said 87-year-old Yitzhak Krasiltchik, from the Soviet city of Leningrad. Krasiltchik arrived in Israel on Tuesday on a flight with 140 other Soviet immigrants. Most of Israel's 100,000 immigrants this year have been Soviet Jews. Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz met him at Ben Gurion Airport, and he was whisked in a limousine to the arrivals lounge where children serenaded him. But after Peretz and the journalists left, Krasiltchik found he and the four members of his family had missed the bus to their destination, the town of Arad in the southern Negev Desert. ``I kept telling the absorption officials that I wanted to go to Arad, but they said it's too far and they told us to go to a hotel in Tel Aviv. It cost us about 700 shekels ($350) for the hotel room and a taxi to Arad the next morning,'' Krasiltchik said in a telephone interview from Arad. He spoke through an interpreter. Asked whether he regretted his celebrity status, he said: ``Not at all, I enjoy all the attention.'' He added he was getting special treatment in Arad because of his newfound fame. Krasiltchik, who walks with a cane, said he wanted to take it easy once he is settled. ``I want to live in peace and joy and go to the synagogue every day,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 33,000 Voted for Jail Inmate
DOC.TEXT: A jail inmate awaiting his second trial on a first-degree murder charge was the choice of 33,004 Minnesotans to serve as state treasurer. Leonard J. Richards, 48, finished last among the three candidates vying for the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party nomination in Tuesday's primary. ``I have no theory about why anybody would vote for him,'' said incumbent Michael McGrath, who won the nomination with 148,617 votes. Richards, who ran for the U.S. House in 1974 and the U.S. Senate in 1978, was convicted in the 1987 shooting and stabbing death of his tax attorney. He was granted a new trial by the Minnesota Supreme Court because he was not allowed to be his own attorney. That enabled him to file for office since, technically, it obliterated his only felony conviction. Richards, who is in the Hennepin County jail, also has been indicted on murder charges in the 1982 death of his half-sister, May Wilson. Her throat was slashed in a crime allegedly motivated by a large insurance award. ``It's impossible for the voters to know a lot about all the candidates,'' said Secretary of State Joan Growe. ``You have to remember that the primary is just one step along the way. That's one of the reasons we have all these steps, so we don't have these kinds of things, hopefully.''

DOC.HEAD: Secession Effort, Gunbattle Reported
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic Albanian deputies of the outlawed Kosovo Parliament declared secession from Serbia and proclaimed their province the seventh Yugoslav republic, the state news agency Tanjug said today. Meanwhile, Radio Belgrade said police raided an ethnic Albanian village looking for arms and foreign currency, and two Albanians were killed in a gunbattle. Two policemen were wounded, one seriously, in the shootout, it said. The proclamation of independence and adoption of a constiution for Kosovo was made Sept. 7 at a secret and ``illegal'' session of the former Kosovo legislature attended by 111 delegates, Tanjug said. The declaration, distributed to Yugoslav journalists in Kosovo's provincial capital of Pristina, has no legal validity but may provoke more Serbian anger and police repression against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, sources said. Authorities in Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, dissolved the Kosovo assembly July 5, three days after its ethnic Albanian deputies voted for a document proclaiming the province's secession from Serbia. In their Sept. 7 meeting, lawmakers also adopted an unspecified constitution of the republic of Kosovo, Tanjug said. Serbian authorities claim that ethnic Albanians are seeking independence from Serbia as a first step toward joining neighboring Albania. Yugoslav republics are viturally independent states, which according to the current constitution can declare their independence from Yugoslavia. The Tanjug report, which could not be independently confirmed, said the declaration extended the term of the dissolved Kosovo parliament and the provincial government until free elections are held in the region. The dismantled Kosovo legislature was dominated by ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the province's 1.9 million people. The dissolution virtually abolished the autonomy Kosovo, administratively a part of Serbia, had enjoyed under Yugoslavia's 1974 constitution. The province, considered by Serbs the ancient heartland of their culture, has been the scene of inter-communal strife since Serbia's Communist government introduced strict limits on the region's self-government in March 1989. At least 60 Albanian protesters have died in sporadic clashes with the Serbian-run security forces, and thousands more have been sacked from their jobs or jailed, according to international human rights groups. Radio Belgrade said the shootout this morning lasted for more than five hours after police surrounded the village of Podujevo, 18 miles north of Pristina. ``Armed resistance was given during the raid on part of a number of persons who used different weapons, both from the building being checked, as well as from nearby groves and hamlets,'' Tanjug said in a report. A large quantity of arms of different caliber and purposes, communications and unspecified military equipment were discovered, the reports said. Tanjug quoted Serbian officials as saying 25 people were detained.

DOC.HEAD: Latest German Concern: What to Do About Socialist Statues
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A towering Soviet soldier smashes a swastika with a giant sword. Marx stares at passing traffic. Cars roll down Ho Chi Minh. Lenin tugs on his lapel. Germany is less than three weeks away from becoming a single bastion of Western capitalism, but much of the new nation will be filled with totems to the old East Germany. While leaders argue over how to pay for unification and East Germans worry about their jobs, many towns are wondering what to do with all those old statues, streets, squares and schools dedicated to the stalwarts of socialism. It is a problem far more complex than merely changing street signs and carting away scowling icons of stone and bronze. In southern East Germany, Karl Marx City wasted little time reclaiming its historical name, Chemnitz. But it is taking much longer to decide what to do with Karl himself, a huge, glowering bust that dwarfs tourists who stare at his gargantuan noggin in the heart of town. No community has taken a greater interest in this issue than East Berlin, the showcase of the former Communist government and the historic heart of what will be the capital of a united nation. An estimated 800 postwar monuments dot the cityscape, some of them the centerpieces of squares. In Leninplatz, the Soviet revolutionary is affixed to a jagged panel, scowling in flowing overcoat, one hand on his lapel and the other clenched at his side. In Marx-Engels Platz, Engels stands erect while Marx sits at his side, his huge lap a favorite place for tourists to nestle for photo opportunities. A committee of artists and historians convened last week to begin an monument-by-monument appraisal of what to do with the memorials. A similiar committee has been charged with examining street names. Some Germans want to remove all remnants of the regime imposed by the Soviets after World War II. Others say they should, to some extent, be preserved. ``Monuments, even if they are horrible or an attack against good taste, are part of the postwar history here,'' said Klaus Hetzel, a spokesman for the East Berlin government. ``You can find other solutions for them.'' The East Berlin committee members believe many statues will be retained but altered, perhaps by adding plaques that put them in historical perspective. Others may have new gardens or green spaces around them to soften them. Still others may be carted away to a single location, becoming part of a museum that will in a sense be a graveyard of Communist artifacts. ``What we do not want to do is merely get rid of everything,'' said Richard Dahlheim, deputy chairman of the city's Cultural Affairs Department. ``Too many historical remnants are lost to the emotions of the moment.'' Few monuments trigger more emotions than the giant Soviet memorial in East Berlin's charming Treptow Park. Many people are stunned by the militaristic scope of this tribute to Soviet soldiers who died while conquering Germany from the east. To see it, a visitor follows a path lined with birch trees leading to a pedestal of stairs. Two red granite walls shaped like drooping flags form a gateway. Two giant Soviet soldiers kneel in front of each wall. On the other side is a lawn that stretches for more than 550 yards, the burial place for 5,000 Soviet soldiers. On each side are eight stone sacrcophagi depicting feats of heroism. At the end of the lawn is a mausoleum on which a 38-foot-high soldier stands. Broad-shouldered and handsome, the soldier smashes a swastika with a sword and clutches a child, creating an idealized image of a Soviet avenger slaying the Nazi oppressors and saving the innocent. Many Germans want it shipped back to the Soviets. ``Marx is okay, but get rid of that thing,'' said Werner Tischer, 72, a native Berliner. West Berlin also has monuments to its World War II occupiers, including a Soviet memorial and a street named after Karl Marx. Hetzel said it will be up to a future united Berlin government what should remain or be modified. An estimated 100 to 200 streets are being studied by the East Berlin streets committee, ranging from streets named after Salvador Allende, the former Marxist leader of Chile; to Konstantin Ziolkowski, a father of Soviet flight technology. They already have decided to change the name of Otto Grotewohl street, named after the first East German prime minister who was a hard-line Stalinist. One broad avenue Americans are always startled to see is named after Ho Chi Minh, the Communist leader who drove the Americans out of Vietnam. There is even a Wall Street. Its namesake nearby, however, has been reduced to rubble.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Starts Energy Conservation Effort; Critics Say Not Enough
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops with 12 grafs, Picks up 4th graf pvs. Addressing a ... Edits throughout to shorten
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration unveiled a revised program today to ease the shortfall in oil, but Energy Secretary James Watkins said worldwide shortages could linger at near 1 million barrels a day through the winter. Watkins said he believed the shortfall can be ``managed'' through conservation efforts and additional domestic production. He left open the possibility of drawing oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in the coming months if conservation and increased production efforts fall short of expectations. But he reiterated it was too soon to use the reserve, which holds nearly 600 million barrels. ``That's a cherished reserve that has a finite life ... and we don't want to use it too early,'' Watkins told the Senate Energy and Natural Resource Committee. He said he was ``comfortable'' that the department would be ready to take oil from the reserve in short notice if needed. The department outlined a revised combined program of energy conservation and oil production measures that officials said was aimed at cutting the oil supply shortfall in the United States by about 1.1 million barrels a day. The new program, including a radio advertising campaign urging conservation, came amid increasing criticism that the administration's efforts to ease the country's reliance on foreign oil have been more rhetoric than substance. ``The president should give more than a speech. He should give us a program,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said Wednesday in response to Bush's call for increased energy conservation in light of the Persian Gulf crisis. Watkins rejected such criticsm, saying the administration's efforts to increase production and get Americans to conserve oil are ``substantive ... We do not think they are trivial.'' Much of the department's program announced today mirrored the response plan announced shortly after the Mideast crisis developed, including calls on motorists to conserve fuel by properly inflating tires and various measures to expand production from existing domestic oil fields. But Watkins said as much as 165,000 barrels of day also could be saved by fuel switching and urged that regulatory and other barriers be eased to promote switching. He said there are 37 natural gas pipeline proposals awaiting federal or state approval. The plan also included tax incentives for oil and gas production, expanded production from Alaska and opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil exploration _ all proposals announced previously. Watkins said current crude oil stocks were well above levels at the same time last year, but he said there was a 3.6 million barrel worldwide production shortfall in September and that the shortfall was expected to be gradually reduced to about 1 million by next January and slightly lower in the succeeding months. The United Nations economic embargo imposed on Iraq slashed available production from Iraq and occupied Kuwait by 4 million barrels a day. Addressing a joint session of Congress on the Middle East crisis Tuesday night, Bush asked lawmakers to enact measures to increase domestic oil and gas production and said conservation is ``essential to keep our energy needs as low as possible.'' But environmentalists and some members of Congress say the administration has been slow in developing an energy plan and is giving only scant emphasis to energy conservation, while emphasizing expanded drilling, possibly in environmentally sensitive areas. ``Never once did he mention renewable energy,'' Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said of Bush's speech. But since returning from their August recess, members of Congress also have been short on specific proposals. The exception has been House and Senate legislation calling for dramatic increases in automobile fuel economy. Legislation sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., would require automakers to improve the average fuel economy of new cars to 40 miles per gallon by 2001. On Wednesday, Bryan and other sponsors said the measure would cut the demand for petroleum by 2.8 million barrels a day by the turn of the century. But the White House has opposed the measure and a recently circulated policy memo suggested that the president likely would veto it.

DOC.HEAD: Army Truck Overturns, Kills 11
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet army truck speeding around a sharp curve overturned and caught fire in the republic of Lithuania on Thursday, killing 11 soldiers and injuring seven, Tass reported. The accident occurred in the western part of the Baltic republic in the village of Pasaltonis, the news agency reported. The injured soldiers were hospitalized with burns, and two were in serious condition, Tass said. It said the military was investigating.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Company Making Limited Number of AK-47s
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. company for the first time is manufacturing assault-style AK-47 rifles that were banned from import, but the company owner says he wants his gunmaking business to be short-lived. E. Robert Jensen, president of Lathrop's Shooters Supply Inc. of Tucson, Ariz., said he's making the weapons only to ``recoup the losses from what the government did to me'' when it banned imports just as his shipments of already paid-for rifles came into port. ``I chose to see if I couldn't find a way to get out of the program in 60 to 90 days,'' he said ``I want out of that market.'' Jensen had gotten permits from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to import the guns before he bought them, but Customs wouldn't let him take the weapons. Instead, he had to break them down and leave behind the receiver, which is the trigger and firing mechanism. Jensen hired a company to produce new receivers and assemble the rifles. He says his version of the AK-47 is better than the imports: ``It was made to higher specifications than anything the Chinese ever made.'' Last summer's ban on imports didn't cover domestic production of assault-style weapons that had been barred from import, said Jack Killorin, spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. But Killorin called Jensen's action an example of why Congress should pass President Bush's proposal to ban such manufactures. The legislation is pending before Congress. The bureau permanently barred imports of 43 models of foreign-manufactured assault-style rifles in July 1989, saying the weapons didn't meet the ``sporting uses'' requirement for imported firearms. The weapons were equipped with military-type accoutrements such as folding or collapsible stocks, pistol grips, threaded barrels for silencers, flash suppressors, bayonet lugs and large capacity ammunition magazines. The ban was prompted by the public outcry after the Jan. 17, 1989, slayings of five children in a Stockton, Calif., schoolyard by a drifter wielding an AK-47. ``This most recent action ... illustrates the industry's creativity when there's a loophole to be exploited and a dollar to be made,'' said Josh Sugarmann, director of the Firearms Policy Project who first noticed the AK-47s were being made by Jensen's company. Killorin and Jensen said they knew of no other U.S. company that was manufacturing assault-style firearms banned from import. ``I don't think anyone else is crazy enough to get involved in this,'' said Jensen, who said he has been in the firearms distribution and retail business since 1955. ``There's no money in the firearms manufacturing market,'' he said. ``If I can come out even it's going to be a victory.'' Jensen has sued the government in federal court over the import ban, although the government has won similar legal battles. ``We don't have any problem with the fact that BATF arbitrarily and capriciously decided they weren't going to issue any more permits,'' Jensen said. ``But I had issued permits on the basis of which I purchased the firearms. They were legal, saleable private property.'' He would not specify how many guns were involved, narrowing it only to the ``mid-four figures.'' Nor would he say how many AK-47s he's manufacturing with the salvaged parts. The original price of the new guns to dealers was $498 each for nine or fewer, $449 each for 10 or more. But Jensen said he dropped both prices about $50 to move the guns more quickly. ``That's still a premium price,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Court: Dying Can Refuse Forced Feeding
DOC.TEXT: Florida's Supreme Court ruled today that dying people have a right to refuse forced feeding, and that guardians can make the decision for people who are incompetent to act on their own. Further, the justices ruled, dying people and their guardians don't need a court's approval before they stop forced feeding. The foundation of the decision, which comes in the case of an elderly woman who died last summer, is the right to privacy as guaranteed by the Florida Constitution. ``The right of privacy would be an empty right were it not to extend to competent and incompetent persons alike,'' Justice Rosemary Barkett wrote in today's majority opinion. Estelle Browning spent the last 2{ years of her life hooked up to a feeding tube despite a ``living will'' she had left saying that she didn't want to be kept alive under such conditions. She was not comatose, but was not able to either swallow or communicate and was considered incompetent. Florida's high court heard oral arguments in the case in January. In June, the U.S. Supreme Court said a Missouri couple could not order the removal of food and water keeping their 32-year-old comatose daughter alive. The daughter, Nancy Cruzan, had not left a living will, although her parents said they were certain she would prefer to die rather than live in a coma. The U.S. Supreme Court did say that competent people have a right to refuse medical treatment. The Florida court, which cited that case, went on to say that it has found previously that incompetent people have the same right, through guardians acting on statements made before becoming incompetent, to refuse medical treatment as competent people. The Browning case extended that ruling to people in Florida who are not totally comatose but who cannot make their own decisions. ``The decision to terminate artificial life-sustaining measures is being made over and over in nursing homes, hospitals, and private homes in this nation,'' Barkett wrote. ``It is being made painfully by loving family members, concerned guardians, or surrogates, in conjunction with the advice of ethical and caring physicians or other health care providers. It is being made when the only alternative to a natural death is to artificially maintain a bare existence.'' The opinion was fully endorsed by five of the seven justices, one of whom wrote an additional, one-paragraph opinion. Justice Ben Overton partially agreed with the rest of the court.

DOC.HEAD: Retirees Help Fill Gaps on Ships During Middle East Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Merchant seamen who have guided vessels around the world are coming out of retirement to man the helms and engine rooms of military supply ships bound for the Middle East. ``I want to go out as a champ. I'm a damn good sailor. I can cut the mustard,'' said Donald Covert, a reactivated retiree who admitted only to being ``over 65.'' ``Oh, yeah, they can cut the mustard,'' agreed Wade ``K.O.'' Hughes, a National Maritime Union agent in Houston. ``They're able-bodied men. They're tough seamen.'' Jessica Smith, a spokeswoman for the Camp Springs, Md.-based Seafarers International Union, said union officials last month issued a manpower alert to physically fit retirees and other inactive members. ``We've taken a number of steps to meet the increased crewing requirements because of the conflict in the Middle East,'' she said. ``In addition to asking the guys on the commercial fleet to stay on there, we've also asked our inactive members and pensioners to get ready to ship out.'' The Seafarers, one of several maritime unions for unlicensed crew members on oceangoing vessels and inland waterways, told members their country needed their skills. In the August issue of the Seafarers' Log, the union reported ``privately operated ships under contract to the Military Sealift Command and vessels in the Ready Reserve Force were deployed to take part in Operation Desert Shield.'' As demand for supply ships and other support vessels continued, Seafarers President Michael Sacco ordered the manpower alert. And the response has been overwhelming. Clarence Holloway, a 35-year sea veteran, served on cargo ships in World War II, Korea and Vietnam. ``Why should I stay here?'' the Houston man asked. ``It's just as dangerous here. You can get shot here.'' ``My country needs me,'' said Charles A. Mills, 69, with 52 years' sea experience. ``There aren't enough trained seamen to man all the ships hauling military cargo into the Persian Gulf.'' The unions have given retirees dispensations to continue receiving pension checks in addition to their salaries for shipboard work for up to six months. ``We have had several from our pensioners and older members volunteer to help us with this crisis,'' Hughes said. ``These are guys with key ratings, specialist-type ratings that just aren't available anywhere else.'' Hughes said because many of the retirees have served on vessels since World War II, they are more familiar with the reactivated Navy vessels and older ships. ``They're taking jobs that we cannot fill with our current personnel because our current personnel either don't have those specialty ratings or are already at sea,'' Hughes said. ``There are more jobs now,'' he said. ``They've taken a lot of ships out of mothballs now and there are more jobs on older vessels.'' Ms. Smith said the union has sent out the call to deckhands, storage workers and engine room workers. In the past month, she said the union suspended onboard working limits for certain seamen classifications, combed lists of retirees and kept union halls open on nights and weekends to register more workers. Of about 100 union retirees who volunteered to be reactivated, seven have been shipped out by last week, she said. Hughes said Maritime union's local chapter has had ``at least 75 retired guys call or come in wanting to help.'' Of those, he said about 30 already have been sent to sea. ``They're seamen who maintain the ships, maintain the engine rooms, keep up the appearance of the ship and serve food,'' Hughes said. ``Their age ranges from 55 to whatever age, as long as they are physically fit, they can do it. ``They've always been there when they were needed,'' Hughes said.

DOC.HEAD: House Puts Off Action on Defense Due to Budget Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts grafs 6-7 reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The House today postponed action on the $283 billion defense bill as lawmakers awaited a possible agreement by White House and congressional negotiators on a plan to trim $50 billion from the federal deficit. With the likelihood that a final figure for military spending could emerge from the talks, the House put aside work on the defense budget for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, until next week. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told reporters the postponement was designed ``to give our negotiators a little opportunity.'' Meanwhile, the House is sending a pointed message to U.S. allies slow to provide military and financial help for the Persian Gulf deployment: The United States will no longer foot the entire bill for defending the world. Angered by Japan's delay in giving $1 billion to a campaign that could cost up to $15 billion in the next year, the House on Wednesday adopted a measure requiring the Asian nation to pay all the costs of stationing U.S. forces on its soil, or begin losing the troops. The White House, which already has threatened a veto of the bill because it would cut troop levels and terminate the B-2 Stealth bomber, criticized the provision on Japan. ``We don't believe that's an apppropriate way to conduct foreign policy,'' said press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. But he noted that the vote ``does express the sentiment of the Congress. I think Japan is aware of the general feeling in the Congress toward some of their activities.'' The amendment was one of three burden-sharing proposals added to the $283 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, by lawmakers who spent several hours of debate lashing out at America's friends. The House had planned to resume action on the bill today with the following issues on the agenda: _Amendments to increase or decrease the level of spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative in fiscal 1991. President Bush had called for a budget of $4.7 billion for the program commonly known as Star Wars. The Senate trimmed about $1 billion from the 1991 request; the House slashed nearly $2 billion. In debate on Tuesday, the ranking Republican on the House Armed Services panel, Rep. Bill Dickinson of Alabama, raised the possibility of a Bush veto if lawmakers ``decimate the program.'' But Rep.
