Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., sponsor of an amendment to end Star Wars, said it was time to stop spending ``billions of dollars on a fairy tale.'' _Debate over the B-2 stealth bomber, the costliest weapon in history at some $860 million a plane. Proponents of the radar-evading aircraft plan to discuss the bomber's merits but no vote on the issue is planned. If approved, the House bill calls for halting production of the plane at the 15 bombers under construction. _Amendments to assist communities, businesses and workers left without a job due to cutbacks in defense spending that force the closing or scaling back of military contractors. Prompted by the rising cost of Operation Desert Shield and little in the way of assistance from Japan, West Germany and other U.S. allies, lawmakers vented their frustrations on Tuesday in overwhelming votes on burden-sharing. By a vote of 370-53, the House adopted the amendment requiring Japan to pay all the costs associated with the 50,000 U.S. troops stationed there. For each year Japan does not cover the costs, 5,000 troops would be taken out of the country. The United States spends $4.5 billion annually for U.S. forces in Japan; Japan contributes $2.9 billion. ``This is a real wake-up call for the new world order,'' said Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., sponsor of the amendment targeting Japan. Neither the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., nor Dickinson voted for the measure, but Aspin summed up the motivations of his colleagues. ``It is not the right thing to do substantively but it's irresistible politically,'' he said. The House also agreed to require the Defense Department to come up with a plan by 1994 to ``dual base'' all military units _ permanently stationing all American troops in the United States and ordering short-term rotation overseas. It also agreed to prohibit use of any Defense Department money for building a new air base at Crotone, Italy, for the 401st Tactical Air Wing of F-16 jet fighters forced to move from Torrejon, Spain. An amendment to eliminate the two provisions failed, 249-174. The House, however, rejected an amendment that would impose a permanent ceiling of 30,000 on the number of U.S. troops in South Korea with that goal to be achieved by fiscal 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Two Powerful Nations Initial Accord To Bind Them Closer Together
DOC.TEXT: West Germany and the Soviet Union initialed a landmark treaty Thursday intended to eliminate long-standing distrust between the Soviets and Germans as the powerful new German nation emerges. The document is also intended as the cornerstone for German help for the battered Soviet economy. Already, West Germany has pledged to give the Soviets $7.6 billion to help cover the withdrawal of Soviet troops from East Germany. Another $1.9 billion will be contributed in the form of a low-interest loan from Bonn. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and his West German counterpart, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, initialed the friendship treaty. A day earlier, both were among the six signatories of the historic agreement clearing the way for German unification. The actual signing of the friendship accord is expected sometime soon between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The Soviets suffered massive losses during World War II. After the war, Moscow's Cold War influence over Communist East Germany was the source of frequent tensions between Bonn and Moscow. The treaty states that it is of primary importance to ``finally be done with the past, and to use understanding and reconciliation to achieve an important contribution toward the overcoming of Europe's division through understanding and reconciliation.'' With Germany set to reunite Oct. 3, Bonn and Moscow want to lay a solid foundation for relations that have been steadily improving over the past two years. ``Now we can with justification say that the postwar period is over,'' Genscher elatedly said after the ceremony. As the two nations were planning closer relations, the Soviet news agency Tass reported that Bonn had denied a visa for Tass' new bureau chief in West Germany. The West German Foreign Ministry said it could neither confirm nor deny the report that Sergei Sosnovsky was being barred from the country. Tass said that as relations between the countries improve, ``the denial of a visa to a Soviet journalist representing a world news agency can only leave observers perplexed. ``The journalist has been denied a possibility of providing objective information, which is expected by Tass subscribers in the Soviet Union and abroad,'' the state-run news agency said. The friendship treaty is the most comprehensive bilateral accord between the Soviets and West Germany since a 1970 treaty in which they renounced the use of force against each other. In the new document, the two sides reaffirmed pledges not to use force against one another, and to ``honor without reservation the territorial integrity of all European states in their current borders.'' ``Should one of the two sides be attacked (by some other nation), the other side will make available no military help .... to the attacker ... and will introduce measures .. to settle the conflict through the use of the United Nations and other structures of collective security,'' the document states. Foreign ministers from the united Germany and the Soviet Union will meet at least twice a year, according to the treaty. The document further says that the nations will ``significantly expand'' their bilateral cooperation, ``especially in the economic, industrial and economic-technological areas.''

DOC.HEAD: Rancher Butts Heads With State Over Exotic Game Ranch
DOC.TEXT: A millionaire rancher is locking horns with the state over a plan to establish an exotic game ranch on his 18,000-acre spread. John Dorrance III, an heir to the Campbell Soup fortune, thumbed his nose at the state Game and Fish Department two weeks ago when he brought a dozen mixed breed deer to his ranch bordering Devil's Tower in northeastern Wyoming. Dorrance says he's just trying to make an old-fashioned profit. He wants to breed the rare animals and sell their lean meat to fancy restaurants, their hides to clothiers and their horns to Asians, who say they make great aphrodisiacs. ``I'm a threat to the Game and Fish. Let's face it. I'm something they despise. I've got money and I've got private property,'' said Dorrance. State wildlife officials say that's nonsense. They contend the animals _ three-way crossbreeds of red deer, sika deer and elk _ could escape, spread disease and inbreed with Wyoming's majestic, purebred wildlife. The deer were bred in Missouri. ``The best guarantee that these animals won't spread disease to native wildlife is to get them out of the state,'' said agency spokesman Larry Kruckenberg. ``The bottom line is simple _ we don't want the animals here or the threats they pose.'' The controversy has resulted in dueling lawsuits, environmental outrage and a splash of Wyoming wit. While the wildlife agency and environmentalists hardly find humor in the dispute, Wyoming residents are already lampooning the great grandson of condensed soup. ``What's John Dorrance's ultimate vision? Cream of Sika soup,'' chortles one jokester. A local newspaper cartoon suggested that even Bambi will need a lawyer if Dorrance's plans to create a full scale game ranch with wild boar, ibex and mouflon sheep were realized. But Dorrance maintains he has done nothing illegal because his dozen hybrid deer are less than 50 percent of any one strain of species, and are therefore not considered wildlife under Wyoming law. Dorrance calls the deer ``non-traditional livestock'' and are not under the jurisdiction of the Game and Fish Department. ``In bringing these animals into the state, I am simply exercising my right to pursue free enterprise and to do with my land as I see fit,'' said the 45-year-old Dorrance, who has been a rancher for 16 years in the hilly terrain made famous in the movie ``Close Encounters of the Third Kind.'' ``The animals are legal, free of disease and parasites and double-fenced. They aren't going to hurt anyone.'' The wildlife agency disagrees and on Wednesday held a telephone conference that resulted in an emergency rule that redefines ``exotic wildlife,'' a definition that is at the heart of the dispute between Dorrance and the department. The rule change came too late to cover the 12 animals Dorrance has already brought in from Missouri, but any others he planned to bring in would fall under the new rule. The department also maintains the new rule wasn't needed to outlaw Dorrance's hybrids, arguing that since red deer and elk are essentially the same species, the animals do fall under their control even under the old rules. The rancher says he will continue to fight for his private property rights, no matter how much it costs. ``When I moved here, I thought `Wyoming is what America was.' Now I think Wyoming wants to be what Russia was _ a bureaucratic nightmare where everything is controlled by a central government.''

DOC.HEAD: King Hussein Presses On In Gulf Peace Quest Despite Setbacks
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein's ceaseless travels in search of gulf peace have raised scant hope, Jordanian officials admitted Thursday, but Hussein plans to step up efforts to find a breakthrough. ``The king has no other choice but to keep trying,'' one senior government official said. ``The alternative is war, a prospect too horrifying for us to contemplate.'' Hussein returned Sept. 4 from a nine-day trip to Britain, West Germany, Italy, Spain and five North African countries. The next day, he called on Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein in Baghdad. He met late Wednesday with Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestinian Liberation Organization, whose own initiatives link Kuwait to the Israeli-occupied territories. The king has said he has no specific peace plan. Instead, he is throwing out ideas. Although he expressed some optimism to reporters in London, he has made no comment since returning to Amman. ``He did not find the flexibility he had hoped for in Europe,'' said one official who, like the others interviewed, spoke on the condition of anonymity. In every European capital, governments insisted that nothing less than a total Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait would be acceptable. King Hussein's approach is to find ground on which Saddam and his adversaries can edge their way back from the brink. ``He feels he has the confidence of Saddam and can help in this situation,'' one aide said. ``If anyone thinks the Iraqis will budge if you don't have their confidence, he's mistaken.'' Jordan has condemned Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, and the royal family insists that it is respecting the U.N. trade embargo that followed. But, said one official, echoing the view of others, ``We just feel that we know the Iraqis well, and we have a different idea about how to convince them to change their minds. We will not stop trying.'' In the Jordanian view, Saddam can be persuaded to pull out of Kuwait if the conditions allow him to emerge with some aura of victory among his Arab followers. Iraq has said it would only talk about Kuwait in the context of U.N. resolutions demanding that Israel withdraw from Palestinian territories in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``He's already brought the Palestinian issue onto the central stage where no one can ignore it,'' one official noted. ``And he has established his zone of influence as a geo-economic power.'' If Saddam can win access to the gulf through a small part of what was Kuwaiti territory, the official said, reflecting Jordan's analysis, he might reverse his annexation of Kuwait and withdraw. Iraq has only a short strip of coastline in the northern gulf and has long demanded control of the Kuwaiti islands of Bubiyan and Warbah, which dominate Iraq's maritime outlets. As the United States continues its military buildup and rallies international support for an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal, there is little chance for any such compromise, the Jordanians acknowledge. But as Saddam enhances his prestige among Arabs by standing firm against a superior foreign force, and as time hangs heavily on U.S. troops in the stifling heat of the Saudi Arabian desert, they expect the picture to change. Meantime, King Hussein is positioning his little kingdom to serve as moderator. Jordan habitually seeks middle ground in the Middle East crises that swirl around it. But the gulf confrontation has squeezed it from both sides. Western leaders charge that Jordan is too close to Iraq, providing aid and comfort to an international outlaw. Saddam wants firmer support from his old friend. ``Whatever King Hussein might feel, the Jordanians' sympathy for Saddam's position is evident, and no leader can ignore public opinion,'' one senior aide said.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Subpoenas Energy Department Committee
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury investigating allegations of misconduct at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant has subpoenaed a U.S. Department of Energy watchdog committee. Merritt Langston, a spokesman for the Advisory Committee on Nuclear Facility Safety, said today that the subpoena was delivered to Chairman John Ahearne earlier this week. It orders him to turn over all documents pertaining to the committee's work at Rocky Flats, or send a representative to testify or both. The subpoena calls for the documents to be delivered Monday and presented to the grand jury Wednesday. Rocky Flats, 16 miles northwest of Denver, is the nation's only manufacturer of plutonium detonating devices for nuclear warheads. Plutonium processing at the plant has been suspended since the beginning of this year because of safety and environmental concerns. The Ahearne committee, formed two years ago to look into the problems, recommended in June that plutonium production not resume before October at the earliest, if national security needs warranted it. The Denver grand jury investigation began Aug. 1, 1989, two months after agents of the FBI, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Energy raided the plant, looking for violations of regulations. The grand jury has issued non in rubber dinghies before dawn and fought their way into Jaffna Fort, said Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunga. Ten soldiers were also wounded in the battle for the fort, where more than 200 policemen and soldiers had been trapped, military officials said on condition of anonymity. An air force plane providing air cover crashed into the lagoon after the siege was broken, military officials said. The pilot of the single-engine Italian-made Marchetti plane was thought to have died. Officials blamed the crash on engine failure. There was no immediate word from the Tamil Tiger rebels or any independent report from Jaffna, where communications have been severed for three months. The 17th century fort had been besieged since June 11 when the Tamil guerrillas broke a cease-fire and renewed their separatist war against the Sinhalese-dominated government. ``The assaulting battle group has now successfully relieved the fort and is consolidating and clearing adjacent areas,'' the military statement said. Officials said most of the 200 policemen and soldiers remained in the fort, while an undisclosed number were evacuated for medical reasons. They said troops were destroying rebel bunkers around the fort. The breaking of the siege would be an important psychological victory for the government forces, but its value would likely be more symbolic than practical. The rest of Jaffna town is Tiger territory, and so is most of the surrounding Jaffna Peninsula. Jaffna is 185 miles northeast of Colombo. Nevertheless, the massive fort _ a classic of military architecture with a moat, drawbridge, watch towers and 20-foot walls _ symbolizes Sinhalese power in the Tamil-dominated peninsula. During the siege, helicopters dropped food to the men trapped inside. Drinking water was provided in the form of ice blocks, which quickly melted in the tropical heat. At least twice helicopter pilots braved rebel flak to land at the fort and pick up seriously wounded policemen and soldiers. Having taken the fort, the government's next task is to take the town of Jaffna, which has been a Tiger stronghold since the insurrection started in 1983. The government opened talks last year to try to negotiate a peaceful settlement with the Tigers, who say they need a separate homeland to protect the Tamil minority from discrimination by the Sinhalese majority. The government says more than 3,000 people have been killed in the last three months, bringing the death toll of the 7-year-old insurrection to at least 14,000. The northeast is the home of most of Sri Lanka's Tamils, who form 18 percent of the island's population of 16 million. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the people.

DOC.HEAD: Author Claims Moses was Egyptian Pharaoh
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Author uses spelling Akhenaten, but Ikhnaton conforms to style.
DOC.TEXT: The author of a new book claims the Jewish prophet Moses was known to ancient Egyptians as Ikhnaton, the ruler and religious reformer. ``I am convinced that I have identified Moses as Ikhnaton, the prophet, poet and king in the 14th century B.C., who shut the temples of the ancient gods, sent the priests home and declared there was only one god,'' said Ahmed Osman. His book, ``Moses: Pharaoh of Egypt,'' was published in Britain on Thursday by Grafton Books. The U.S. rights are under negotiation. Osman's first book in 1987, ``Stranger in the Valley of Kings,'' theorized that the mummy of a royal official named Yuya was Joseph, the biblical figure with the coat of many colors who led the tribe of Israel into Egypt. Osman, 55, an Egyptian who has pursued research in Egyptology and the Bible in London for 25 years, is regarded by academics as a controversial but respected outsider. Younes Ahmed el-Batrik, cultural counselor at the Egyptian Embassy, held a reception Thursday night to launch Osman's book. ``It's a very interesting subject and a very controversial book and I will be interested to hear what the experts say about it,'' he said. In identifying Moses with Ikhnaton, Osman builds on Sigmund Freud's last book, ``Moses and Monotheism,'' in which the father of psychoanalysis commented on the similarity of the teachings of the two ancients. Sydney Leperer, a senior history lecturer at Jews' College, University of London, said of Osman's Ikhnaton-Moses theory: ``There is a faint possibility that it is true, although I have my doubts.'' Naim Dangoor, editor of The Scribe, a journal on Babylonian Jewry, said he had read and reviewed both of Osman's books. Osman ``knows a great deal about the period,'' and his theories ``invite further investigation,'' Dangoor said. Osman said in an interview that scholars had always had difficulty establishing links between any of the important figures in the Old Testament and Egyptian history. ``I believe that Moses had an Israelite mother and an Egyptian father,'' he said. ``He was the son of Pharaoh Amenhotep III and Queen Tiye, daughter of Joseph the Patriarch. Tiye's first son had mysteriously disappeared so when Moses was born, Tiye sent him by water for safekeeping to her Israelite relatives. I think that was the origin of the story that Moses was found in the bulrushes on the Nile.'' After 17 years as pharaoh, Ikhnaton was deposed and succeeded by the boy prince, Tutankhamen. ``I believe Ikhnaton survived and went into exile in Sinai with a few followers,'' Osman said. ``When the oppressor Pharaoh Horemheb died, Ikhnaton saw his chance to regain his throne as there was no heir. He challenged Horemheb's general, Ramses, for the throne but Ramses attacked him and forced him to flee. The flight was the Exodus, in 1333 B.C.'' ``Ikhnaton and his followers attempted to enter Canaan, the Promised Land, but were slaughtered by Ramses' successor, Seti I. This fight is recorded in the Temple of Karnak in Luxor,'' the author said. Jewish narratives are silent on any blood connection between Moses and Egypt because of memories of the oppression, Osman believes. ``However, the Talmud (the Jewish law) indicates that Moses became a king and was forced to abdicate,'' he added. Eric Uphill, an Egyptologist at London's University College, said he helped and supported Osman's research because he regarded Osman as a serious student with extensive knowledge. Osman's manuscript was based on the right sources for Egyptian history, Uphill said, but he would not comment on the conclusions without further study. ``The problem with Moses is that the historical truth about him is very unclear and lends itself to many theories, some of them haywire,'' Leperer said. Dangoor said Moses' death is a mystery that is not resolved in the Exodus accounts. ``Osman's explanation that he was killed by Seti I is very plausible,'' Dangoor said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Denies Ambassador Encouraged Saddam
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The White House denied Thursday that the U.S. ambassador to Iraq gave President Saddam Hussein any reason to think President Bush would look the other way if Iraq invaded Kuwait. ``It's pretty ludicrous to suggest that any time any place we would find it comfortable to have them invade Kuwait _ the basic implication is that somehow the U.S. would be willing to look the other way or would have condoned this kind of action,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``That is ludicrous and stupid,'' he said. But Fitzwater acknowledged that the administration, before the Aug. 2 invasion, was trying to develop better ties with Iraq. Fitzwater's comments came in response to reporters' questions about an Iraqi transcript of a conversation between U.S. Ambassador April Glaspie and Saddam a week before the invasion. U.S. officials have not denied the authenticity of the transcript, in which Glaspie reassured Saddam that the United States had no official position on ``Arab-Arab conflicts, like your border disagreement with Kuwait,'' according to a version published by The Washington Post. ``She reflected United States policy,'' Fitzwater said. ``At that time we were trying to nurture relations with Iraq,'' he said when asked if Glaspie indicated the United States would not intervene in Iraq's border dispute with Kuwait. On July 31, just three days before the invasion, Assistant Secretary of State John H. Kelly gave the same answer in testimony on Capitol Hill as he argued against imposing trade sanctions on Iraq. ``We have historically avoided taking any position on border disputes or internal OPEC deliberations,'' Kelly said. Another official explained U.S. thinking on the Iraq-Kuwait conflict before the invasion. ``Neighbors have had disputes over boundaries and borders for years. It's not for us to intervene. But ... it's a big difference'' when a country actually invades another, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Fitzwater said Glaspie, a career diplomat, has been stationed at a State Department desk working on the Iraq matter in Washington since the invasion. He said that doesn't reflect any dissatisfaction with her performance. ``We believe Ambassador Glaspie is an outstanding professional,'' Fitzwater said. ``She has represented her country well and correctly.'' She was in London, en route to Washington, when the invasion occurred. In Washington, she was told not to return to Baghdad, where Joseph C. Wilson III heads the embassy in her absence. Glaspie has met with Bush two or three times on the matter, and is active in State Department deliberations on strategy, Fitzwater said, adding that she consults daily with her colleagues in Baghdad. ``We believe it's most useful that she remain here to help with our analysis and also that we not send a signal that it's business as usual with Iraq,'' Fitzwater said. He did not dispute the report that Saddam had made menacing comments to Glaspie in their July 25 meeting in Baghdad, suggesting that the United States should not oppose Iraqi aims in the Middle East. ``The fact is that Saddam Hussein has lied to everyone in the world,'' including Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and Jordan's King Hussein, Fitzwater said. ``The whole world was misled in that sense.''

DOC.HEAD: Minor Earthquake Felt In Tel Aviv
DOC.TEXT: A minor earthquake shook Tel Aviv and its suburbs Thursday but caused no damage or injuries, a government official said. Dr Avi Shapira, head of the seismological divison of the Institute for Petrol and Geophysical Research, said the quake registered 4 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale gauges the energy released by an earthquake by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. At magnitude of 4, an earthquake can cause moderate damage. However, no damage was reported from the tremor in the Tel Aviv area, according to the national news agency Itim. Israel sits on the Syrian-African rift that runs from southern Turkey into Africa. Although there are daily tremors along the rift, they reach a magnitude felt by humans only once or twice a year, Shapira said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Protected Terry Waite Murdered
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen on Thursday murdered a Lebanese militia officer who led a squad of bodyguards assigned to protect Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite while he negotiated for the release of Western hostages. Amin Sleit, 36, a senior officer of Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party, was shot in the head, neck and chest, a police spokesman said. The assailants, armed with silencer-equipped pistols, stormed into Sleit's office in West Beirut and opened fire, said the spokesman, who under regulations cannot be identified. The killers fled in a car. No motive for the crim was immediately known, the spokesman said. Sleit headed a Progressive Socialist Party security group that was in charge of protecting Waite, 51, before the church envoy disappeared in West Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987. He also managed a real estate firm in West Beirut. A key security figure in the Socialist Party, Sleit had unofficially provided protection for many foreigners - potential targets of Shiite Moslem kidnappers - even before Waite's mission. Sleit had strongly advised Waite against going unescorted to a meeting with representatives of the Islamic Jihad, which holds American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. Waite refused, insisting that a contact had told him he would be allowed to visit the hostages if he showed up for the meeting alone. Waite never returned. No group has claimed Waite's abduction. Former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, who was released last month, said Waite has been ill but is alive. ``He was in the same apartment as I was being held in,'' Keenan said in a recent radio interview. ``I know Terry Waite is alive. I know he has been ill and the illness I do not think is serious.'' The Western captives, held mainly by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon, include three other Britons in addition to Waite, two West Germans, an Italian and six Americans. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held Western hostage. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Launched After Recruits Forced to Eat Explosives
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Ministry on Thursday launched an inquiry into practices at an army training center after it was revealed that recruits had been forced to eat explosives. The ministry confirmed newspaper reports that up to 20 young soldiers were taken to hospital earlier this week after swallowing 30 grams of explosives in what was described as a regular initiation ceremony. One person killed himself and six others attempted suicide during the summer at the same recruit training center in Colombier in the West of Switzerland. A ministry spokesman said the army lieutenant at the center of the explosives incident had been suspended. One of the victims, who was not named, told Swiss radio the ``explosives baptism,'' was a routine part of army life. The commander of the barracks, Colonel Jean-Pierre Voirol, described the incident as an innocent, allbeit stupid, joke.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Police Injured During Protests of imported Meat
DOC.TEXT: Farmers in two towns attacked riot police with eggs, beer bottles and clubs Thursday, wounding at least eight officers during mass protests against low-priced meat imports. Police in Nevers responded with tear gas as some of an estimated 10,000 marchers tried to tear down a fence around a government building. In Chateaureaux, also in central France, police sprayed tear gas and jets of water to disperse more than 1,200 farmers who set fire to bales of hay and hurled eggs, tomatoes, firecrackers and stones at the officers. During recent months, French farmers have hijacked numerous livestock trucks and butchered or burned alive hundreds of animals in a campaign against low-priced lamb and beef imports from Britain, East Germany and elsewhere. At a news conference coinciding with Thursday's clashes, Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet said the government would announce a ``substantial'' emergency aid plan for farmers within the next few days. He declined to discuss the size of the aid package and appealed for an end to the violence. Farmers came from throughout central France to Nevers, the home of Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy. At one point during an hour-long confrontation, a group of farmers attacked a police unit with clubs, injuring one officer who was taken away in an ambulance. In all, eight policemen reportedly were injured, several by bottles hurled at them. Before dispersing, farmers set fire to tires near the city hall and tore down several traffic signs. An estimated 1,000 policemen were deployed along the march route. Many residents heeded authorities' advice to close shops along the route, and at about 4 p.m. police blocked off the entrances to the downtown area to keep out motorists. The march was organized to demand increased government support for farmers, whose earnings have dropped because of a drought as well as the influx of imports. In Strasbourg, the European Parliament on Thursday urged the European Community to take emergency measures to control the recent fall in farm prices. Prices of meat, vegetables and dairy products have dropped as a result of East German produce coming onto the market faster than anticipated. Most the attacks by French farmers have been targeted at shipments from Britain. On Wednesday, leaders of French and British farmers' unions agreed to urge the EC to adopt emergency measures to prevent further escalation of the dispute. They urged tighter restrictions on beef imports from Eastern Europe, larger purchases of surplus meat, and speedier payments of subsidies for sheep farmers.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Receives Warm Welcome from West German Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan was warmly welcomed by West German leaders Thursday in a city where large crowds once protested his visits. ``In this historic hour when German unity is becoming reality it is right that you, a great friend of our country, are here,'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl told Reagan, who is on a 10-day trip with scheduled stops in Poland, the Soviet Union and Italy. Reagan thanked Kohl for a 6,000-pound slab of the Berlin Wall that is now displayed in the presidential library in Simi Valley, Calif. Kohl said Reagan help encourage the democratic reforms that led to reunification of East and West Germany, set for Oct. 3. Some of the largest European protests against Reagan's presidency were staged in Bonn. Reagan's May 1985 attendance at an international economic summit was overshadowed by a controversy when he and Kohl visited a war cemetery in Bitburg where Nazi officers are buried. In 1982, at the height of the dispute over stationing U.S. nuclear missiles in Western Europe, about 200,000 West Germans massed in Bonn to protest a visit by Reagan. But on Thursday, an honor guard greeted Reagan, 79, and his wife, Nancy, as they arrived in a convoy of black limousines at President Richard von Weizsaecker's official residence overlooking the Rhine River. ``Sunshine for you,'' von Weizsaecker's wife, Marianne, told Reagan. The Reagans traveled to Bonn following a visit to Berlin, where the former president chipped at the remnants of the Berlin Wall with a hammer and chisel.

DOC.HEAD: Debris Spotted Floating Near Where Plane Ditched
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with debris spotted; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian Forces Aurora plane spotted debris today floating in the North Atlantic near where a Peruvian Boeing 727 carrying 16 people is believed have ditched two days earlier. Transport Canada spokesman Dick Pepper said the Aurora crew sighted the debris 240 miles southeast of Cape Race. A coast guard ship was dispatched to the scene to recover the debris, Pepper said. Earlier, Pepper said the rain and fog off Newfoundland's south coast was hampering the search for the airliner. The jet, owned by Faucett Airlines of Peru and carrying Peruvian airline crew members and their relatives, disappeared Tuesday afternoon about 200 miles offshore after the pilot radioed that he was short of fuel. The plane was headed for a refueling stop in Gander, Newfoundland, en route to Miami from the Mediterranean island of Malta. If it ditched successfully there was only a slim chance the plane would be afloat after two days, Pepper said. But if the plane was equipped with life rafts, as the 727 often is, the crew could have escaped, he said.
