DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0675 to restore dropped material
Souter Refuses to Discuss Abortion as Confirmation Hearing Opens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with later testimony, inserting 8 grafs after 7th graf pvs, Biden engaged; subs 13th graf pvs, Biden and; cuts last 4 grafs
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter firmly refused to discuss his views on abortion Thursday as the Senate Judiciary Committee opened confirmation hearings. Democrats promised to continue pressing him on that and other controversial issues. Souter told senators it would be inappropriate for him to discuss such a hotly contested constitutional matter as abortion, though he said he accepted the constitutional right of privacy on which the Supreme Court based its abortion-legalizing 1973 decision, Roe vs. Wade. The New Hampshire judge, nominated by President Bush to be the court's 105th justice, spoke slowly and somberly in the crowded Senate hearing room of the position he called ``the greatest responsibility that any judge in our republic can undertake.'' The court has been deeply divided in recent years with 5-4 rulings on such contentious issues such as abortion and civil rights, and conservatives are hoping that Souter will help anchor the court firmly on the right. ``If the Senate of the United States believes it is right to confirm my nomination, then I will accept those responsibilities as obligations to all of the people of the United States whose lives will be affected by my stewardship of the Constitution,'' Souter said. Committee chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., then began the long process in which Souter would confront questions from all 14 committee members. Biden engaged Souter in a dialogue about the right of privacy, which although not specifically mentioned in the Constitution has been recognized by the Supreme Court since a 1965 decision called Griswold vs. Connecticut. At one point, Souter talked about a need for the Supreme Court to follow its own precedents - stating that past decisions should be overturned only after careful consideration. ``The first question is whether the prior decision was wrong,'' he said. And if the court does determine its previous ruling was incorrect, he added, it should measure ``the degree and kind of reliance placed upon'' the ruling and the ``cost of overruling'' it. Souter began his testimony after sitting quietly for two hours while senators made opening statements. He proved an attentive and respectful witness, though hardly devoid of humor. When one senator, worried about his questioning time expiring, cut Souter's response to a question short, the nominee quipped, ``You're going to turn me into a laconic Yankee if you keep doing that.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., questioned the nominee closely about positions he took while New Hampshire's attorney general and, before that, as an assistant in the attorney general's office. Kennedy focused on cases in which the state defended a literacy test for prospective voters and resisted federal regulations seeking information about hiring in state government. In both instances, Souter emphasized, he was ``acting as an advocate'' and ``representing a client.'' He said both positions were tenable at the time, in the 1970s. Earlier, Souter said he would view his Supreme Court service as a responsibility ``to make the promises of the Constitution a reality for our time and to preserve that Constitution for the generations that will follow us.'' Drawing battle lines quickly, Democrats advised him to ``open for us the window into your mind'' while Republicans told him to keep his own counsel in facing sensitive questions. ``The burden of proof is on you,'' Biden told him. ``We have a right to know, and a duty to discover, precisely what you ... think about the great constitutional issues of our time.'' He urged Souter, ``Open for us the window into your mind. And give us a little bit of a glimpse into your heart.'' Biden and the committee's two other leading liberals, Kennedy and Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, asked Souter to discuss candidly his views of key issues on which the Supreme Court is closely divided. But Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the committee's ranking Republican, said his colleagues had no right ``to question a nominee about how he or she would decide a particular case. It is inappropriate.'' Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., added, ``Overly explicit questions are not only unwise but, I believe, impermissible.'' Reminding Souter that federal judges are ethically bound not to publicly discuss matters that are, or may be, before any court, Simpson gave the judge some Western advice: ``Sit deep in the saddle.'' Kennedy said little in Souter's record as a state judge and attorney general in New Hampshire ``demonstrates real solicitude for the rights of those who are weakest and most powerless in our society.'' ``It is the responsibility of this committee to find out whether Judge Souter is committed to these rights and other basic values enshrined in the Constitution,'' Kennedy said. ``That is why these hearings ... are so important.'' But Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, urged the nominee to ``stand your ground when you sincerely believe you are being asked for answers you clearly cannot properly provide.'' The hearing's opening session was interrupted briefly when 12 people - six men and six women - stood and shouted in protest. ``He will kill women,'' shouted one. The demonstrators, who said they were members of a gay rights group, were hustled from the cavernous hearing room by police. They were arrested and charged with disrupting a congressional hearing. ``Welcome to Washington, judge,'' Biden told Souter after the outburst. Souter, 50, was nominated by President Bush on July 23, three days after Justice William J. Brennan retired from the nation's highest court. Although he wrote more than 200 opinions in his seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court, Souter has had few, if any, occasions to write about such divisive issues as abortion, civil rights and church-state relations. Souter, who spent more than a week last month paying courtesy calls to the senators who will decide his nomination's fate, was formally introduced to the committee by Republican New Hampshire Sens. Gordon Humphrey and Warren Rudman. Both defended his ascetic lifestyle. ``The elegant pundits here inside the beltway think David Souter may not be quite up to the big time because he drives a clunky old car, because he believes in conserving energy by not mowing his lawn until it begins to block his view when he looks out his window,'' Humphrey said as Souter smiled. ``I believe you'll find David Souter to be as smart as anyone in this city.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Refugees Clear Out of Shaalan Camp
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shaalan I became an ugly memory Thursday, a ghost town of tattered, dust-coated tents abandoned by tens of thousands of Asian refugees. Caravans of crowded buses, their roofs piled high with the last possessions of shattered lives, evacuated the remaining residents of Jordan's most crowded and squalid refugee camp. ``We don't know where we are going. Some say we are going directly to the airport. Others say we are going to a new camp. Right now we don't care,'' said M.K. Aboobacker, a young Indian electrician who came to Jordan when he could no longer find work in occupied Kuwait. Shaalan I had become a symbol of hopelessness for the hordes who fled Kuwait after it was invaded by Iraq on Aug. 2. It was the first of three camps built along the Iraqi border and once housed as many as 50,000 people. ``Attention Red Cross: Show us humanity. Save us from this deadly desert,'' read one sign that Indian refugees attached to a light pole at Shaalan I. ``At the begining we barely managed to provide enough drinking water for everyone,'' said Laurent Schopfer, an official with the International Committee of the Red Cross at Shaalan I. ``It was like a riot when the water trucks arrived.'' Jordanian officials said 13,000 refugees left the country Thursday and that 13,000 more arrived. Salameh Hammad, general secretary of Jordan's Interior Ministry, said about 40,000 refugees remained in Jordan and more than 360,000 others were in Iraq waiting to cross into the country. He said 589,000 foreigners, mostly Egyptians, had crossed Jordan on their way home since the gulf crisis began. U.N. officials estimate there could still be 2 million foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq. Hammad said his country has spent $30 million on the crisis and appealed to the world for more aid. Some of Shaalan I's last residents were taken to Amman's airport for flights home. Caravans of buses took the others 120 miles west, across the ancient lava fields of Jordan's eastern desert, to Azraq I, a new camp with running water and hundreds of large tents set in neat rows on a rocky plain. Red Cross official Roland Sidler said the camp, 50 miles west of Amman, can house 15,000 refugees but is being expanded to hold 25,000. Azraq II, another new but smaller camp, was being set up 1{ miles west. ``When we don't have room at Azraq I and II, we will transfer people to Shaalan II and Mercy camp,'' said Hammad, referring to two smaller, better-equipped border camps. At Azraq I Thursday, a handful of half-dressed Indians showered or washed their clothes under faucets while about 50 evacuees from Shaalan I argued heatedly with Jordanian officials who had taken their passports. ``They told us we were going straight to the airport but we came here instead and then they took our passports,'' said Surrya Raddimalla, 37. Iqbal Singh, 50, told reporters conditions were better, that there was water and food. But he also showed his Air India return-trip ticket to Bombay and demanded to know why he must live in any camp. ``I have a Jordanian visa in my passport. Why must I suffer? Why won't they let me in?'' Singh asked. Back at Shaalan I, Schopfer marveled at the speed with which he said governments and relief organizations were moving to repatriate the refugees. Officials once feared massive starvation would overtake relief efforts. ``It only took about four days to move everyone out of this camp,'' he said. As he talked he strolled past piles of rotting garbage in the litter-strewn camp, swatted at swarms of flies and peered inside the filthy, abandoned tents. ``It is really the first time we have seen how these people had to live,'' he said, nodding toward the bedding, tins of food and cooking utensils left behind. ``Maybe they will take a bulldozer to it and bury this ugly memory,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Says it Plans More Aid in Gulf Showdown
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Thursday that West Germany will lend ``a helping hand'' to the United States in the gulf showdown, but he did not say whether that included money. In Brussels, Belgium, an official of the European Economic Community said the foreign ministers of the 12 member nations will consider a proposal on Monday to provide $1.95 billion in aid to Jordan, Turkey and Egypt. The official spoke on condition of anonymity. The EC foreign ministers agreed in principle to aid for Jordan, Turkey and Egypt last week, but no amount was disclosed. The countries have lost trade because of the U.N. embargo against Iraq and Kuwait. In Washington, Congress has been scathingly critical of Japan and West Germany for allegedly failing to shoulder their load in the U.S.-led military buildup following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Kohl said he will discuss ways his country could assist in the Middle East when he meets Saturday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Germany would ``like to extend a helping hand to our friends in the United States in this very critical situation in the Middle East,'' he said. He made the comments in a welcoming address for visiting former President Reagan. ``When Jim Baker pays us a visit on Saturday, I am going to discuss with him what we can do to help. ... Let me remind all of us that what the United States is doing there is of benefit to us,'' Kohl said. The West German leader said he did not want his country to be perceived as one that benefits from its powerful exports but was not willing to help out in times of crisis. ``This is not my policy,'' Kohl said. Earlier, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told a news conference that Baker would be very satisfied with his trip to Bonn. ``We will lay out what we want to do and in part what we are already doing,'' Genscher said. But he declined to specify how West Germany would show its solidarity with the international effort to reverse the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. West Germany so far has sent five minesweepers and two supply ships to the eastern Mediterranean to support the U.S. fleet. Bonn also has provided humanitarian aid for the tens of thousands of refugees stranded in Jordan. The West German government says its constitution prevents it from sending troops outside the NATO area. Kohl has said he would seek changes to allow German forces to take part in U.N. activities.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... practical government.
DOC.TEXT: I went to work for a law firm in Concord, N.H., and I practiced there for several years. I then became, as I think you know, an Assistant Attorney General in the Criminal Division of that office. I was then lucky to be Deputy Attorney General to Warren Rudman and I succeeded him as Attorney General in 1976. The experience of government, though, did not wait until the day came that I entered public, as opposed to private, law practice, because although in those years of private practice I served the private clients of the firm, I also did something in those days which was very common then, perhaps it is less common today, I know it is, but it was an accepted part of private practice in those days and that was to take on a fair share of representation of clients who did not have the money to pay. I remember very well that the first day that I ever spent by myself in a courtroom, I spent in a courtroom representing a woman whose personal life had become such a shambles that she had lost the custody of her children and she was trying to get them back. She was not the last of such clients. I represented clients with domestic relations problems who lived sometimes, it seemed to me, in appalling circumstances. I can remember representing a client who was trying to pull a life together after being evicted because she couldn't pay the rent. And although cases like that were not the - those were not the cases upon which the firm paid the rent, those were not remarkable cases for lawyers in private practice in those days before governmentally funded legal services. And they were the cases that we took at that time because taking them was the only way to make good on the supposedly open door of our courts to the people who needed to get inside and to get what courts had to offer through the justice system. And I think it is fair to say that even - I am glad it is fair to say that even today, with so much governmentally funded legal service, there are lawyers in private practice in our profession who are doing the same thing. As you know, I did go on to public legal service. And in the course of doing that, I met not only legislators and the administrators that one finds in a government, but I began to become familiar with the criminal justice system in my state and in our nation. I met victims, and sometimes I met the survivors of victims; I met defendants, and I met that train of witnesses from the clergy to con artists who pass through our system and find themselves, either willingly or unwillingly, part of a search for truth and part of a search for those results that we try to sum up with the words of justice. As you also know, after those years, I became a trial judge, and my experience with the working of government in the judicial system broadened there, because I was a trial judge of general jurisdiction, and I saw every sort and condition of the people of my state that a trial court of general jurisdiction is exposed to. I saw litigants in international commercial litigation for millions, and I saw children who were the unwitting victims of domestic disputes and custody fights which somehow seemed to - somehow seemed to defy any reasonable solution, however hard we worked at it. I saw, once again, the denizens of the criminal justice system, and I saw domestic litigants. I saw appellants from the juvenile justice system who were appealing their findings of delinquency. And in fact, I had maybe the - one of the great experiences of my entire life in seeing week in and week out the members of the trial juries of our states who are rightly called the ``consciences of our communities,'' and I worked with them and I learned from them, and I will never forget my days with them. And when those days on the trial court were over, there were two experiences that I took away with me, or two lessons that I had learned, and the lessons remain with me today. The first lesson, simple as it is, is that whatever court we are in, whatever we are doing, whether we are on a trial court or an appellate court, at the end of our task some human being is going to be affected. Some human life is going to be changed in some way by what we do, whether we do it as trial judges or whether we do it as appellate judges as far removed from the trial arena as it is possible to be. The second lesson that I learned in that time is that if indeed we are going to be trial judges whose rulings will affect the lives of other people, and who are going to change their lives by what we do, we had better use every power of our minds and our hearts and our beings to get those rulings right. And I am conscious of those two lessons, as I have been for all of the years that I was on an appellate court. I am conscious of them as I sit here today, suddenly finding myself the nominee of the president of the United States to undertake the greatest responsibility that any judge in our republic can undertake, the responsibility to join with eight other people to make the promises of the Constitution a reality for our time and to preserve that Constitution for the generations that will follow us after we are gone from here. And I am mindful of those two lessons when I tell you this: that if you believe, and the Senate of the United States believes, that it is right to confirm my nomination, then I will accept those responsibilities as obligations to all of the people in the United States whose lives will be affected by my stewardship of the Constitution. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: More Overseas Bases Will Be Closed
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon will close ``well over 100'' military facilities overseas over the next few years, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday. Cheney gave no specifics about the type of facilities he was referring to, but he said the bulk of the cutbacks would be in Western Europe. The secretary made the remark at a question-and-answer session following a speech before the Air Force Association and the Comstock Club in Sacramento, Calif. Queried why the administration had begun cutting back on domestic bases instead of sites in Korea, the Philippines or Japan, Cheney replied: ``Within the next couple of weeks, I will announce well over 100 facilities overseas where U.S. forces are now deployed that will, in fact, be closed over the next couple of years.'' The secretary said that ``most of those'' would involve sites in Western Europe. The closings will be in line with expected reductions in U.S. forces in Europe, given prospects for an agreement with the Soviet Union on reducing conventional forces, Cheney said. ``So the idea that we're only closing bases at home simply isn't a valid one, because ... there will be significant ones (closures) overseas,'' the secretary said. A Pentagon spokesman, Glenn Flood, said in Washington that Cheney was using the word ``facilities'' rather than bases. That could mean that Cheney would propose closing several facilities within a particular base, such as a school, hospital or other type of unit, the spokesman said. In January, Cheney recommended closing or scaling back 72 domestic bases and 14 overseas facilities. The Pentagon doesn't need congressional approval to close overseas facilities. Cheney defended domestic base closings as a necessary part of the long-term reduction in defense spending. ``It is not a pleasant task to be the one who has to preside over that,'' Cheney said. But the secretary said that there is ``no question'' such cuts are coming given the nations' budget woes. ``The only way I know to cut the defense budget is to seriously go about the business of trying to downsize the force, to cut force structure, to cut procurement, and to cut the infrastructure - the base structure - that goes with it,'' Cheney said. ``If I do what many in Congress want me to do, which is to protect and preserve all the bases, keep all the jobs open on all the assembly lines and all the defense jobs in America, the thing that ends up getting cut is our forces - such as the units we just sent to Saudi Arabia,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Forces Clash With Guerrillas Near Security Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD details of fighting; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army unit battled Shiite Moslem guerrillas and leftist militiamen Thursday near a village believed used as a base to attack Israel's self-declared security zone, police reported. A statement by the Lebanese National Resistance Front indicated at least 12 Israeli soldiers were either killed or wounded in the clash around the village of Kawkaba in the Bekaa Valley, about two miles north of the security zone. There were no other reports or confirmations of casualties. The estimated 50-member Israeli unit withdrew from the area after shelling troops from the resistance front, a leftist militia, and the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, said a police official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Seven Israeli armored personnel carriers advanced into Kawkaba ``behind a curtain of howitzer fire at first light,'' said the police spokesman. Israeli howitzer batteries in the security zone also shelled the Hezbollah-controlled villages of Ein al-Tineh and Maidoun near Kawkaba. The police spokesman said the shelling seemed to be an attempt to block Hezbollah supply lines. He said Hezbollah counterattacked in the ``fierce battle'' with Soviet-designed Katyusha rockets. He said Syrian troops deployed nearby were not involved. Kawkaba, a deserted village, is believed to be used by Hezbollah fighters to launch attacks against Israeli troops and allied militiamen in the security zone. Israel established the six- to 10-mile-wide zone in 1985 after the withdrawal of its troops who invaded Lebanon three years earlier. It is patrolled by about 1,000 Israeli soldiers and 3,000 allied troops of the mostly Christian South Lebanon Army.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Appear in Court Amid Tight Security
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) - A magistrate ordered a delay Thursday in the start of a hearing for Yasin Abu Bakr and 112 other Moslem militants who captured the prime minister during a coup attempt. Chief Magistrate Melville Baird granted a prosecution request for an adjournment to allow more time to prepare its case. The magistrate set Sept. 25 as the new date for the preliminary hearing. Bakr, 48, a former policeman, and the members of his Jamaat al-Muslimeen (Society of Moslems) face the death penalty for charges that include murder and treason. About two dozen female Jamaat supporters shouted ``Allah akbar!'' (God is great) as Bakr and 18 other prisoners filed into the courtroom, where they were kept in a specially built iron cage for the 45-minute proceedings. For security reasons, the remaining prisoners are to appear later in four separate groups. Heavily armed soldiers in camouflage uniforms ringed the converted gym in the western town of Chaguaramas, 10 miles outside Port-of-Spain, for the Moslems' first court appearance since the six-day coup attempt ended Aug. 1. Wearing a white tunic and black fez, the Moslem leader bowed to reporters and said: ``Morning to the press. Morning everybody.'' Spectators were searched and scanned with metal detectors before entering the courtroom. An armored tank was positioned outside. Prosecutor Theodore Guerra said the newly appointed head of the prosecution team, Karl Hudson-Phillips, needed more time to prepare his case. Defense attorney Nathaniel King had no objection. Bakr and his followers captured the Parliament and state-run television station and seized Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson and more than 50 others, including several Cabinet members. The attack and subsequent looting left 24 dead. Robinson, 63, was shot in the left leg. Bakr and his men are charged in connection with eight deaths. Bakr had blamed Robinson's administration for widespread poverty in this once oil-wealthy Caribbean nation off Venezuela. Trinidad and its sister island of Tobago remain under a state of emergency, giving police wide powers of search and arrest, and a nighttime curfew.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Hartigan, Edgar Race Tightening
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Neil Hartigan is catching up to GOP rival Jim Edgar in the Illinois governor' race, but Republican Lynn Martin is showing no gains in her bid to unseat Democratic Sen. Paul Simon, according to a statewide poll. In the telephone survey of 821 registered Illinois voters, Secretary of State Edgar had 44 percent and Attorney General Hartigan 40 percent, with 16 percent undecided. Simon had 51 percent and Martin 36 percent, with 13 percent undecided. The survey was conducted last Friday through Tuesday for Copley News Service by Political Media Research Inc. of Washington, D.C. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points above or below each candidate's totals. Edgar has lost two percentage points and Hartigan has gained two points since a similar survey done in July by the same polling organization. In that poll, Edgar was leading 46 percent to 38 percent. The latest poll had Simon holding on to a significant lead over Martin, a five-term congresswoman. Simon is running for a second six-year term. The latest results represent a slight loss for Martin, who trailed Simon 51 percent to 39 percent in the earlier poll.
DOC.HEAD: Globe Declines to Endorse Any Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The Boston Globe took the unusual step Thursday of deciding not to endorse any contender for statewide office in next Tuesday's primary election. In an editorial, the newspaper said that ``In 1990 ... the resource of leadership is severely depleted.'' The editorial noted that Massachusetts faces political and economic perils and said that there has been ``politics-as-usual bombast'' among the candidates. The Globe criticized Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierce and his GOP opponent, William Weld, for taking ``irresponsible'' positions by supporting a November ballot question that would sharply roll back state taxes and fees. On the Democratic side, the editorial said, ``John Silber seemed on paper to be an ideal profile for voters yearning for a new era.'' ``Campaigns, however, are waged not on paper but on personality,'' the Globe said. ``If voters were judging Silber on a report card, his mark on `Works well with others' would not be high.'' Francis X. Bellotti, a former attorney general, offers associations with the era of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the newspaper said.
DOC.HEAD: Kissinger To Appear At Rinfret Fundraiser
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger will be the main attraction at a $1,000-a-head fundraiser Oct. 1 for Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret, the Rinfret campaign announced Thursday. Kissinger will speak on the crisis in the Persian Gulf and other world affairs, Rinfret's campaign said. Rinfret's campaign billed the fundraiser at the Plaza Hotel in New York City as a ``private briefing'' by Kissinger. Rinfret is also getting fund-raising help from Vice President Dan Quayle, who will be the guest at a reception on Tuesday in New York City. Tickets for Quayle event are $250.

DOC.HEAD: Executions Moving Out of the South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7, bgng, `The South ..., with 4 grafs to include number of states with death penalty statutes, list of executions outside the South, CORRECTS second `has' in 6th graf to `had'; pick up 8th graf, `On Wednesday ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Executions this week in Oklahoma and Illinois may be signaling an era of more frequent use of the death penalty in more states, legal experts say. With 124 other Illinois death row inmates and at least two murderers in New Jersey and California nearing the end of their appeals, capital punishment appears likely to become more common in non-Southern states. ``We are stepping up to another plateau,'' said Henry Schwarzschild, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Capital Punishment Project. ``We're now seeing the reality that the death penalty is no longer a regional Southern phenomenon but a national one.'' The South remains the heartland of the death penalty, according to figures from the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. All but 16 of 139 executions since the U.S. Supreme Court cleared the way for resumption of the death penalty in 1976 took place in Southern states. Thirty-six states have death penalty laws under which about 200 people are sentenced annually. Texas has had 37 executions, Florida 23, Louisiana 19, Georgia, 14, Virginia nine, Alabama eight, Mississippi four, North Carolina and South Carolina three each, Arkansas two, and Oklahoma one. Outside the South, Nevada has executed five people since 1976, Utah has executed three, Indiana has executed two and Missouri has executed five, four of them this year. On Wednesday, Illinois became the northernmost state to carry out the death penalty when it executed murderer Charles Walker by injection, the first to die at the hands of that state in 28 years. Illinois became the 16th state to put someone to death since the 1976 high court ruling. On Monday, Oklahoma executed murderer Charles T. Coleman by injection. In Wyoming, convicted murderer Mark Hopkinson faces death by injection on Sept. 25. His latest appeal was rejected by the U.S. Supreme Court. Perhaps the most closely-watched case at the moment is in California, where murderer Robert Alton Harris came a step closer to the gas chamber when his sentence was upheld last month by a federal appeals court. No execution date has been set. And on Tuesday, New Jersey's Supreme Court heard arguments in the case of multiple murderer Richard Biegenwald. The court overturned his death sentence in 1987 on a technicality, but a new jury broke new ground in the state by sentencing Biegenwald to death again, triggering an automatic appeal. Nineteen murderers have been executed this year, compared with 16 in all of 1989 but still less than the post 1976-peak of 25 in 1987. Twenty-one of the 139 executed since 1976 went voluntarily, including Walker in Illinois. But even for those fighting execution, many now believe that the decade-long conservative drift in politics and court decisions increases the likelihood of more frequent executions in more states. Politicians including California Democratic gubernatorial candidate Dianne Feinstein have recently been scoring points with voters by stressing their pro-death penalty stance. Death penalty opponents who had held executioners at bay since 1976 have largely been rebuffed by the courts, said Schwarzschild. ``There are almost 2,400 on death row,'' he said. ``Many have been there for a long time. Though the legal remedies are very time consuming, they are not inexhaustible. Some are now reaching the end of those remedies. And those legal remedies are being progressively foreshortened.'' The average time elapsed between sentencing and execution was 77 months between 1977 and 1988 for those who have actually been executed, according to latest figures available from the federal Bureau of Justice Statistics. Some expect the average stay on death row to become shorter in the years ahead. The U.S. Supreme Court two years ago took a crucial step in breaking the appeals logjam. In McCleskie vs. Kempp, the justices rejected arguments that the death penalty should be overturned because it was geared largely to punish killers of white victims. According to NAACP Legal Defense Fund figures, 120, or 85.1 percent of the victims of those executed since 1976 were white. The McCleskie case, said Schwarzschild, ``was the last great challenge to the general pattern and process by which the death penalty was imposed. Now we have hand to hand legal combat, but nothing that affects a great many people on death row.'' But Karima Wicks, research director of NAACP Legal Defense's capital punishment project, said the rush to the death chamber might yet be slowed if Congress passes the so-called Racial Justice Act, an amendment to the Omnibus Crime bill now pending before the House of Representatives. The act, aimed at overturning the McCleskie ruling, would make it unlawful to impose a death sentence because of the race of either the victim or criminal. A defendant could appeal a sentence by using evidence that showed a pattern of discriminatory sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Pushes Clean Air Legislation
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, concerned the oil crisis might be used to thwart clean air legislation, said Thursday the tougher pollution controls required by the bill could save as much as 1 million barrels of oil a day. The report on the expected fuel savings, most of which would come toward the end of the decade, was made public as some members of Congress began questioning the wisdom of new and expensive pollution controls at a time of increasing energy costs. House and Senate negotiators were continuing to try to resolve differences in separate clean air bills, but a meeting was abruptly canceled Thursday. Participants had hoped to give final approval to a compromise reached last week on industrial controls to reduce urban smog. The legislation, expected to cost the energy industry as much as $25 billion a year by the end of the decade when all its requirements go into effect, requires pollution controls on electric power plants, factories and automobiles. It also requires the sale of cleaner gasoline blends in areas with serious smog problems. The study released Thursday by the Environmental Protection Agency concluded that as much as 500,000 barrels of oil a day may be saved because tougher acid rain controls will prompt utilities to switch from oil to natural gas. Another 500,000 barrels a day will be saved from requirement for automobiles to burn cleaner fuels and from the increased use of alternative fuel vehicles, the EPA said. ``The total of 800,000 to 1 million barrels a day exceeds the total oil imports from Kuwait and Iraq,'' EPA Administrator William Reilly told reporters. ``I think the energy implications ... make it more urgently necessary than ever for Congress to pass the bill,'' he said in a later telephone interview. Bush administration officials have acknowledged some concern in recent weeks that progress on the clean air legislation might be jeopardized amid the uproar over rising oil prices, the prospects of an economic recession and the potential of oil shortages. Only days after the Middle East crisis erupted last month, industry lobbyists began to question whether the time was right to impose added financial costs to industry in the form of tougher pollution controls. Some critics have argued that a number of provisions in the bill would increase oil consumption. For example, the use of scrubbers by utilities to reduce sulfur dioxide requires more energy, as does the refining of certain cleaner gasoline blends, they said. But the EPA study said all that would be offset by more significant energy gains. The study said that 300,000 to 500,000 barrels of oil could be saved by utilities that will be persuaded to switch from using sulfur-containing oil to using natural gas because of the bill's acid rain control provisions. A requirement to use cleaner fuels and gasoline blends in cities with serious smog problems and the increased use of alternative fuel vehicles also would lead to the savings of another 500,000 barrels of oil daily, the study said. The legislation requires that gasoline blends, which likely would be 15 percent or more of ethanol or methanol, would be required in at least nine cities. Some of the cleaner fuel requirements would apply to as many as 40 cities.

DOC.HEAD: Souter's Mother Says Nominee Looks Tired; Hometown Watches with Pride
With AM-Souter, Bjt
LaserPhoto CR3
DOC.TEXT: David Souter's mother didn't blame her son for showing up at his Supreme Court confirmation hearings with a 5 o'clock shadow and a ragged look. ``He has a very heavy beard. He's meticulous about shaving, but that he can't help,'' Helen Souter said. ``He looks exhausted, after all he's been through.'' The high court nominee lived with his mother in their weatherbeaten farmhouse until she moved into a retirement residence in nearby Concord several years ago. Until Souter went to Washington to prepare for the hearings, he continued to live in Weare and visit her every Sunday. Mrs. Souter, 82, recalled watching all of Robert Bork's confirmation hearings live and expected similar coverage of her son on Cable News Network, which isn't broadcasting all of the hearings. ``I was just watching it and they turned it off,'' she said. ``I'm very much disappointed.'' But Mrs. Souter is luckier than many of Souter's hometown fans. Without cable in the town of 4,500 people, only those with satellite dishes can watch CNN or C-SPAN. At John Stark Regional High School, teacher Tom Sutton said he plans to show tapes of some of the hearings in his personal-law class. He said Souter gives hometown flesh to the abstractions of justice. ``Here's the highest court in the land, and we've got someone who is maybe going to be there,'' he said. ``It's creating a lot of local interest in the man, but it's creating interest in the position as well.'' One of Sutton's students, senior Joel Nazer, said Souter's rise from Weare to Washington has inspired him. ``I'm from Henniker, and not a lot really comes out of Henniker or Weare,'' Nazer said. ``You see a rare incident like this and you really stop and think.'' When Souter was growing up, he spent his summers swimming and fishing with Janet Brown. She said she is still close to her friend and watches his confirmation hearings with pride. ``We went to an elementary school where there were 11 or 12 children in class, in a town where fathers worked and mothers were home,'' she said. ``Swimming, canning, getting wood - he's a real country person. He's the basics; he's what we were all brought up to believe in. He'll be as strong as our Constitution.'' Brown said that during the opening of the hearings, the respect with which the senators treated Souter impressed her. ``It's America at work. America can sleep better knowing someone with his integrity has the opportunity to be there,'' she said. Each of Weare's selectmen has written to the members of the Judiciary Committee urging them to confirm Souter's nomination. ``I don't think he can do wrong in any way as far as the people in the town are concerned,'' Selectman Bill Herman said.

DOC.HEAD: French President Urges Alliance of East, West Europe
DOC.TEXT: French President Francois Mitterrand on Thursday called for a European community that would eventually include the newly democratic countries of Eastern Europe. Mitterrand spoke to deputies of the Czechoslovak parliament, this country's first freely elected legislature in four decades, on the first day of his two-day official visit to Czechoslovakia. ``Let us create a new European geography of culture and history. ... Let us get used to the idea of cooperation as soon as possible,'' he told deputies in a 45-minute nationally televised speech. Calling Czechoslovakia the ``spiritual crossroads of Europe,'' Mitterrand presented his vision of European integration based on Western democracies gradually absorbing the emerging independent countries of Eastern Europe. ``We could reach a continental agreement that could be a beginning of a permanent dialogue,'' he said. He said his idea was close to that of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, who wants European integration to be built around the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. ``Prague could become the center for such talks, and I am going to campaign for this idea,'' Mitterrand said, indirectly supporting Prague's bid to become the headquarters of the 35-nation body. In other remarks, the French president cautioned that the process of reforming Czechoslovakia's stagnant economy requires patience. However, he praised the peaceful revolution of 1989 as ``the greatest popular revolt since the French revolution in 1789.'' Earlier in the day, Havel drew parallels between the German invasion of Czechoslovakia 52 years ago and any appeasement of Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait. Havel's comments, at an official lunch for Mitterrand, played heavily on comparisons of the Persian Gulf crisis and the Munich Pact. Concluded Sept. 30, 1938, the pact secured French and British acquiescence for Germany's invasion of Czechoslovakia. ``The shameful aggression against Kuwait and the ensuing crisis in the Persian Gulf today make the old lesson from Munich topical again,'' Havel said. ``The policy of appeasement cannot be successful in the long run; on the contrary, it is malignant.'' Czechoslovakia has joined in the U.N.-ordered embargo on Iraq, despite estimates it could lose up to $1 billion in trade. Also Thursday, Foreign minister Jiri Dienstbier and his French counterpart, Roland Dumas, signed agreements on cultural and student exchanges and the setting up of cultural centers in both countries. Finance ministers Vaclav Klaus and Jean-Marie Rausch of France ratified a treaty on protection of French investments in Czechoslovakia and repatriation of profit.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Warns Congress About Acting Hastily
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan added his voice Thursday to those warning of threats to the insurance fund that protects bank deposits, but he cautioned Congress against acting so hastily that it makes the problem worse. Members of Congress appeared inclined to ignore Greenspan's go-slow advice because of alarm over two reports this week that indicated the reserves of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. could be wiped out by a further downturn in the economy or by one large bank failure. House Banking Committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, said he was introducing legislation that would remove the caps on the premium amount the FDIC can charge banks for the deposit insurance. The legislation, co-sponsored by Rep. Chalmers Wylie of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the committee, was similar to a measure proposed Wednesday by Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald Riegle, D-Mich. Riegle said the matter was of such urgency that it had to be addressed before Congress adjourns next month. The Bush administration added its support to a move to give the FDIC more flexibility in setting premiums, with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady saying the agency should be given ``all the tools it needs.'' The FDIC charges banks 12 cents a year for every $100 the agency insures. The FDIC board voted last month to boost that amount to 19.5 cents, the maximum allowed under current law. That increase will cost the banking industry an estimated $1 billion next year. General Accounting Office and Congressional Budget Office reports that raised the specter of a savings-and-loan-type debacle unless something is done to shore up the bank fund focused attention on the problem. The depletion of a separate fund that insured deposits at S&Ls forced a bailout expected to cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars over 30 years. Lawmakers, eager to avoid a repeat of the fiasco, said Congress had to act without delay to rescue the FDIC, which has $13.2 billion in reserves. ``The revelation that with a few downward twitters of the economy, the once mighty federal deposit insurance fund could go broke shows the seriousness of the situation,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. In testimony before the House Banking Committee, Greenspan noted that FDIC reserves were at their lowest level in history at a time when there were ``all too many problems'' still facing the banking system from sagging loan portfolios, especially in the real estate area. ``It thus seems clear that the insurance fund likely will remain under stress for some time to come,'' Greenspan said. ``Moreover, pressures would intensify if real estate market conditions were to weaken further or a recession were to develop in the general economy.'' The Congressional Budget Office reported Wednesday that even without a recession some 600 to 700 commercial banks likely will fail over the next 3{ years, draining $20 billion from the FDIC fund. But Greenspan cautioned that while ``reform is needed, so is caution.'' He spoke against proposals to reduce the insurance limit from $100,000 per account and said it would be difficult, but not impossible, to administer a law that limited the number of insured accounts each individual could own. He also said lawmakers shouldn't boost premiums too much because that could make the banking industry uncompetitive and increase the number of bank failures, exactly the opposite effect intended. While saying he didn't oppose an increase in the insurance premiums, Greenspan said such legislation should be adopted along with proposals to restructure the banking system to give banks more powers, such as the ability to underwrite the sale of securities. Greenspan has long championed efforts to repeal the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act, which separated commercial and investment banking activities, saying the restrictions made it difficult for banks to compete in a rapidly changing financial world. Greenspan's appearance marked his first congressional testimony since the Persian Gulf crisis boosted oil prices and added to fears of an impending recession in the United States. However, his only comment on possible Fed monetary responses came when he said that a credible, multiyear deal between the administration and Congress to cut the budget deficit would lead to lower interest rates. Repeating earlier comments, Greenspan said financial markets would respond favorably in the belief that reduced federal government borrowing would allow long-term interest rates to decline. He said the central bank would do its part by helping to push short-term interest rates lower.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Won't Discuss New Detection Device
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration said Thursday it won't make any further comments about the only airport device that can detect plastic explosives. FAA Administrator James B. Busey said critics of the device have had an adverse effect on the campaign to combat aviation terrorism. ``I felt they were damaging the deterrent capability of this device,'' he said. ``The details of its performance are now classified and aren't going to be discussed any more.'' Four of the sophisticated Thermal Neutron Analysis, or TNA, machines are being used to inspect baggage at international airports here and in Europe and two others are ready for installation. The performance of the TNA technology has long been the subject of debate, with critics pointing to what they say is a high rate of false alarms. Critics also note that the device failed to detect a bomb as small as the one said to have destroyed Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. The presidential commission created to investigate the Pan Am bombing called for a halt to the FAA's plans to buy 150 TNA devices and install them at high-risk airports around the world. The commission said the government had made too heavy an investment in TNA devices at the expense of other developing technology that might prove more effective. Busey said the public discussion of the amount of explosives the machine can detect and its false alarm rate have had a decidedly negative impact. ``I disagree with them,'' Busey said of commission members who reported their concern about the TNA technology to President Bush in May. ``It is the only technology that can detect plastic explosives,'' he said. ``It does work.'' Busey also said the FAA knows how to put it into a system ``where we can work with and around its known capabilities and limitations.'' ``And in order to protect the enhancements, ... we are classifying it so that it won't become common knowledge and therefore limit its capabilities in a deterrent system,'' he said. TNA machines are used at Kennedy International Airport in New York, Dulles International Airport outside Washington, in Miami and at Gatwick airport south of London. Negotiations are under way to install a TNA detection device at Frankfurt, West Germany. Busey said a decision will be made by the end of the year on where the sixth TNA detector should be installed.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon-Postal Service Disagree Over Free Mail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs `But, on ...' to UPDATE with House putting off vote. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Pentagon spokesman ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A day after the Postal Service offered to deliver mail free from American military personnel in the Middle East, the Pentagon said no. Military post offices collect the mail and then turn it over to postal officials for delivery in this country. Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank had said Wednesday that his agency was prepared to accept and deliver mail, without stamps, from personnel serving in Operation Desert Shield. But, on Thursday, the Defense Department said letters without stamps cannot be accepted until Congress and President Bush approve the action. The plan has passed the Senate and is pending in the House. The House had appeared poised to approve the plan overwhelmingly until Rep. Thomas Ridge, R-Pa., offered an amendment stipulating that money to pay for the free mail would come from appropriations for free franked mail by members of Congress. Ridge's proposal was rejected on a voice vote. He then demanded a roll call vote, and because the House had already agreed to hold no more recorded votes this week, the members postponed action until next week. Pentagon spokesman Glen Flood said ``current law does not authorize free mail for deployed forces in situations short of hostilities. We hope the full Congress takes action soon, but as of right now free mail is not authorized. We hope that changes.'' Advised of the Pentagon decision, the Postal Service said that its announcement of free mail from troops in Saudi Arabia ``was made in the spirit and intent of proposed legislation.'' ``The Postal Service stands ready to accept and deliver service men and women's free mail when received,'' the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Court Says Feeding Tubes Can Be Removed
DOC.TEXT: The Florida Supreme Court ruled Thursday that relatives or guardians can order the removal of feeding tubes that keep brain-damaged people alive, even if the patients haven't signed ``living wills.'' The justices added that the guardians don't need a court's approval in each individual case. However, the patient must have expressed, at least verbally, a preference for dying rather than being kept alive with feeding tubes. Advocates of the ``right to die'' hailed the ruling, which does not apply outside Florida. Opponents did not immediately respond, saying they needed more time to review it. Roman Catholics and anti-abortion groups have been among those fighting laws that allow forced feeding to be withdrawn. The foundation of the right-to-die decision, which came in the case of an 89-year-old woman who died last summer, is the right to privacy in Florida's state constitution. ``This case resolves a question of an individual's constitutional right of self-determination,'' Justice Rosemary Barkett wrote in the majority opinion. The woman at the center of the case, Estelle Browning, spent the last 2{ years of her life hooked up to feeding tubes that she had earlier, in a ``living will,'' specifically said she didn't want. She suffered permanent brain damage in a stroke and was left in a persistent vegetative state, unable to swallow or communicate. She was not comatose. Doris Herbert, Mrs. Browning's second cousin and only living relative, was named her guardian. Herbert sought permission to remove the tubes in 1988. The state fought the request and a trial court denied it. But a state appeals court said the state's consititution allowed it, and the issue was reviewed by the Supreme Court. ``We hold that, because Mrs. Browning was unable to exercise her constitutional right of privacy by reason of her medical condition, her guardian was authorized to exercise it for her,'' Barkett wrote. Herbert's attorney, George Felos, said he was ``highly pleased'' by the ruling. He said he had expected the justices to rule that guardians could order the removal of feeding tubes. However, he said he had worried that the court would establish a judicial review process that ``would have in essence defeated the right.'' Barkett wrote that the court was ``loath to impose a cumbersome legal proceeding at such a delicate time in those many cases where the patient neither needs nor desires additional protection.'' C. Marie King, the assistant state attorney who presented the state's case to the court, did not return a phone call Thursday. The high court heard arguments in the case in January. Six months later, the U.S. Supreme Court said a Missouri couple could not order the removal of food and water that was keeping their 32-year-old comatose daughter alive. The daughter, Nancy Cruzan, had not left a living will, although her parents said they were certain she would prefer to die rather than live in a coma. In its split decision, the nation's high court did say that competent people have a right to refuse medical treatment. The Florida court, which cited that case, went on to say that it has found previously that incompetent people have the same right, through guardians acting on statements made before becoming incompetent, to refuse medical treatment as competent people. The Browning case extended that ruling to people in Florida who are not totally comatose but still cannot make their own decisions. Patricia Dore, a law professor at Florida State University who drafted the Florida privacy clause, said it was significant that the justices ruled there was no legal distinction between food and water supplied through invasive tubes and other medical treatments, such as respirators. Attorneys and advocates said other state courts could be influenced by the case. ``I think many, many state courts look to Florida for guidance on issues that affect the elderly,'' Felos said. Robert Miller, who represented the national Society for the Right to Die in a friend-of-the-court brief, said the ruling was a ``real contribution in this area.'' ``It's a really strong decision supporting the right of an adult to control their own medical decisions,'' Miller said. Rosemary Gallagher, a spokeswoman for the Florida Catholic Conference, said she hadn't seen the court's ruling and couldn't comment on it. The Catholic Conference had submitted a friend-of-the-court brief that opposed the removal of forced feeding.

DOC.HEAD: Troop Limits Dropped From Proposed Arms Accord
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union are giving up on setting limits on their troops in Europe in a treaty they're negotiating to reduce tanks and other non-nuclear weapons, a senior U.S. official said Thursday night. But that still leaves a dispute over limits on airplanes, the official said after Secretary of State James A. Baker III met for two hours with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and then for more than an hour with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``We didn't make any headway on that,'' the official told reporters as he flew to Damascus, Syria, for talks Friday with President Hafez Assad. The outlook for completing the treaty by the end of the year - a goal set by President Bush and Gorbachev - remains unclear. The two sides have set completion of the treaty as a precondition for holding a 35-nation summit conference on reducing tensions in Europe. Baker and Shevardnadze concluded that proposed limits on U.S. and Soviet troops had become obsolete. The Soviets have agreed with West Germany to withdraw the 350,000 soldiers they have in East Germany over four years as part of German unification. Also, Soviet troops are being pulled out of Eastern Europe, while U.S. forces in Western Europe also are being scaled back. The senior U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Shevardnadze had taken the troops issue off the table when they met in Siberia last month and that Baker agrees the proposed ceilings were overtaken by events. The ceilings would have permitted the Soviets and Americans up to 195,000 soldiers in Central Europe, with another 30,000 U.S. troops elsewhere on the continent. The official said he could not rule out the Soviets bringing up the issue again as a way of making sure the United States cuts back. But he said that probably would not happen until a second round of bargaining is held after the treaty is finished. The aircraft dispute, meanwhile, is a serious roadblock. It involves an effort by the United States and its NATO partners to limit Soviet airplanes that Moscow insists are defensive. The Soviets soon will send negotiators to Washington to try to break the deadlock, the official said. Baker's three-day visit here produced no serious progress on another prospective arms control treaty - a U.S.-Soviet agreement to cut their long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 percent to 50 percent. Bush hopes to sign the treaty at a summit in Moscow in December. Gorbachev told reporters at the Kremlin that ``a lot of things have to be done'' before there is another summit meeting. Later, U.S. officials confirmed none of the remaining issues in the way of a START treaty had been settled. Those issues include: -The kinds of restrictions to be placed on the 154 heavy, ground-based SS-18 intercontinental missiles the Soviets will retain under the treaty. -Whether the Soviet Backfire bomber is to be classified as a strategic weapons, as the United States demands. That would mean counting Backfires against numerical weapons limits established in the treaty. -The restrictions to be placed on U.S. and Soviet transfers of weapons barred under the treaty to allies - from the United States to Britain, for instance.

DOC.HEAD: Arens to Meet with Cheney
With AM-Cheney
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens will meet here next week with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to discuss developments in the Persian Gulf, sources said Thursday. Arens is coming to the United States on a private visit to deliver a speech. But, in addition to meeting Cheney, he may also hold talks with National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, the sources said. The Israeli official was last here in mid-July, when he warned Cheney that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein intended to invade Kuwait. The invasion came Aug. 2. At the request of the United States, Israel has refrained from taking any part in the standoff with Saddam so as not to antagonize the U.S. coalition with Arab states opposed to Iraq. The United States, Egypt, Syria and the United Arab Emirates have sent troops to Saudi Arabia to prevent Saddam from raiding the oil-rich country. Israel is believed to provide the United States with intelligence information about Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Latvia Passes Resolution on Soviet-Iraq Connection
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Latvia's parliament Thursday called for the expulsion of Iraqi troops who they said are training at a Soviet naval base on Latvian territory. There was no way to independently verify the report that Iraqi soldiers were stationed at the Soviet Navy Training Center near the republic's capital of Riga. A Canadian television station reported Wednesday that Latvian Foreign Minister Janis Jurkans confirmed the Iraqis were being trained at the base. The Soviet Union has condemned Iraq, a longtime ally, following its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Moscow, which had been Iraq's leading arms supplier, has cut off arms shipments to Baghdad. In the past, the Soviet Union has trained thousands of soldiers from socialist states and other nations to whom it has sold military weapons. Andrejs Krastins, a vice-chairman of the Latvian parliament, told a Western reporter in Riga there were ``several dozen'' Iraqis studying rockets and missiles at the base. He suggested Latvia might cut off water, electricity and food to the base. The resolution, endorsed by the parliament's presidium, or cabinet, expressed ``a firm and categorical protest against the stationing and military training of soldiers from the armed forces of the aggressor-state Iraq, which is occurring in the territory of the Republic of Latvia and is sponsored by the military leaders of the U.S.S.R. armed forces.'' The resolution demanded the parliament's Defense and Internal Affairs Commission inspect the base, that any Iraqi soldiers leave Latvia, and that Soviet authorities provide information on all foreign military personnel and family members in Latvia. Latvia, along with the neighboring Baltic republics of Lithuania and Estonia, is seeking independence from the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Two New Japanese Cabinet Ministers Named
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Thursday appointed two veteran lawmakers to succeed ailing Cabinet members who resigned. Seiroku Kajiyama, 64, is taking over the justice ministry, and Yoshiaki Kibe, 64, will be the new state minister in charge of Hokkaido and Okinawa development. Both are veterans of the lower house of parliament. Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto announced their appointments at a news conference. It was the first change in the Cabinet since a reshuffle after elections in February. Kaifu became prime minister in August 1989. Kajiyama will take over from 71-year-old Shin Hasegawa, who announced his resignation Wednesday because of treatment for a stroke he suffered two days earlier. Kibe replaces Shigetami Sunada, who also announced his resignation on Wednesday. Sunada has been absent from three Cabinet sessions since Sept. 4 because of a chronic respiratory illness.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Date Set for Chico Mendes Murder
DOC.TEXT: After a long judicial delay, an Oct. 25 trial date has been set for the murder of labor leader and rainforest defender Chico Mendes. A court official said Thursday the trial will be held in the western Amazon town of Xapuri, where Mendes lived and died. A court clerk, who asked not to be identified, said presiding Judge Aldair Longhini had selected a 21-member jury. Mendes, a rubber tree tapper who led a movement to stop destruction of the rainforest, was gunned down Dec. 22, 1988, as he stepped onto the back porch of his wood home in Xapuri, a town 2,700 miles northwest of Rio near the Bolivian border. Cattle rancher Darli Alves da Silva and his sons Darcy Pereira da Silva and Oloci Alves da Silva are charged with murder. The two sons recently were convicted in a separate trial for firing on a group of rubber tappers led by Mendes in May 1988, badly wounding two men. Mendes' successor, Osmarino Anancio Rodrigues, has charged that businessmen and ranchers masterminded the Mendes shooting but have never been called to testify. ``The head of the snake was not hit,'' Rodrigues said last month. ``Those who planned it are still at large.'' Mendes was one of the main rubber tapper leaders in the northwestern Amazon and was honored with the United Nation's Global 500 Prize. Robert Redford is currently working on a film about his life and Mendes has been the subject of several biographies. The movement Mendes led promotes the establishment of reserves in the Amazon to collect rubber and Brazil nuts and promote small-scale agriculture projects. The tappers say the rainforest can be profitably developed without being destroyed. Slash-and-burn clearing by ranchers and farmers has destroyed an estimated 8 percent of the 2 million-square-mile Amazon wilderness. Rubber tapper supporters expressed relief a trial date had finally been set. ``National and international public opinion calls out for justice in the Chico Mendes case, with exemplary punishment for his killers,''said Jeronimo Nunes of the Roman Catholic Church-linked Pastoral Land Commission. Rural conflicts between poor peasants and large landowners have resulted in over 1,000 deaths the past decade, according to Amnesty Intenational. Nearly all the victims have been union activists and advisors.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Temporarily Halting Soviet Jewish Immigration
DOC.TEXT: German Jewish organizations on Thursday condemned West Germany's decision to temporarily halt further Soviet Jewish immigration. The West German government on Wednesday told its diplomats in the Soviet Union to stop processing applications until a fixed quota is established. Bonn said its consulate in Kiev had received immigration requests from 10,000 Soviet Jews. Forty-five years after the Nazi Holocaust, Germany has become an increasingly attractive destination for Soviet Jews, who are dealing with persecution as the Soviet state is eroded and various nationalist movements - some of them anti-Semitic - gain strength. West German Jewish community leader Heinz Galinski said Germany must be willing to accept Soviet Jews, but that regulations are needed ``to avoid chaos'' caused by huge numbers. Galinski, head of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, said he estimates 800 Soviet Jewish immigrants have reached East Germany the last nine months. About 400 Soviet Jews have settled in West Germany the last two years, the Bonn government said. Guenther Krause, a top East German negotiator, was talking with officials in Bonn in hopes of avoiding a temporary ban like the one that West Germany made, the Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper reported in Munich. East Berlin's Jewish Cultural Union sharply criticized Bonn's action, saying it is out of step with ``the German responsibility toward the Jewish people.'' Jewish leaders in East and West already are upset about the wording of the preamble of the unification treaty between the two German states. The leaders are seeking a clear statement of the Germans' responsibility for the Holocaust that claimed the lives of an estimated 6 million Jews. A draft of the preamble contained only general wording about peace and democracy. While seeking fixed numbers for Soviet Jewish immigrants, West Germany continues to accept thousands of asylum-seekers from Eastern Europe and Third World countries. The refugees are strapping West Germany's social services, still reeling from the influx of 500,000 East Germans the last nine months.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Troops Liberate Besieged Fort
DOC.TEXT: Troops backed by air cover broke a three-month siege of Jaffna Fort on Thursday and killed at least 100 Tamil guerrillas during the surprise predawn attack, the military said. It said 12 soldiers also were killed in the assault, which freed more than 200 policemen and soldiers who had been trapped in the fort by rebels since June 13. ``The assaulting battle group ... is consolidating and clearing adjacent areas,'' said a statement issued by the military. It said ``heavy resistence'' by guerrillas of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam had been reported but gave no details. There were no independent reports on the attack from Jaffna, 185 miles northeast of Colombo. Communications have been severed since summer while the government battled Tamil guerrillas. Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunga said gunboats and helicopter gunships bombarded the 17th century fort while 360 soldiers paddled across a shallow lagoon in rubber dinghies and fought their way into the area. The Tigers fought back with rockets, grenades and heavy-caliber guns, military officials said. An ir force plane crashed in the lagoon after the siege was broken and the pilot bailed out but was missing, the military statement said. The reports indicated the soldiers had outwitted the Tamil Tigers by paddling across the lagoon during the aerial bombardment, instead of trying to break across a heavily mined causeway that leads to the rear of the star-shaped Dutch colonial fort. The fort is a classic of military architecture with a moat, drawbridge, watch towers and 20-foot walls. Crushing the guerrilla siege was an important psychological victory for the government forces, but its value was more symbolic than strategic. The fort and nearby Jaffna town is Tiger territory, and so is most of the surrounding peninsula, the longtime power base of the 7-year-old Tamil revolt against the Sinhalese majority that controls Sri Lanka's government. Nevertheless, the massive government fort symbolizes Sinhalese power in the peninsula. The government opened talks last year to try to negotiate a peaceful settlement with the Tigers, who say they need a separate homeland to protect the Tamil minority from discrimination by the Sinhalese. The talks and a 13-month-old cease-fire broke down when the Tigers launched a series of raids on June 11 on police stations and army camps in northern and eastern Sri Lanka. Hundreds of unarmed policemen were massacred after surrendering to the rebels, and the government declared it was time for all-out war to crush the Tigers. The guerrillas laid siege to the fort on June 13. The government launched its offensive on Aug. 22, but its forces became locked in battle nearby with guerrillas. Meantime, helicopters swooped over the fort to drop food to the men trapped inside. Drinking water was provided in the form of ice blocks, which quickly melted in the tropical heat. At least twice helicopter pilots braved rebel fire to land at the fort and pick up seriously wounded troops. Having liberated the fort, the government's next goal likely is to take the town of Jaffna. The government says more than 3,000 people have been killed the last three months, bringing the death toll to 14,000 since the revolt began in 1983. The northeast is home for most of Sri Lanka's Tamils, who form 18 percent of the island's population of 16 million. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the people.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants $1.8 Billion
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will ask Congress for an additional $1.8 billion to cover costs of the military deployment in the Persian Gulf through the end of the month, administration and congressional sources said Thursday. The emergency request, to be formally submitted to Congress on Friday, also includes an expected request to forgive $7 billion in past military debt owed the United States by Egypt, the sources said. And it includes a proposal to transfer another $900 million from unused accounts within the Pentagon to make up the rest of the $2.7 billion additional costs imposed by Operation Desert Shield, the sources said. The 1990 fiscal year ends Sept. 30. The White House hopes that paying some of the bills from the deployment in the current year will ease pressure at least slightly as the administration and Congress draft a Defense Department budget for 1991, according to the sources who spoke on condition that they not be identified. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, in visits to key members of the House and Senate on Wednesday, argued that the debt forgiveness for Egypt is necessary to reward an ally that has taken a leadership role in rallying the Arab world against Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. In the private meetings, Eagleburger has made the case that aid to Egypt bolsters a moderate Arab state and helps to stem the rising tide of Moslem fundamentalism in the Middle East. Egypt has been the linchpin of U.S. efforts to mount a broad international response to the invasion, Eagleburger argued. But while many lawmakers agree Egypt is worthy of a reward, they wince at the size of the debt writeoff and worry that other U.S. aid recipients will line up for similar largesse at a time when the budget can ill afford it. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said he has asked the administration for a better idea of how much the debt forgiveness will cost the United States in lost repayments each year. ``Egypt should be helped,'' said Leahy, chairman of the Senate Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee. ``They do have their necks out about as far as you can get. But there's going to be a need to help a lot of people,'' and he would like to handle it all at once instead of piecemeal, and with a full picture of the costs involved, Leahy said. The administration official acknowledged the difficulty, alluding to the perennial unpopularity in Congress of foreign aid: ``There's a lot of head scratching over how we are going to pull this off 30 days before an election.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Ministers, 69 Lawmakers Worked for Stasi, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Parliament voting against interior ministry's ouster, minister denying he worked for Stasi, West Berlin mayor supporting sit-in. Pickup graf 14 pvs, `The Stasi...'
DOC.TEXT: Struggling through its final days, East Germany's first free government faced new charges Thursday that it still contains the most hated remnants of the old regime. A prominent activist who headed a committee assigned to dissolve the Communist secret police said 69 current lawmakers and four ministers had worked with the secret police. During a 14-hour Parliament session, lawmakers bickered over the allegations and the government's announcement the previous day that it had purged 56 suspected secret police agents from government posts this week. But they voted against demanding that Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere oust Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel, who has been under fire for months for allowing secret police agents on his payroll. Meanwhile, 22 activists who helped bring down the Communist regime by leading protests last fall continued to occupy the headquarters of the secret police. The activists, who have been occupying the headquarters since Sept. 4 and went on a hunger strike Wednesday, are demanding public access to the secret records kept on 6 million people. West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper visited the activists Thursday and said he supports their cause. The furor over the dark past was heightened by comments made by Werner Fischer, a prominent activist who led a committee assigned to oversee the dissolution of the Communist secret police unit. In an interview with the East German news agency ADN, Fischer said there were four ministers in the government who were unoffical members of the Stasi. He named Environment Minister Karl-Hermann Steinberg as ``an example.'' Steinberg denied the accusation. Matthias Gehler, spokesman for the prime minister, criticized Fischer for naming Steinberg but said de Maiziere wanted to speak with Steinberg. Fischer was also quoted as saying 68 members of the 400-member Parliament worked with the Stasi. In addition, he was quoted as saying Diestel fought attempts by Fischer's committee to investigate the number of Stasi agents working in the Interior Ministry, which is responsible for law enforcement. The Stasi used threats, intimidation, surveillance, beatings and purportedly murder to keep in check 16 million people during Communist rule of the country. Former agents have said a system of favors and contacts still exists in the goverment. Nearly 200,000 people were either official or unofficial members of the network, and tens of thousands more worked as informants. Parliament convened Thursday to discuss aspects of a treaty that lays many of the conditions for unifying with West Germany on Oct. 3. Much of the debate was spent on the growing obsession with the secret police. Fischer headed a citizen's committee made up of activists appointed by the caretaker government, which took over after hard-line leader Erich Honecker was ousted from power last autumn. The committee had completed organizing Stasi files and materials when it was replaced by a new committee formed after de Maiziere was elected in March. The second committee last week handed the government a list of 5,000 names of undercover Stasi agents who worked in government ministries. On Wednesday, the government said 56 people who were on that list were either fired or put on leaves of absence. Most of them worked in Diestel's department.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say They've Cured Diabetes in Rats; Diabetes Group Cautious
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th graf: ``The researchers,'' to make ``the anti-rejection drug'' read ``an anti-rejection drug.''
DOC.TEXT: Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center say they've cured diabetes in rats by transplanting clumps of cells from the pancreas to the thymus gland. Richard Kahn, chief scientist and medical officer for the American Diabetes Association, said the study was important but added: ``We should be clear that we have not found a cure for diabetes.'' Nearly 1 million Americans - a number that grows by 10,000 to 15,000 a year - suffer from Type One diabetes in which there are no insulin-producing cells, called islets, in the pancreas. A far greater number suffer from Type Two diabetes in which the body produces some - but not enough - insulin. The missing insulin must be replaced by daily injections. The researchers said the thymus implants restored the blood sugar in the rats to normal levels and permanently cured the diabetes with only a single dose of an anti-rejection drug. A team led by Dr. Clyde Barker was the first to cure diabetes in animals by islet transplantation 17 years ago. But the islets were rejected within a few days without continuing heavy doses of anti-rejection drugs. The latest findings were detailed in Friday's edition of Science magazine. Barker, chief of surgery at the Penn Medical Center, co-authored the report. ``This is the first indication that we can engraft foreign islets and restore normal glucose to diabetic individuals without subjecting them to chronic, long-life immunosuppression with side effects,'' said Ali Naji, professor of surgery at Penn. The thymus didn't reject the implants of pancreatic islets and didn't require repeated injection to lower the rats' immune response, a finding that surprised the researchers. Kahn said the study helps in the understanding of the body's immune system, but he doubts whether it holds hope for human diabetics. ``The reason it is slim is that your thymus gland all but disappears before the age of 2, so that it's very difficult to find any trace of the thymus gland,'' Kahn said. ``We don't know how it functions after that period, so it's questionable if this is of clinical significance.'' In April, researchers at Washington University said a similar transplant of insulin-producing cells into the liver of a woman with diabetes enabled her to go without daily insulin injections for more than two weeks. But the woman's body then began to reject the transplant. Andrew Posselt, an M.D.-Ph.D. student at Penn who conducted the experiment, said the thymus is well-suited for the transplantation of islets.
