The gland, near the thyroid gland at the base of the neck, doesn't permit white blood cells to enter the organ easily, which makes it a protective site from the immune system. Also, the cells in the thymus can differentiate between substances in its own body and foreign substances, Posselt said. ``So if islets are transplanted into the thymus, we think that the cells can be tricked into thinking that the foreign tissue is actually part of its own body, and the immune system won't be able to respond to it,'' Posselt said. Posselt said the blood sugar levels in the rats remained normal for more than 200 days and some are still working normally after about 17 months. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Refugees Into U.S. Hit Decade High
DOC.TEXT: The United States admitted 107,000 refugees in 1989, the highest influx in a decade, the Department of Health and Human Services said Thursday. Of the 107,000, 39,414 came from the Soviet Union, 37,066 from Southeast Asia, 4,826 from Iran, 3,808 from Cuba, 1,745 from Afghanistan and 1,724 from Ethiopia. Amerasians - children with a Vietnamese mother and American father - comprised 8,721 of the total, HHS said. Since 1975, the United States has admitted more than 1.3 million refugees, HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan said in an annual report to Congress. ``I am proud that we are able to welcome these refugees to our country and to assist them in their quest for self-sufficiency,'' Sullivan said in a statement. The 107,000 was an increase of 31,000 from 1988. It was the largest number of refugees since 1981. Through English language and vocational training programs, more than 24,000 refugees were placed in unsubsidized employment last year, said Jo Anne B. Barnhart, HHS assistant secretary for family support. ``These individuals and their families are now repaying this country through their work efforts and their tax dollars,'' Barnhart said. HHS reimburses states for costs of providing cash and medical assistance to refugees during their initial months in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Invasion Cost Nearly $164 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department estimates that the cost of the U.S. invasion of Panama last December was about $163.6 million, says a congressional report released Thursday. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found that the incremental cost for Operation Just Cause was about $155 million for the Army, $5.7 million for the Air Force and $2.9 million for the Navy. The incremental expense represents the cost over and about the price for normal operations. The invasion that began in the early morning hours Dec. 20, 1989 and lasted until Jan. 31 involved 27,000 U.S. troops, including 13,000 who were stationed in Panama. The objective of Operation Just Cause was to remove Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega, who had been indicted in the United States on drug charges. The GAO based its report on estimates from the military services and did not independently verify the numbers. Among the costs associated with Operation Just Cause were expenses incurred prior to the invasion, including practice missions and the price of evacuating military dependents. Other expenses included replacing aircraft and vehicles lost during the operation, the price of ammunition and allowances paid to military personnel, including imminent danger pay and family separation pay. The release of the costs associated with the Panama invasion comes as the Bush administration is estimating that the U.S. military buildup to deter Iraqi aggression could cost as much as $15 billion in the next fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Kessler Leading Candidate To Head FDA
DOC.TEXT: The leading candidate to head the Food and Drug Administration is David A. Kessler, medical director of the Albert Einstein medical school in New York, sources said Thursday. Though Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan has not sent Kessler's name to the White House, he is said to be the secretary's choice to lead the agency, said sources who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The top spot at FDA has been vacant since Frank Young resigned under pressure nearly a year ago. James Benson has been acting FDA commissioner pending appointment of a permanent successor. Kessler was a consultant to Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, for several years in the early 1980s. He is a member of an HHS advisory commission that was formed to study problems at the agency, which has been under scrutiny since an investigation of its generic drug division uncovered evidence of fraud and bribery last year. Kessler earned a medical degree from Harvard and a law degree from the University of Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Scattered Rain and Flooding in South; Nebraska Cools Off
DOC.TEXT: Rain extended over most of the nation Thursday, causing flooding in Texas and some southern states. Cooler weather was forecast in sizzling Nebraska. Flooding was expected Friday across a portion of southeast Texas from Palacios to Huntsville. There was minor flooding Thursday in northwest Georgia. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms extended from the Texas coast across Louisiana to Florida, along the East Coast into eastern Pennsylvania and in northwest Minnesota and North Dakota. Low pressure over northern North Dakota moved east Thursday, while a cool front trailed southwest across the northern Plains toward northwest Nebraska. The National Weather Service said the front would bring rain and cooler weather Friday to Nebraska. Nebraska has sizzled for most of September, with temperatures in the high 90s accompanied by high humidity. Many schools suspended classes because of the weather. In Colorado, unseasonable highs continued. By early afternoon, Colorado Springs reached 88 degrees, tying a heat record for the date. Pueblo reached 97, breaking a record of 96 degrees last reached in 1956. Fog forced air traffic controllers to shut down Greater Cincinnati International Airport and nine satellite regional airports for about an hour Thursday morning. The dense fog was caused by a combination of humidity, rain, wet ground conditions and cooler air that reached the region Thursday. Temperatures aroun the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 59 degrees at Caribou, Maine, to 103 degrees at Twentynine Palms, Calif. The lowest temperature in the nation Thursday was 29 degrees at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: General Powell Tours Bases in Arabia - Troops Ask `How Long?'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Powell leaving for Bahrain, Schwarzkopf says he'll have winning force within 2 months, 8-day delay in U.S. deployment, edits to trim. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DOD1,2
DOC.TEXT: The top American military commander extolled troops in the Saudi desert Thursday to ``bear with me'' as evidence mounted the deployment of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf region will be a prolonged one. Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told Army infantrymen during a pep talk at their desert camp that they had the support of President Bush and the American public for their mission. ``Don't think I ever forget that you have loved ones back home,'' Powell added. But at each of a half-dozen stops at Army, Air Force and Marine camps, the four-star general, clad in desert camouflage, was pressed by servicemen about the likely length of their stay. ``I want to get you home as fast as possible but bear with me,'' Powell said. ``I can't give you an exact date.'' At a news conference, Powell said rotations of troops will start ``as soon as possible,'' a welcome message for the troops but another sign that military planners foresee a lengthy deployment. ``Even if Iraq pulled out starting tomorrow, I'd be here probably six months minimum,'' one general who met with Powell said, asking that he not be named. Powell, who later flew to Bahrain, refused to say how long the Bush administration would tolerate Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, now in its sixth week. Gen. Norman H. Schwarzkopf, the U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia, said his forces were strong enough to stop an Iraqi attack now but the infusion of more armored units the next two months will provide a ``100 percent chance'' of winning any battle. ``Give me a couple of months and I'll be able to stand up and say ... there is absolutely no question whatsoever'' of the outcome, Schwarzkopf said. If Iraqi President Saddam Hussein were to order an attack now, ``I feel confident we could handle the problem and he would suffer extraordinary losses. But I still do not have the ground forces of choice that I need to fight a mobile war in the desert,'' he said. A senior U.S. officer who spoke on condition he not be named said no end to the U.S. military presence is in sight. He all but ruled out a unilateral U.S. military action to force Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``It's the classic Mexican standoff,'' said the official. ``I wouldn't want to launch an offensive against Kuwait with 150,000-200,000 troops on the ground. ... And I don't think Saddam Hussein is going to leave.'' Powell said the mission of the American troops remained a defensive one and that the U.S. forces would leave when asked to by the Saudi government. ``We have no desire to have any permanent presence,'' he said. The U.S. deployment to the region, including sailors and Marines, now is about 145,000 men and women. Powell said the U.S. deployment was behind schedule because of delayed transport ships and a limited airlift capacity. ``You're bound to have glitches,'' he said. But most vital heavy gear was here or nearing Saudi ports, he said. Schwarzkopf, interviewed at the headquarters of U.S. forces, said the flow of equipment for American forces into Saudi Arabia was eight days behind schedule because of logistical problems, including two broken-down Navy ships. Pentagon spokesman Bob Hall said the fast sealift ship Antares was transferring its goods to another fast ship at Spain's port of Rota. Another ship has engine problems in the Atlantic and may need to be towed, Hall said. Powell played down suggestions there would be command problems directing a multinational forces in combat, saying if hostilities erupted, a command structure could be put in place. Powell planned to visit a Navy ship Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Lotto Jackpot Soars to $100 Million
DOC.TEXT: Florida's Lotto jackpot reached $100 million Thursday with tickets for Saturday's drawing selling at a rate of 500 a second. Players poured in from other states and countries with dreams of becoming millionaires, or of making a few bucks selling the $1 tickets at a higher price to those who could not make it to Florida. The tickets are not sold outside the state. Two men from New Orleans, Joe Revolta and Robert Bache, plunked down $10,000 in cash Wednesday for 10,000 tickets at Groovin' Noovin's, a Pensacola convenience store near the Alabama-Florida state line. ``It's on our news in Louisiana constantly,'' Revolta said. ``You might not have much of a chance, but you have even less if you don't play.'' State lottery officials on Thursday increased the jackpot to $100 million, the second largest in U.S. history, but said they doubted it would break the record of $115 million. The expected jackpot is based on sales and projected sales through Saturday. About 30 people flew from Atlanta to Pensacola Regional Airport early Wednesday, bought tickets at a nearby convenience store and went home, said Gene Mumtzis of Eagle Travel. ``One guy said he goes to California, Ohio and everywhere else to buy tickets,'' Mumtzis said. Richard Cardone, owner of a Pittsburgh beauty salon, bought 50 tickets during an airline stopover in West Palm Beach. ``Who wouldn't play?'' asked Cardone. ``You'd be a fool not to. Everybody's fantasy is to be a multimillionaire.'' Bahamians carrying thousands of dollars are flying to south Florida to buy tickets tosell at a higher price back home, the Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale reported. ``They come every Friday. This week they will bring $4,000 to $5,000,'' said George Prado, who sells lottery tickets at the Caribe Cafeteria, a Cuban restaurant near Miami International Airport. To play the Florida Lotto game, players select six numbers from one to 49. The winning numbers are chosen at random during a weekly, televised drawing. The odds of one ticket containing all six winning numbers are about one-in-14 million. But for every dollar spent, there was a dream. ``First, I would help the church in any way I could, then I would buy a ticket to fly to the moon,'' said Anne Straub, 66, of Gulf Breeze. ``I've just always wanted to go into space.'' On Thursday, tickets sold at a rate of 500 a second, said Florida Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul. The highest sales were reported along the state's lines with Georgia and Alabama, she said. Results of Saturday night's drawing would be announced Sunday, although the final size of the jackpot would not be determined until Monday, she said. The record jackpot of $115 million was split among 14 winning tickets in Pennsylvania's Super 7 game in April 1989. Florida's previous record Lotto prize was a $58 million jackpot split between five winners in April. Each winning ticket was worth nearly $11.7 million, to be paid out over 20 years. Sheelah Ryan of Winter Springs holds the world record for a prize to a single winner of a computerized numbers game. She won a $55.1 million Florida Lotto jackpot in September 1988. In Florida, 50 percent of each dollar spent on the lottery is returned in prizes, 38 percent goes to the state's schools system and the rest is split between retailers and the lottery department.

DOC.HEAD: Forty Three - Count 'em - 43 Marilyn Monroes
LaserPhoto FX2
DOC.TEXT: Forty-three Marilyn Monroe look-a-likes fanned out through a downtown plaza Thursday in a stunt stemming from the sex symbol's roots - as an artichoke queen. The show was designed to convince the public that ``artichokes, not diamonds, are a girl's best friend.'' Why 43? Because 43 years ago Marilyn Monroe was the first official California Artichoke Queen, said Patty Boman of the California Artichoke Advisory Board. ``Artichoke growers believe that during Marilyn's reign more people than ever before were inspired to eat artichokes,'' she said. It was no coincidence, Boman noted, that the two-day Castroville Artichoke Festival starts Saturday. Castroville, 40 miles south of San Francisco, is dubbed the artichoke capital of the world. The women were costumed to resemble Monroe in her role in the movie ``The Seven Year Itch.'' All were topped by blonde wigs and wore white satin dresses. The platoon of photographers that showed up at Justin Herman Plaza on the waterfront snapped away as one of the Marilyns, also known as Dianna Dawn, attempted to duplicate the famous scene in the movie in which a gust of air raises the star's dress to display her legs. Dawn and her colleagues circulated through the lunch time crowd to distribute artichoke leaves as songs by Monroe flowed from a loud speaker. The tunes included ``A Fine Romance,'' ``I Want to Be Loved By You'' and ``Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend.'' The 43 lined up behind tuxedo-clad Castroville artichoke grower Dale Huss, who told the crowd that ``artichokes, not diamonds, are a girl's best friend.'' ``Tell us about you reign as queen in 1947,'' Huss asked Dawn, who does a fairly good impression of Monroe. ``I always eat artichokes when it rains,'' she answered. The problem with artichokes, said Boman, is not enough people know how good they are, or even that the vegetable exists. ``We measure in terms of cartons,'' she said. ``Last year we sold 4.2 million cartons. Most of that was on the West Coast. A shocking proportion of Bay area residents have never tried artichokes.'' Artichoke leaves are usually peeled off and dipped in a sauce. Then the choke is removed and the heart is scooped out and consumed. Some eateries offer the hearts deep-fried. The samples passed out by the look-a-likes went fast. Monroe is still big business, according to Roger Richman who represents the estate of the actress who committed suicide in 1962. He said 89 companies in the United States are licensed to use the name and likeness of the star of such movies as ``Some Like It Hot,'' and ``Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.'' The stint as Artichoke Queen must have helped her career. Richman noted that she made her first film a year later. It was a bit part in something called ``Scudda-Hoo! Scudda-Hay!''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Begins Debate Over Tougher Standards
DOC.TEXT: The Senate will be asked to renew the 55 mile sper hour national speed limit as an alternative to required increases in new-car gasoline mileage, a Michigan senator told his colleagues Thursday. ``If we want to cut down on the amount of gasoline being used, we can put the 55 mph speed limit back in ... and we'll burn a lot less gas and we'll save energy right now, today,'' said Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich. in preliminary debate on a fuel-efficiency measure. The provision is strenously opposed by the auto industry, headquartered in Riegle's home state, and hailed by conservationists as one of the most important steps possible to reduce demand for oil. Riegle and Sen. Carl Levin, also D-Mich., urged their colleagues to postpone action on the fuel economy bill until next year, when it could be considered as part of a comprehensive energy program. But proponents said there was no reason to delay a new standard that would reduce U.S. deendence on foreign oil and reduce carbon dioxide emissions, one cause of the global warming predicted by many scientists. ``It does not take a crystal ball to realize that if we don't start conserving now, some future president may have to consider sending our young men and woman back to the deserts of the Middle East,'' said Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., the bill's chief sponsor. The bill would require automakers to boost the average mileage of new car fleets by 20 percent by 1995 and about 40 percent by the year 2001, or about 40 miles per gallon in the current government test. Both a 55-mph speed limit and the fuel economy requriement, now 27.5 mpg, were required by Congress as fuel-saving measures in the wake of the 1973 oil embargo. By 1986, the speed limit was widely ignored and Congress relaxed it, giving states then option of a 65-mph limit on rural interstate highways. Most have done so. Although senators discussed the pros and cons of the bill Thursday, the question actually at hand was whether to bring it up for consideration. A vote is expected Friday on a motion to officially open debate. It is regarded as a key test of the degree of support for the bill. If the motion passes, opponents have signaled they would mount a filibuster and offer a string of amendments in a bid to derail the measure. Levin told the Senate he could support some increase in fuel efficiency standards as part of an overall conservation package. But he said the Bryan bill was ``not a reasonable and balanced approach.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Approves Austerity Plan to Absorb Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Cabinet on Thursday adopted an economic plan that includes tax increases to help pay for the settlement of the 1 million Soviet immigrants expected by the end of the decade. The plan also is meant to turn Israel's socialist-style economy into a more capitalist one. Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai presented it during a marathon 10-hour Cabinet meeting. Parliament must approve the plan, which is expected to meet stiff opposition from left-wing parties. Israel radio said the government expected it to raise at least $500 million over the next year, but a proposal to impose a 16 percent tax on fruits and vegetables and on tourism was not approved. A special ministerial committee was appointed to discuss that measure. The Cabinet did approve Modai's proposal to impose a 20 percent tax on lottery winnings and on earnings from pension and saving plans, a 16 percent tax on cigarettes and a 14 percent tax on beer. It also approved a proposal to ease restrictions on capital markets to encourage outside and domestic investment. ``What we are trying to do is remove taxes or burdens which are stopping growth and transfer them to things which do not affect growth,'' Modai said at a news conference. One measure likely to meet stiff resistance in Parliament is a proposal to lower the minimum wage for some workers as an incentive to employers to create more jobs. Under the plan, employers would not have to pay immigrants the minimum wage, about $475 dollars a month, for their first half year of employment. Ora Namir, a legislator for the left-of-center Labor Party that runs the Histadrut Labor Union vowed she and her party would ``launch a tremendous struggle,'' against that proposal. Former Finance Minister Shimon Peres said the plan would not help the immigration problems. ``I don't see a plan for the absorption of 250,000 immigrants, nor a plan for stabilizing the economy,'' Peres, leader of the opposition Labor Party, said on Israel television. ``The government made no decisions about its own budget, about its policy on salaries or war on inflation.'' Already the nearly 90,000 Soviet Jews who have arrived this year face severe housing and job shortages. Officials estimate it will cost $20 billion to $30 billion to provide housing and jobs for the Soviets the next two years.

DOC.HEAD: New Round of Salvadoran Peace Talks Starts Amid Heavy Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran peace negotiators on Thursday began their fifth round of talks this year, and Salvador's army reported renewed fighting between government and rebel troops. The army said without elaborating that 61 rebels and soldiers were killed or injured and five civilians injured in stepped-up fighting Wednesday night and Thursday morning. At least 73,000 people have been killed in the nearly 11-year-old civil war. Representatives of President Alfredo Cristiani's conservative, U.S.-backed administration and leaders of the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, agreed this year in Venezuela to try to reach a cease-fire by Saturday. But the two have reached an impasse in their talks on the issue of military reforms, which the guerrillas have been demanding. The negotiating teams appeared to not to have yet resolved the issue of army reforms as they began the talks in Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Ship Recovers Debris in Area Where Jet Went Down
DOC.TEXT: Searchers recovered debris Thursday in the area where a missing jetliner was believed to have ditched in the North Atlantic with 16 people aboard. The Boeing 727 disappeared Tuesday off Newfoundland. Transport Canada spokesman Dick Pepper said a Canadian Forces search plane spotted the debris, and a Coast Guard ship dispatched to the area retrieved five plastic-foam cylinders about 240 miles southeast of Cape Race. Pepper said he did not know what their use was. He described them as ``five hard-packed Styrofoam cylinders, 14 inches in length, 4} inches in diameter, with brass screws in one end.'' The site is in the middle of a major ocean shipping lane, so the debris could have come from passing ships and not the missing jet, he said. The jet, owned by Faucett Airlines of Peru and carrying Peruvian airline crew members and their relatives, disappeared Tuesday afternoon after the pilot radioed that he was short of fuel. The plane was headed for a refueling stop in Gander, Newfoundland, en route to Miami from the Mediterranean island of Malta. Pepper said the rain and fog off Newfoundland's southern coast was hampering the search for the plane. If it ditched successfully, there was only a slim chance the plane would be afloat after two days, he said. But if the plane was equipped with life rafts the crew could have escaped, he said. Maj. Walt Chipchase, spokesman for the Canadian Forces, said the plane carried one 22-person liferaft.

DOC.HEAD: Revolutionary Treatment Readied
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf: ``Scientists said,'' to CORRECT ``do expect'' to ``do not expect''
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old girl was being prepared to become the first patient to receive gene therapy in a study that scientists say could revolutionize he treatment of disease, officials said Thursday. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health said they expected to be ready to begin the gene-restoration treatment Friday on the child, who was born with a defective immune system unable to fight infections and diseases. Scientists said they do not expect to see results from the treatment during the first few months. But if successful, it would put researchers on a new frontier in medicine that could lead to similar treatments for cancer, hemophilia, sickle cell anemia, AIDS and other diseases. ``We feel that this is potentially a major new therapy option that should have significant clinical effects in the next century,'' said Dr. W. French Anderson, a researcher at the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute at NIH. ``It's very exciting,'' said R. Michael Blaese, an immunology expert at the National Cancer Institute. Because of the potential of the therapy and the importance of the testing, Anderson said researchers are beginning slowly and cautiously with their first patient. The child, who was not identified, has a rare genetic disease called ADA deficiency - a defective gene which means her immune system does not function adequately because the enzyme it produces is defective. This leaves her vulnerable to infections and diseases most people can fight off. Only about 10 children a year are born with the disease. Without treatment they die within the first two years of life. The best current treatment is a bone marrow transplant with a donor whose tissue type matches the child's, such as from a brother or sister. Experts say most children do not have a matched donor. For the children without a match, their options are a partially matched bone marrow transplant, which fails half the time, or enzyme replacement therapy with a drug called PEG-ADA. Weekly injections of the new drug decreases the severity of infections for some patients, but it does not fully restore their immune systems. Researchers have already begun the initial work necessary for the first patient's treatment. Weeks ago, they took white cells from some of her blood and began growing them in tissue culture. Then they inserted a normal ADA gene into these cells with a genetically engineered virus. The virus has been disabled and is no longer infectious, but serves as a vehicle to get the normal gene into the cells where it produces the required enzyme. Once a sufficient number of ADA-corrected cells have been grown, they are infused into the patient intravenously. In the case of this first patient, scientists expect to give her about 1 billion cells - about a small thimbleful - mixed in a saline solution in the first infusion. The treatments will be given once a month for about two years. The experiment, first proposed by NIH in April 1987, was recommended for approval by an advisory committee July 31 and was approved by NIH last week. The Food and Drug Administration gave its go-ahead Thursday afternoon, said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Says Men Wouldn't Face the Criticism Leveled at Her
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher says she is criticized for qualities that are admired in men. ``The characteristics that they criticize you for, that you are strong-minded, that you make firm and tough decisions, are also characteristics which, if you were a man, they would praise you for,'' she said in an interview published Thursday in the October issue of Woman's Journal. ``I think they have not yet fully come to terms with that.'' Mrs. Thatcher continued: ``If you do anything good, then you have got an ulterior motive, and so you are, naturally, like any female of the species, defending yourself and defending everything in which you believe.'' There is one advantage of being a woman in politics, she said. ``If we have a big international conference, they will always know the president of the United States, they will always know the president of the Soviet Union and, being a woman, I am the other one they will automatically recognize.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Overturns Ruling That Blocked Book on Israeli Spy Agency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `A call...' with two grafs to UPDATE with reax from Israeli Embassy, picks up 7th graf pvs, `A hearing...'
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court Thursday overturned a judge's unprecedented order that halted distribution of a new book about the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad. The Israeli government, which won the temporary restraining order Wednesday, failed to prove that its agents' lives were endangered, said a statement by a four-judge panel of the state Appellate Division. The panel also said that with 17,000 books already shipped to stores, ``any grant of injunctive relief in this case would be ineffective.'' ``We think it's a victory for a free press and we are going to sell the book again,'' said Roy Gainsburg, president of the book's publisher, St. Martin's Press. ``It's the only decision. We're grateful to the appellate court for acting quickly.'' He said Israel might appeal to the state Court of Appeals, but added, ``We are starting to tell the bookstores that they can sell the books.'' ``Orders have increased dramatically, which is what always happens when you try to stop a book,'' he added. Reacting to the latest decision, the Israeli Embassy in Washington accused author Victor Ostrovsky of placing personal profit above agents' lives. The book violates Ostrovsky's ``pledge of allegiance towards his country,'' it said in a statement. A hearing in state court scheduled for Friday on Israel's request for a permanent stay was canceled. The original ruling by Justice Michael Dontzin had been roundly criticized by First Amendment experts. Richard Winfield of Rogers & Wells called it ``without precedent and egregious''; it was ``an aberration,'' said Floyd Abrams of Cahill, Gordon & Reindell; ``Prior restraint is basically a no-no,'' said Richard Green of Green & Hillman. They said it apparently marked the first time a foreign nation sought to stop publication in the United States, and predicted the ruling would not stand for long. Following a midnight hearing in his apartment, Dontzin on Wednesday temporarily barred St. Martin's from distributing ``By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer'' by Ostrovsky, who says he served in the spy agency for four years in the 1980s. The book contends Israel had detailed information about preparations for the bombing that killed 241 Marines in Lebanon in 1983, but only gave the United States a vague warning to damage U.S.-Arab relations. In an interview Wednesday, Ostrovsky said agents have threatened his life. He said two of his former commanders turned up at his home in suburban Ottawa at night a week ago. ``They said that it's better for me that I don't write it. They told me to stop it,'' he said. ``I will have to be on the move more or less for the rest of my life.'' Dontzin issued the ruling at the request of the Israeli government, which claims the book could imperil Mossad agents by blowing their cover. It also implies that Mossad agents agree in writing to keep details of their work secret after leaving the service. Lawyers for the publisher immediately appealed the decision. The book's distribution also has been restrained by a judge in Toronto. Under terms set out in a series of U.S. Supreme Court decisions, a litigant seeking to stop publication must shoulder a huge evidential burden - perhaps show that life could be lost - and assure a court that its order could, in fact, stop dissemination of the objectionable material. ``In this case, the book is already out and around town,'' said Abrams. ``Under these conditions, this ruling is literally unthinkable. It is not a close case.'' St. Martin's had shipped out about 17,000 books before Dontzin's ruling, which included instructions that the publishing house contact its customers and tell them not to sell the book. Thomas McCormick, chairman of the house, said St. Martin's made telephone calls or sent telegrams to about 400 locations. Many of the books had been sent to wholesalers, who in turn had to make hundreds of additional calls to stores. McCormick said St. Martin's merely asked its customers not to sell the books. ``We have no authority to order them to do anything,'' he said. ``We simply complied with the judge's order.'' ``It certainly has been reported to us that books have been sold, and we had mailed out about 35 review copies to begin with,'' he added. Jonathan Lerner, a New York lawyer representing the Israeli government, was asked if the distribution had doomed his case. ``I can't say to what extent you can put the genie back in the bottle, because I don't know to what extent it's already out,'' he said. Like the other lawyers, Lerner said he knew of no precedent for a foreign government seeking to bar publication of material in this country. Even if publication could have been stopped, the argument that Israeli lives were jeopardized does not justify prior restraint, Abrams said: ``The usual answer is that there's been enough time to withdraw agents or take other steps.'' The Israeli action also raised the issue of an American court's obligation to a foreign government. Although the Supreme Court has not upheld a request for prior judicial restraint for more than 50 years, the court once speculated that the government might be entitled to prior restraint in a case involving reports of troop movements during wartime. If under such circumstances a court could stop publication to save American lives, must it do the same for Israeli ones? Winfield, chairman of the state Bar Association's committee on media law, noted that the high court had rejected the government's strong national security argument when it allowed newspapers to publish the Pentagon Papers on the Vietnam War two decades ago. ``It's doubtful that an American court is obligated to give the same weight to the security interests of a foreign government that it gives to its own.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Hostages Arrive in North Carolina
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS five grafs after 2nd graf pvs, `The predominant...' to UPDATE with quotes from passengers. picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The plane...' ^LaserPhoto RA2
DOC.TEXT: A jet carrying 263 former hostages from Kuwait, most of them women and children, arrived Thursday to a greeting of flags, balloons and a knot of anxious relatives. The predominant image was of women with babies in their arms as the passengers slowly stepped down the exit ramp at Raleigh-Durham International Airport. Soldiers formed a human cordon to the terminal, and occasionally lifted a straggling child to help a mother. Lorri Zeidan from Riverside, Calif., said she was in Kuwait City with her husband and year-old son, Kamel, when Iraq invaded Aug. 2. Her husband, Khalid, is Palestinian and remained in Kuwait. ``I didn't have to hide,'' she said. ``I didn't feel like a hostage. Everything that's American they blew up.'' But she added, ``You feel like you live in a prison. It's awful.'' A crying woman who didn't give her name said: ``It's great to be here. I want to say `Hi' to all my friends I left behind in Kuwait and I hope they make it.'' The mood inside the airport terminal was almost somber, the quiet broken by scattered applause when more hostages entered the building. Each arriving adult received a yellow carnation and each child got a toy. The plane carried 147 children under age 12 and, of those, 37 under age 2, according to Graham Wilson, spokesman for the North Carolina Department of Crime Control and Public Safety. Iraq is allowing Western women and children to leave Iraq and Kuwait, but is keeping most Western men behind to serve as deterrents to an attack by the United States and its allies. Authorities said the passenger list included one woman 8{ months pregnant and five unaccompanied children. Also aboard the plane were five cats, two of which belonged to diplomats, Wilson said. A vacant terminal was turned into a makeshift refugee center, with an old gift shop used as a registration center and the main waiting room converted into a dining area with long tables covered with dark green tablecloths. A restaurant was set up as a short-term day-care center. Welcoming banners were hung in some areas. Red, white and blue ribbons and balloons dangled elsewhere. The airport's baggage claim and transportation areas were turned into reception centers for people trying to get airline tickets to their homes, or hotel reservations nearby. Relatives at the airport waited for their loved ones to go through customs before they could greet them. Patricia Smith of Jacksonville said she was waiting for her sister, Leona, and six children to get off the plane. ``As far as I know she's doing all right,'' Ms. Smith said. ``She's just glad to get back and I'm glad she's coming back. She's upset because her husband is still back there and he hasn't been able to leave yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Dies from Tornado Injuries; Death Toll Now 28
DOC.TEXT: The death toll from a series of tornadoes that ripped through northeastern Illinois rose to 28 with the death of a 69-year-old man. James Kachel died Wednesday night at Loyola University Medical Center in Maywood, a Chicago suburb, said hospital spokesman Mike Maggio. Kachel of Plainfield suffered severe chest injuries when his car rolled over in the storms, Maggio said. Tornadoes ripped through Plainfield, Joliet and Crest Hill on Aug. 28, injuring more than 300 people. Property damage has been estimated at more than $100 million.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Tax Proposal at Budget Talks Provides Breaks for Upper-Income People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CLARIFY that material was gained from multiple sources; talks have recessed for the night; should stand for AMs.
DOC.TEXT: New taxes proposed by Republicans at the budget summit would cost low- and moderate-income Americans $4.1 billion next year while slashing taxes by $11 billion for those better off, according to documents obtained Thursday by The Associated Press. A Democratic offer would lower by $4 billion the taxes paid by people with incomes below $20,000, while boosting them by $26.8 billion for everyone else, the papers show. In the Republican plan, the biggest break, $7.4 billion, would go to people with incomes of more than $200,000. The estimated distribution of both tax proposals was calculated by Congress' nonpartisan Joint Tax Committee. The documents were made available on condition that the identities of the sources be withheld. The GOP plan included cutting the capital gains tax rate, limiting the deductability of state and local income taxes, a tax on petroleum fuels and higher alcohol taxes. It also contained a proposal to increase excise taxes, extend the soon-to-expire 3 percent tax on telephone calls and change in the child care tax credit. The Democratic proposal included a 20 percent surtax on the income taxes paid by people earning more than $500,000 annually. It would double the beer tax of 16-cents-per-sixpack and the 3-cent-per bottle tax on wine, and boost the $12.50 per gallon levy on spirits by $2. It would increase the 9-cent-per-gallon federal gasoline tax by 11 cents, and put a 4 percent sales tax on other forms of energy. It also contemplates extending the 1.45 percent payroll tax people pay on their first $51,300 of wages each year to all of their additional income, if any. The tax goes to the costs of hospital care provided by Medicare. The documents did not provide additional detail on the taxes in the Republican roposal. Under the GOP plan, people earning $50,000 annually or less would have to pay higher taxes totaling $4.1 billion. Americans with incomes above that amount would receive breaks worth $11 billion, the documents showed. One official, demanding anonymity, said Republicans offered the package Thursday at ongoing negotiations at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. The document describing the Democratic plan was dated Tuesday, fifth day of the 7-day-old talks. But it was unclear when the proposal was actually presented at the bargaining table. Officials, demanding anonymity, said the bargainers were beginning to be pressured by interest groups objecting to proposals such as higher taxes on beer and boosting the payments Medicare recipients make. Differences remained over major stumbling blocks such as cuts to domestic programs and President Bush's desire to cut the capital gains tax rate. ``There is no single issue holding it up,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said of the talks. ``There are a lot of tough issues.'' Foley said he expected the bargaining at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, 10 miles from Washington, to conclude by Sunday. Both sides have discussed the possibility of increasing the $28.60 monthly Medicare premium - which covers doctors' bills - for better-off recipients. It would be the first time the program's costs were adjusted to the income of the senior citizens it serves. But officials involved in the talks said they would not be surprised to see the proposal toned down or withdrawn in light of the tremendous opposition the idea is attracting. The 33 million senior citizens covered by Medicare are considered a potent voting bloc. ``We believe that proposal is a non-starter,'' said Martin Corry, lobbyist for the American Association for Retired Persons, the nation's largest senior citizens' group. Bargainers considered limiting a tax increase on cigarettes to 8 cents per pack, said one official who asked to not be identified. On Wednesday they had discussed doubling the current 16-cent levy. Anheuser-Busch Inc., the nation's largest brewer, began submerging congressional offices with more than 1 million letters and 1.3 million petition signatures it has drummed up in a well-advertised campaign to block higher beer taxes. ``We hope this will convince the negotiators that beer drinkers don't want to see this kind of discriminatory tax, but we'll see,'' said Anheuser-Busch spokesman Mark Abels. One official said that bargainers were now discussing boosting levies on alcohol by $14 billion over five years instead of by $18 billion. But the official did not know what specific taxes would be applied to beer, wine or spirits under those figures. Although details of the bargaining continued to seep out of Andrews, participants continued trying their best to staunch that flow. As an example, Foley was asked by reporters if the negotiators had reached agreement on any issues. ``I think probably maters that I would consider settled - but I wouldn't want to, under torture, tell you what they are,'' he responded.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Bank Withdraws Offer To Guarantee Loans
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss bank has withdrawn its offer to guarantee $50 million in loans to Philadelphia and Gov. Robert Casey said Thursday the state could not provide even short-term relief to the near-bankrupt city. Mayor W. Wilson Goode on Wednesday postponed the city's attempt to sell $375 million in short-term notes rather than face unacceptably high interest rates. The Swiss Bank Corp. withdrew its guarantee of $50 million in temporary loan notes, saying the city failed to meet ``certain conditions.'' Goode met with Council members Thursday and said he was ``in serious discussion'' with Casey and Robert O'Donnell, a Philadelphia Democrat who is speaker of the Pennsylvania Assembly. Goode and Casey are also Democrats. ``In a week I'm going to report where we are,'' the mayor said. In Harrisburg, Casey said there was still hope that the notes could be sold. When asked if the state could make a short-term loan to the city, he said, ``Obviously no. ... Our budget is closed at this point.'' Casey said he told Goode that city officials and the business community must work together to solve the crisis. ``The responsibility still remains with the elected leadership of that city,'' the governor said. ``I don't look at this in political terms. We've been helpful to the city of Philadelphia (but) we have an entire state to take care of.'' The city's finance director, Betsy Reveal, said legal action against the Swiss Bank Corp. was being considered. Reveal said city officials signed a contract with the bank and met all conditions. The bank said only that the city failed to meet ``certain conditions.'' Goode has said the city would be broke by late this month unless it receives a cash infusion, and sought to sell the loan notes. The greater the risk that a city would be unable to pay its debts, the higher the interest it must offer to buyers of its loan notes. The notes would be repaid from property and business tax receipts expected early next year. Even so, the city projects a $206.4 million deficit in its $2.1 billion budget by next June. Four local banks last week rejected a city request to guarantee notes.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Error Due to Upside-down Measuring Rod
DOC.TEXT: A 2-foot metal rod accidentally put in upside-down caused the flaw in the Hubble Space Telescope's primary mirror, NASA investigators said Thursday. ``It is, unfortunately, an error we now believe an operator is likely to have made,'' said Lew Allen, director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, who led the investigative team. ``It was a technical error made by people of good will who made a mistake,'' he said. The team on Thursday concluded two days of meetings at Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., which manufactured the $1.5 billion telescope's primary mirror in the late 1970s and early 1980s. At that time, Hughes Danbury was the optical division of Perkin-Elmer Corp. The company conducted tests that revealed the error, but they were considered unreliable at the time and disregarded, Allen said. The name of the operator who made the mistake was not released. The rod, made of the temperature-insensitive metal invar, was used in a measuring device called a reflective null corrector, which read the curve of the mirror's surface as it was polished. The incorrect placement led to a 1.3 millimeter spacing error that caused the mirror to be made into the wrong shape. No one could tell with a naked eye that the rod was upside-down because it was surrounded by other parts of the null corrector, he said. The flaw, called a spherical aberration, has blurred the view of the orbiting observatory, which was supposed to take razor-sharp pictures of outer space. It will be corrected during a previously scheduled 1993 space shuttle mission to replace the Hubble's most powerful instrument, the wide-field planetary camera, said Charles Pellerin, director of astrophysics for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Pellerin said it would cost an extra $15 million to correct the flaw. NASA originally estimated the new camera would cost up to $65 million, he said. Allen said many tests could have detected the error during the manufacturing process, but Perkin-Elmer scientists and engineers didn't do them because they were pressured to finish the project. The pressures, including cost overruns and time constraints, distracted those working on the mirror, he said. Some tests that detected the error were considered unreliable at the time, he said. ``They could have been trusted. They weren't,'' Allen said. But Allen said that did not mean Perkin-Elmer was negligent. ``With 20-20 hindsight, one would clearly say there was negligence ... but you have to take into account the situation that actually existed,'' he said. The investigative team, which visited Hughes Danbury three times, will issue a final report soon, Allen said. NASA's Office of the Inspector General continues to investigate, Pellerin said. The flaw, discovered shortly after Hubble was launched in April, is one of a series of problems facing the space agency. NASA's shuttles were grounded because of fuel leaks and its Magellan spacecraft temporarily ceased communication with earth while orbiting Venus. Because of the Hubble flaw, NASA withheld about $3 million in so-called ``performance fees'' to Hughes Danbury, Pellerin said. Performance fees represent a company's profit after NASA has paid for labor costs. NASA's total contract with the company was worth about $450 million and Hughes has received $10 million in performance fees, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan: Will Provide Another $3 Billion to Forces, Gulf Region
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs with official saying contribution wasn't linked to U.S. demands, Japan can't pay more, details.
DOC.TEXT: Japan will provide an additional $3 billion in aid to international peacekeeping forces in the Persian Gulf and nations suffering from the U.N.-sponsored embargo against Iraq, the government announced Friday. The Cabinet decision brings Japan's total aid in the gulf crisis to more than $4 billion. Members of the U.S. Congress had complained Japan was not doing more in the crisis, and had not contributed enough in light of its high dependence on Middle East oil. Misoji Sakamoto, the chief government spokesman, said Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had telephoned President Bush to notify him of the increase in contribution. ``President Bush expressed deep appreciation and told Kaifu that he will tell his people that Japan is playing an active role in the international effort in the gulf,'' Sakamoto told reporters. Sakamoto said Japan would provide $1 billion to the U.S.-led forces deployed in the gulf region in the aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of oil-rich Kuwait, in addition to $1 billion already pledged. Together, Iraq and Kuwait possess 20 percent of the world's oil reserves. Another $2 billion would go to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey to help them overcome setbacks from the economic embargo imposed against Iraq, he added. Of the aid for those frontline states, Sakamoto said Japan would give $600 million in the first year as an ``exceptional measure to respond to the emergency situation.'' He said it would be in the form of a loan at 1 percent annual interest, repayable in 30 years. The additional contribution to the peacekeeping forces was based on ``the development of the situation in the Middle East and international efforts of other countries,'' Sakamoto said. The 4 billion dollar total figure matched the contribution that Japanese press reports said the United States was demanding from Japan. Japan pledged Aug. 29 it would provide 1 billion dollars in non-military aid to the peacekeeping forces. The first shipment of 800 four-wheel-drive vehicles and other equipment already has left for the Middle East. It also announced $22 million to help refugees stranded in the region. Sakamoto said Japan's increased contribution was not in response to U.S. demands. ``This is Japan's contribution to the world based on the United Nations resolutions. ... We are not only listening to what the United States says,'' he added. Sakamoto said the expanded contribution was the maximum Japan could provide at this point. Sakamoto also reiterated Japan's rejection of efforts by the U.S. House of Representatives to link Japan's contribution to the gulf peacekeeping effort with Japanese support for American troops based here.

DOC.HEAD: OAS Hopes for Early Haitian Election Despite Cost Problems
DOC.TEXT: The Organization of American States wants tosend 400 election monitors to Haiti but doesn't have the money, Secretary-General Joao Clemente Baena Soares said Wednesday. His remark at the regular weekly meeting of the OAS permanent council was regarded as an indirect appeal for the United States to pay $51 million it owes the organization. Baena Soares spoke after a Haitian diplomat told the council Haitians will begin registering for the election during the first week in October. But, Ambassador Raymond Joseph said, no date has been set as yet for the election itself. The Haitian said interim President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot has suggested the election take place in November but said some members of the Council of State are opposed. The 19-member council has veto power over the president. Baena Soares expressed hope the presidential election, originally planned early this year, would not be postponed again. Haitian President Pascal-Trouillot was offered a U.S. grant of $3 million for setting up the election when she visited Washington last May and heard President Bush declare that present chances of a democratic vote in Haiti ``may be greater (now) than at any time in its recent history.'' Mrs. Pascal Trouillot, 43, a widow and one of only a handful of female judges in Haiti, was a Justice of the Supreme Court when selected by a coalition of opposition leaders to fill the post vacated by Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril on March 10 amid growing violence and unrest. She said her main task would be to organize an election in order ``to pass power to a democratically elected government chosen with complete liberty.''

Assault-style AK-47 rifles are being manufactured for the first time by an American company that is getting around the government's ban on imports of the weapon by producing some new parts. But the company's owner and president says he wants to get out of the business as soon as he recoups the money he lost when the government cut off imports of the semiautomatic weapons last summer. ``There's no money in the firearms manufacturing market,'' said E. Robert Jensen of Lathrop's Shooters Supply Inc. in Tucson, Ariz. ``I don't need to be in the manufacturing business. When I'm out seven figures because of an arbitrary action by the government, I'd like to get it back.'' Jensen said the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms had issued him permits to import several thousand AK-47s from China before he contracted to buy them. But before they arrived, the government banned the imports and the Customs Service refused to release the guns to him, he said.

Americans, accustomed to watching presidents and members of Congress on television, will get their first televised look at federal judges at work next year. The U.S. Judicial Conference, which sets policy for the federal courts, approved on Wednesday a carefully controlled and limited plan to permit TV cameras to record and broadcast civil trials in a handful of federal courtrooms. The three-year experiment will begin in July, limited to two federal appeals courts and six trial courts. Judges who volunteer their courtrooms for the plan will have almost total control over what the public sees. Rep. Robert W. Kastenmeier, D-Wis., who has been urging approval of the experiment, hailed the Judicial Conference action as a step toward promoting public understanding of the court system.

Israeli agents had detailed information about plans to bomb a U.S. Marine barracks in Lebanon in 1983 but gave the CIA only a vague warning about the attack in which 241 Americans were killed, a new book claims. The allegation is one of many by Victor Ostrovsky, a Canadian graphic artist who says he served for four years as an operative of the fabled Israeli spy agency, the Mossad. A New York court, at the Israeli government's request, on Wednesday issued a temporary order barring the publisher, St. Martin's Press, from distributing the book. The suit said information in the work could endanger the lives of Israeli agents. The 300-page book, ``By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer,'' was written in collaboration with Canadian journalist Claire Hoy. It purports to name many Mossad agents and supervisors as it describes in detail Ostrovsky's three-year training and many of the operations he heard about or in which he was involved.

Peru's new president says Washington can keep the millions in military aid it's offering to step up the war on cocaine trafficking. He wants cash to get farmers to stop growing coca and for highway construction so alternate crops can make it to market. Because the aid package ``is destined only for the fight against drug trafficking, we are not going to sign this agreement,'' President Alberto Fujimori said Wednesday night. His statement appeared to torpedo any hope his 6-week-old government will accept the $35.9 million in military aid Washington is offering this year to fight the cocaine trade. Peru could use the money. The country is reeling from the effects of tough austerity measures aimed at curbing 3,000 percent annual inflation.

It's crunch time in New York's newspaper wars and thousands of jobs and some long journalistic traditions hang in the balance. The economy, combined with the competition, is threatening two of the city's tabloids. The no-holds-barred New York Post, which has suffered losses for years, says that the hemorrhaging must end and that it will shut down with Saturday's edition unless its unions agree to more than $19 million in concessions. At the money-losing Daily News, months-long labor negotiations appear stalemated. Management has made extensive preparations for a strike. The unions continue working but are urging advertisers to boycott the paper.

DOC.HEAD: Bay Area Band Riding Success of Second Album
DOC.TEXT: When the Bay Area-based Tony Toni Tone talks about a revival, the band's not flashing back to the 1960s, high times in the Haight, or the Jefferson Airplane. These guys were infants in the ``Summer of Love,'' and they don't play any laid-back hippie music. ``What we're talking about on the revival tip is a couple of things. One is the revival of old sounds, acoustic instruments. There's too much of machines these days. We wanted to bring the acoustic sounds back,'' said vocalist Dwayne Wiggins, 23. ``And it's the revival of Tony Toni Tone. We controlled everything on this album: writing, producing. That means a lot to us.'' Not surprisingly, the Tonys' second album came to be titled ``Revival.'' It's already revived the sales which brought their debut LP, ``Who?,'' to the top of the charts; ``Who?'' sold more than 700,000 copies and had three No. 1 singles on the black charts. Their first single off album No. 2, ``The Blues,'' went top five as well. Mighty impressive work by the funky six-piece band, none of whom are named Tony. They are, instead, guitarist-vocalist Dwayne and his singing brother, Ray; drummer Timothy Christian; bassist Elijah Baker; and keyboardists Antron Haile and Carl Wheeler. While ``Revival'' is not about the '60s, there's a bit of the '70s in there. ``Oakland Stroke'' pays homage to Sly Stone, while ``Whatever You Want'' echoes Earth, Wind & Fire. If there's a bit of the past in this band's current funk, blame on on their upbringing, says Wiggins. ``That wasn't purposely. It's something we inherited, growing up influenced by certain musicians,'' he said. ``Motown, definitely. James Brown, Ohio Players _ I like that kind of stuff. Barry White _ that big bottom sound.'' The band's name came from a childhood expression among the members for ``looking good.'' Its biggest break came from a man with an inherited ear for music: Ed Eckstine, son of the brilliant Billy Eckstine, who helped the group get a recording contract. So how does the son of one of America's most influential jazz vocalists get an ear for funk? ``Ed's real sharp. He's part of the movement,'' said Wiggins, referring to the new Oakland-San Francisco music scene featuring M.C. Hammer, En Vogue and Digital Underground. ``He knows what's happening, and he's got a real open mind to all types of music. There's not too many people out there like him.'' Along with the music, the Tonys serve up some laughs. ``Revival'' opens with the sound of an old woman sitting quietly in a rocking chair. She breaks the reverie by asking, ``Is you gonna record another album?'' ``Yes, ma'am,'' the Tonys reply. ``Is it gonna be anything like the last album?'' she asks. ``No, ma'am,'' respond the Tonys. ``Oh, well. Let me take off my apron. The boys is back, y'all!'' Dwayne laughs even now when asked about it. ``That's just us joking on the mikes. A lot of the time when we were joking in the studios, we kept the mikes on, 'cause we had a lot of tracks to blow,'' Wiggins continued. ``We kept some of the stuff on the album.'' Up this fall for the band: a headling tour. An expanded line-up of Tonys, including a horn section and two back-up singers, will get out on the road. And more hit singles can be expected; Wiggins said the group would like to release five more. When the tour is done, a third album will follow. Rest assured it will be done in Oakland, just like the first two. ``I've seen other places, traveled and investigated, but I guess I'm just from Oakland. I've been here my whole life,'' said Wiggins. ``I'm staying, even with the earthquakes.'' Wiggins can't resist giving the needle to a caller from New York. ``Besides, we got the best baseball team out here. And Rickey Henderson,'' he said, laughing. Oakland Athletic's outfielder Rickey Henderson was traded last year by the Yankees to the ``Left Coast.'' He is the likely Most Valuable Player of the American League this year.

DOC.HEAD: Dividing Up the House: How It's Done
DOC.TEXT: Virtually every 10 years since this country was founded the nation has played musical chairs with seats in the House of Representatives. It's a process that has grown more complex with time and technology, marked this year by dueling computers. The Census Bureau pioneered the development of modern computers in its efforts to get Americans counted. And today, competing factions use the machines to pick apart Census results, seeking to squeeze out every bit of advantage to increase their political and financial standing. Americans are counted in every year that ends in a zero to make sure each state is fairly represented in the House. That's because the original compromise that allowed the nation to get started provided for states' representation to be equal in the Senate, while power in the House would be based on population. Divvying up the House seats sounds like a simple proposition: divide the number of people by the number of House seats and assign one seat to each group of that size. With 435 seats and a preliminary Census count of 245,837,683 for 1990, that would mean one House member for every 565,144 people. Of course, like most things in government, it doesn't work out that easily. To begin with, House seats are assigned to states _ a district can't be partly in one state and partly in another. That creates a problem, since the populations of individual states don't always divide up evenly by 565,144. In fact, Wyoming doesn't have nearly that many people. It will get a seat in the House anyway. Every state gets one. Indeed, the first thing that happens when reapportionment time comes is that one seat is assigned to each state. It's dividing up the remaining 385 seats that gets complicated. How to do this fairly has perplexed politicians since 1790, when Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton butted heads over the total number of seats and what to do when the number of people in the average district didn't divide evenly into the state population. Hamilton's plan prevailed in Congress and President Washington exercised the nation's first veto. When Congress couldn't override the veto, it passed Jefferson's plan. Officials of small states complained that Jefferson's plan discriminated against them, and in 1840 a plan devised by Daniel Webster was used. It awarded an additional seat to any state that had more than half of a district population left over after all seats had been divided up. While various other methods were used over the years, Congress avoided taking representatives away from some states and shifting them to other states by the simple expedient of increasing the size of the House every 10 years. In general, the number of seats was increased to whatever level was needed so that states that grew could gain seats without other states losing seats. From 1850 to 1900, a plan devised by Samuel F. Vinton of Ohio was used. But it was abandoned after a mathematical problem was found called the Alabama Paradox. It was discovered that increasing the size of the House caused Alabama to lose a seat. A more refined system called the Method of Major Fractions was used in 1910. Eventually, it became obvious that the House would one day become so large as to be unmanageable and in 1913 House membership was fixed at the current 435 seats. But disagreement over the method to be used prevented any redistricting after the 1920 Census. The Method of Equal Proportions was adopted in 1930 and is still used. That means today, when any state adds people and gains a new seat, some other state has to lose one. Here's how it works: A set of priority values is developed for each of the 385 remaining seats, and those values are multiplied by each state's population. That gives population-leading California the highest priority for the next available seat, followed by New York and so forth. This year it looks like California will wind up with 52 seats, New York with 31 and so on, down to Wyoming, Alaska, Delaware, Montana, North and South Dakota and Vermont, whose populations are so small that all 385 seats are gone before they get a second one. Assigning the seats to states becomes a fairly straightforward task when the formula and populations have been programmed into computers. It gets tougher afterward, though, as politicians and their consultants try to draw lines within the states to organize those seats. Each side tries to improve the chances of getting candidates from his or her party elected without being so obvious about it that a court throws the plan out. That will occupy state legislators and their computers for much of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Graham Kerr Back on TV 19 Years After `Galloping Gourmet'
DOC.TEXT: Picture, if you can, the Galloping Gourmet gone so spartan in the kitchen that his own family quit speaking to him over dinner. That was a low point in the culinary and spiritual odyssey that has led Graham Kerr back to television 19 years after the wildly successful series that made him famous. Along the way, a traffic accident nearly killed him and his wife, Treena, they spent two years sailing around the world with their children, they spurned TV and gave away their possessions in favor of aid to the poor and church work as born-again Christians, and Treena overcame alcohol and Valium addiction and survived a heart attack. Now, vowing never again to preach the ``rampant legalism'' that once banished pleasure from his kitchen, Kerr (rhymes with hair) is returning with a show under his own name, starting Monday on nearly 100 TV stations nationwide. ``We are the only show, I believe, that puts its food out to test in the audience on the show itself,'' he said. Judging by three of the 44 episodes produced by Treena at Seattle's KING Television, Kerr and his slimmed-down preparations pass the test handily. Gone are the long sideburns, omnipresent wine glass and classic concoctions oozing calories and cholesterol the Galloping Gourmet brought to households worldwide. Exuberant as ever at age 56, he now seeks to ``create a cloud of aroma and color and texture, and then steal into that cloud and steal away the fat and salt and sugar.'' His recipes are analyzed down to the fat level of lemon (9.31 percent) and the salt count of celery (4 milligrams per stalk) by a $7,000 computer and software from the University of Minnesota School of Public Health. When a recipe calls for wine, it's a wine without alcohol. ``I'm trying to provide a creative alternative for people who say, `I don't want to drink wine and drive home,' '' he said. He figures he spends about 11 hours converting a dish like quiche Lorraine into a healthier and _ he hopes _ even more tasty alternative for each half-hour show. Rice and parmesan cheese replace the rich quiche crust, one egg is used rather than three, and the amount of ham is cut from six ounces to two in favor of mushrooms, bell peppers, sun-dried tomatoes and ``lots of thyme and basil,'' he said. ``We are very clear: This quiche is not a quiche Lorraine,'' he said. ``Quiche (Lorraine) is absolutely deadly. Real men don't eat quiche because real men want to live beyond their 14th birthday.'' ``You'll find butter and beef, cream and eggs in my dishes, but they will all be pegged down about two-thirds,'' he said. A native of London, Kerr was born to well-established hotel operators and trained from age 15. He held the rank of captain and served as catering adviser during a five-year stint in the British army. In 1958, Kerr moved to New Zealand, where he was named chief catering advisor for the Royal New Zealand Air Force. At the order of his senior officer, he began appearing on TV. He left the service, launched a cooking show in Australia and moved to Canada, where he hit the big time with 440 episodes of ``The Galloping Gourmet'' from 1969 to 1971. Witty, amusing and sometimes outrageous, Kerr eventually reached 200 million viewers around the world each week. He sold $4 million worth of books, including the ``Galloping Gourmet TV'' series, ``The Graham Kerr Cookbook'' and ``The Complete Galloping Gourmet Cookbook.'' As producer, Treena won two Emmy nominations. Then a vegetable truck piled into their on-location vehicle outside San Francisco. While they recuperated, the family sailed more than 24,000 miles aboard a 71-foot sailboat. Their personal life disintegrated. Treena was hooked on Valium and two of his three children on alcohol and drugs. The success of a four-minute show, ``Take Kerr,'' grew increasingly hollow and he abandoned it. That was when their maid converted the couple to the Pentecostal faith. Over the next decade, the Kerrs lived in Colorado, Hawaii and Oregon, working in Christian outreach programs, then settled in Tacoma, Wash., in 1981. Always the primary cook at home, Kerr went from reveling in each new taste sensation to banning one food after another from the household. ``Salami, chocolate ... even bran cereal, when I found out it was about 40 percent sugar. My poor family suffered,'' he said. ``I mean, can you imagine, I was preaching to a 7-year-old child about colon cancer.'' ``It was horrible,'' Treena said. ``The kids would whisper about sneaking out to McDonald's.'' Finally, the family stopped talking to him at the table. ``That got to me,'' he said, ``so I started to build back the enjoyment factor in my family (cooking), and my family started talking to me again.'' The final ingredient of Kerr's culinary rebirth was Treena's 1986 heart attack, adding a personal incentive to wring as much fat, salt and sugar out of his recipes as possible. ``Eating is a celebration,'' he said. ``We've got it with bells on. Why don't we enjoy it to the max, but without risk?''

Elsewhere in television ... THE THINNEST BLUE LINE: ``Blue Helmets: The History of United Nations Peacekeeping,'' a 90-minute documentary airing tonight on PBS, examines the noble aspirations and sometimes rocky history of U.N. peacekeeping efforts. The program, narrated by Jesse Jackson, chronicles the U.N. forces' historic role as buffer between adversaries in the Congo, Cyprus and Namibia, as well as in the Middle East. U.N. forces, distinctive in their blue helmets, historically have operated with restrictions on the use of their weapons. ``All you've got really is the kindness in your eyes and the tone of your voice,'' as one puts it.

DOC.HEAD: Restored Disney Classic Returns to the Screen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Fantasia'' opens Oct. 5.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Leopold Stokowski's hands carve the air, yellow and pink lights illuminating his every move as he brings Bach's ``Toccata and Fugue in D Minor'' to visual life. Soon, he and the orchestra disappear, replaced by clouds, abstract lines, shifting shapes and beams of light. It is ``absolute music,'' we are told in the opening moments of Walt Disney's animated tribute to classical music, ``Fantasia.'' And this autumn, Stokowski will once again shake hands with Mickey Mouse as a restored version of the 1940 classic plays on movie screens throughout the United States. The film, two years in restoration, will have its gala premiere Sept. 21 in Philadelphia as a benefit for The Curtis Institute of Music, a tuition-free conservatory for exceptionally gifted young musicians. Already showing in Europe, the film is scheduled for general release in the United States on Oct. 5. ``Fantasia'' was revolutionary when it appeared, and today remains a landmark blend of cinema and music, largely because of the collaboration of Disney and Stokowski, the legendary conductor of The Philadelphia Orchestra. Disney had tinkered with synchronization of cartoons and music as early as 1929 in ``The Skeleton Dance,'' the first of his more than 70 ``Silly Symphonies.'' He first approached Stokowski with the idea of recording Dukas' ``The Sorcerer's Apprentice'' and animating it. The plan grew into a concert of eight classical works narrated by Deems Taylor, a popular composer and radio broadcaster. The animated vignettes begin with abstract designs swaying to Bach, and shift to fireflies, mushrooms, flowers, fish and thistles in Tchaikovsky's ``The Nutcracker Suite.'' Mickey puts on his master's cap and instructs brooms to carry water, then loses control of them in ``The Sorcerer's Apprentice.'' Moments after the vignette, Mickey's silhouette shakes hands with Stokowski at the podium. Dinosaurs act out the origin of the Earth to the strains of Stravinsky's ``The Rite of Spring.'' Fauns, centaurs and a drunken Bacchus populate Mount Olympus in Beethoven's ``Pastoral Symphony.'' A tutu-clad hippopotamus is the star of Ponchielli's ``Dance of the Hours,'' performing a graceful _ and funny _ pas de deux with a crocodile. The vignette includes other dancing hippos, crocodiles, elephants and ostriches. Evil and the profane meet the forces of goodness and light in Mussorgsky's ``Night on Bald Mountain,'' and Schubert's ``Ave Maria'' ends the film on a pious note, as a processional is reflected in a pool of water. The original soundtrack was recorded in April 1939 by The Philadelphia Orchestra under Stokowski at the Academy of Music. Nearly half the orchestra's members are graduates of The Curtis Institute, and The Walt Disney Co. thought Philadelphia would be the appropriate city in which to have the first showing of the restored version. To restore the film, Disney used modern film stock and improved lenses to extract more detail and color from the original nitrate negative than seen in versions released a half century ago. In a version of ``Fantasia'' shown in theaters in 1982 and 1985, the soundtrack was by studio musicians. The new version not only restores the Philadelphia Orchestra, but recreates Stokowski's vision for a ``Fantasound'' soundtrack that distributed sound throughout the theater in the days before stereo and digital sound. The film originally traveled with a complex system of up to 135 speakers to which the sound had to be switched manually. It later showed in theaters with a simpler, mono soundtrack. The music, however, was never uniformly popular with critics, many of whom considered Stokowski's treatment of Beethoven and Bach as verging on sacrilege. Some of Disney's caricatures have been criticized for being overly cute, and the only black animated characters are servants for Bacchus. But Stokowski saw the film as a pioneering development. ``We who with Walt Disney made `Fantasia' think of it not as perfect or final, but as the beginning of a new art form,'' he wrote in 1940. ``Our aim was to make use of all the most recent scientific developments in recording and reproducing music, methods that seemed to us helpful in making music more eloquent, and so be of greater service to all those who enjoy music.'' Much of the effort was to make the music flow around moviegoers as if they were in a forest listening to birds all around them instead of in a theater, Stokowski wrote. ``What people will be hearing probably hasn't been heard since 1941, the actual `Fantasound,' the way it was intended to be heard,'' said Terry Porter, who headed the sound restoration for Disney. ``It's quite dynamic, even by today's standard of films.'' He used Stokowski's handwritten notes, old blueprints and 1940s journals to direct the music through modern theater sound systems. He estimated 3,000 pops and hisses were removed from the soundtrack. ``We really tried to keep the music to its original integrity,'' he said. ``We didn't want to mess with the original sound. If in removing a pop we would hurt the sound, we left the pop in.'' Similar care was taken to adhere to the original visual images in restoration, said Pete Comandini, vice president of engineering for Y.C.M. Laboratories, which did the work under the direction of Disney's Leon Briggs. Original negatives were rescued from Disney vaults for all but about 15 minutes of the film, Comandini said. Each frame was individually examined and cleaned. ``This dirt, being on there for 50 years, some of it was quite stubborn and had to be cleaned by razor blade,'' he said. The restorers' mandate was to make no modifications. ``It was a big jigsaw puzzle putting everything together, making sure everything fit to the exact frame as it originally was,'' Comandini said. Finally, the color was balanced and approved by the studio. ``The picture is quite a bit sharper,'' he said. ``The colors are quite nice and rich and saturated. There's a lot of detail in there that's subtle and probably hasn't been seen since it was released.'' The Curtis Institute hopes to raise $100,000 from the benefit screening of ``Fantasia,'' to be used toward a three-year $5.2 million fund drive, said James McClelland, Curtis' development director. The institute was founded in 1924 by Mary Louise Curtis Bok in memory of her father, Cyrus H.K. Curtis, founder of Curtis Publishing Co. The school counts conductor Leonard Bernstein, composer Samuel Barber and pianist Peter Serkin among its graduates. This fall, 164 students from the United States and 13 foreign countries are expected to study with the school's 76-member faculty. The institute is tuition free, so students are admitted based on their musical talents.
