DOC.HEAD: Secret Industry Helps Make Food Palatable
DOC.TEXT: From high-tech chicken pot pies to powdered soft drinks, a super-secret world is at work on much of our food. The flavor industry replaces the savor we destroy, making a TV dinner taste less like cardboard. ``In processing food to get it into the form people want or to make it safe, flavor is processed out,'' said Bob Pellegrino, general manager at Cincinnati-based Fries & Fries, one of the nation's largest flavor producers. Grandma went to her garden or market for fresh produce hours before preparing and serving it. But we've come to expect food to wait months in warehouses and on store shelves, before it's popped into a microwave oven to be ready to eat in seconds _ and to still taste as good as grandma's. To a surprising degree, it does, thanks to flavorists who have created an estimated $750 million-a-year industry that helps make the food we eat palatable. Flavorists usually are chemists who have spent several years learning to identify and duplicate natural flavors. Many say then can discern thousands of flavors, nuances such as the difference between the part of an apple near the skin and the part near the core. The flavorist's challenge is to restore natural flavors, no matter what modern processing, packaging, storage and cooking have done to them. America's changing lifestyle means that food processors have to compensate for flavor that used to be provided by animal fats, cream and other high-cholesterol foods that don't fit into our diet-conscious lives. ``There are a few words that are driving our industry _ light, or low-fat; natural; and convenient,'' Pellegrino said. Flavoring agents are pervasive. Dairy products, bakery goods, desserts and beverages of all kinds are laced with flavorings. Just about every package in your pantry lists flavoring as an ingredient. Because ingredients are listed in descending order by weight, flavoring is last because it comprises less than one-half of 1 percent of the weight of the product _ sometimes just a few parts per million. ``That means 100 pounds of flavoring makes more than 20,000 pounds of product,'' Pellegrino said. Liquid flavoring rolls out of his plant in 55-gallon drums and powders in 10,000-pound lots. The flavor-making industry is secretive and clannish, Pellegrino said. A food company that markets its brand has a proprietary interest in the way its pot pie, pudding or potato chip tastes and doesn't want anybody else to produce that flavor. ``There's a high level of trust between the flavor company and the food and beverage company,'' Pellegrino said. ``Service and confidentiality are important. We'd be out of business pretty quickly if we said we were flavoring this or flavoring that.'' He refuses to identify any brand that uses his products. But he says Fries & Fries and a competitor, International Flavors and Fragrances Inc., are among the nation's largest, each handling about 10 percent of the industry's business, or upward of $50 million a year. There are about 100 flavor companies in the United States, and about 80 of them belong to the Washington, D.C.-based Flavor and Extract Manufacturers Association, said Earl Klinger, the group's administrator. The association refuses to acknowledge any ranking among the industry's companies or the volume of the business. ``We really do not know for certain,'' Klinger said. ``It's not legally possible to patent, copyright or otherwise protect a formula for a flavor, so the only way one company can maintain a competitive advantage is to keep it a secret. ``I've heard all sorts of figures, and we really have no way of knowing.'' Flavorists like to say they can reproduce a flavor from taste the way some musicians play songs by ear. In practice, they usually start by analyzing the chemical content of a food by using a gas chromatograph and listing the ingredients. Then they recreate flavors in the laboratory, altering them any way they choose by, for example, making a fruit drink taste riper, sweeter or more tart. There might be 500 components in any flavor, and it is the distinctive formulation of those components that makes one brand of soft drink taste different from another brand. ``This is very much a self-policed industry, although we work in partnership with the Food and Drug Administration,'' Pellegrino said. Flavoring ingredients come from the FDA's ``Generally Recognized As Safe'' list, and many flavors are recreated from chemicals that occur naturally to produce the flavor being enhanced, he said. Ruth Weisheit, supervisor of consumer affairs at the FDA's Cincinnati office, said flavorings are regulated as food additives. ``Any new flavorings or new uses of a flavoring agent would require FDA testing to make sure it is safe.'' Under the 1938 food labeling act, artificial flavorings can be listed as flavoring without identifying individual ingredients, Ms. Weisheit said. ``One of the reasonings . . . is that a flavoring agent can contain literally hundreds of ingredients, and it would be almost impossible to have a label large enough to list all of them,'' she said. Not all flavorings are used in food, Ms. Weisheit noted. They are in cough syrups, lipstick, mouthwash and drug products. Flavorings are widely used throughout the beverage industry, from soft drinks and powdered mixes to liqueurs such as peach schnapps and apricot brandy. A bigger challenge is making flavor additives that stand up to processing, especially microwave cooking, which tends to distort traditional flavors, especially in meat and bakery products. ``When you bake a cake, a lot of the flavor comes from the baking process, and you just don't get that from a microwave,'' Pellegrino said. There is no char-broiled flavor in a microwaved hamburger, without a flavor assist. Sometimes, a laboratory-created flavor that's good for one item is bad for another because of the way texture, aroma and flavor are affected by cooking or the preservatives necessary to prolong shelf-life. ``In beverages, you don't want the flavor to linger, but you do want it in low-fat ice cream,'' Pellegrino said.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Enter `Brave New World' of Spud Manipulation
With BC-EXP--Flavor Makers, b0947
DOC.TEXT: As Idaho's famous potato enters the 21st century, it may be dressed with something more than the same old sour cream and chives _ a new genetic identity. Scientists at the University of Idaho's Aberdeen Research and Extension Center are taking the first steps toward weaving new genes into the potato's molecular tapestry. Their super spud would have enhanced consumer appeal, increased grower profitability and reduced environmental impact. ``The potato is going to change. It's changing now,'' said Bill Belknap, a plant physiologist with the USDA's Agricultural Research Service. The tuber of the future will be rugged. It will ward off viruses and bruises, withstand drought and even carry natural toxins to kill the insects used to feasting on it. ``We're trying to alter the genetic makeup and still make it normal in all other respects,'' said Dennis Corsini, a research plant pathologist in Aberdeen. ``It's all designed to produce a crop more efficiently.'' The idea of genetically altered food may make consumers leery. But done successfully, it could put the potatoes currently lost to insects and disease on the dinner table. Although genetic alterations are fairly new for Idaho's No. 1 crop, they have been conducted for some time on plants like tomatoes or tobacco. Because the commercial end of the spud, the tuber, is produced on an annual cycle, the researchers have only one chance each year to transform and then review it. ``It's terrifying,'' Belknap said. ``Spring comes whether you're ready or not. . . . You only get one shot per year.'' Belknap and colleagues _ ``gene jockeys,'' he calls them _ have added two additional ``marker'' genes this year to several varieties of potatoes. One resists a certain drug and the other contains a specific enzyme. They will not change the potato as much as show a genetic change has taken place. Belknap applies agro-bacteria containing the genetic signal to the host potato's tissue. The bacteria create a ``disorganized tissue,'' or gall, as the new genes meld with the plant's molecular DNA ladder. ``The genes it puts in are so cute, you wouldn't believe it,'' Belknap said. ``It's how Mother Nature does it.'' If the initial experiments turn out well this year, Corsini and research geneticist Joe Pavek will cross the altered plants, called ``constructs,'' with standard varieties like Aberdeen's Lemhi Russet in 1991. Then the new hybrids will be tested for quality and yield characteristics. Researchers will then start tinkering to improve their stamina in the field and storage bin. One identified gene could make the potatoes resistant to black spots, those ugly bruises beneath the skin. Other genes would fight soft rot or leafroll virus. Potatoes could even be designed to accommodate the droughts plaguing the West. Yet another gene would create a toxin fatal to the Colorado potato beetle. Coast producers now spray their fields five times a year to combat it, Corsini said. Other potato problems are harder to eradicate, Belknap said. It would require an extensive genetic overhaul to prevent ``sugar end,'' or the migration of carbohydrates to one end of the tuber. French fry producers reject those potatoes because the sugar turns dark brown when it hits the cooking oil. But success could mean the demise of Idaho's world-renowned baker _ the Russet Burbank that makes up 40 percent of the potato acreage in the country. It is pollen-sterile and cannot be used as a parent plant, so it probably will not be genetically crossed, and someday a potato boasting super genes could take its place on top of the heap. The Agriculture Department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service oversees the tests and requires a long paper trail of applications before permits are granted.

DOC.HEAD: Profs Say Hebrews Beat Columbus to America
DOC.TEXT: Two professors say carbon dating of wood fragments and other evidence found a century ago in an ancient tomb in Tennessee prove Hebrews sailed to America centuries before Columbus. But the professors are having little success convincing other scholars. Cyrus Gordon, a former Dartmouth College professor of Judaic culture, proposed the theory in 1971 after studying inscriptions on a stone from the tomb. He believes the words are Old Hebrew for ``strong'' or ``strength'' and ``for Judea.'' Based on the way the letters are drawn, Gordon, an expert on epigraphy, the study of old writings, figures they had to be inscribed around A.D. 100. ``The . . . inscription is important because it is the first scientifically authenticated pre-Columbian text in an Old World script or language found in America,'' he wrote in a paper describing the finding. ``It proves that some Old World people not only could, but actually did, cross the Atlantic to America before the Vikings and Columbus.'' Frank Cross, a Semitic languages professor at Harvard University, is among the skeptics. The inscriptions, he said, ``don't fit any Paleo-Hebrew script that I know. Most of the signs are unrelated. A few have superficial similarities, but they don't go together for that period.'' ``Cyrus Gordon is the only scholar in the field of epigraphy that I know of who has taken the stuff seriously,'' he said. Gordon, of Brookline, Mass., stands by his findings. ``For any rational person to deny these facts, they have to deny not only the evidence of the inscriptions, they have to deny all the rules of scientific dating,'' he said. Gordon said brass bracelets from the tomb support his theory. They contain a zinc-copper alloy used by the Romans from A.D. 45 to 200, he said. Gordon said that for years, he talked little about his theory because he had no way to prove the artifacts were as old as he believed. He wanted to have the wood fragments carbon-dated, but the process wasn't advanced enough to work on such a small amount of wood. In 1979, with the advent of better testing methods, J. Huston McCulloch of Ohio State University began pestering the Smithsonian Institution, which had the artifacts, to have the wood carbon-dated. Finally, in 1988, McCulloch, an economics professor with an interest in epigraphy, got the Institute for the Study of American Cultures in Columbus, Ga., to pay for the dating. It established that the wood dated to somewhere between A.D. 32 and 769. Columbus sailed to the New World in 1492, while the Vikings landed in Newfoundland, Canada, sometime around 1000. McCulloch and Gordon theorize that Hebrew sailors were trying to escape Roman repression after one of two rebellions, the first ending in A.D. 73, the second in 135. Gordon believes the sailors landed in the southeastern United States, were forced inland because the coast was settled by American Indians and got as far as Loudon County, in eastern Tennessee, about 30 miles southwest of present-day Knoxville. The Bat Creek tomb was unearthed in 1889. It contained nine skeletons with the heads of all but one pointing north. Under the skull and jawbone of the south-pointing skeleton were several objects, including the inscribed stone. Gordon theorized the south-pointing skeleton was the leader of the settlement. McCulloch said the wood fragments probably were part of an earspool worn by the leader. Cyrus Thomas, who headed the Smithsonian team that unearthed the tomb, believed the stone inscriptions were done by Cherokee Indians. But Gordon said the shape of the lettering isn't consistent with Cherokee inscriptions. McCulloch published the carbon-dating results in the journal Tennessee Anthropologist, but they attracted little attention. ``There's been kind of a stony silence,'' he said. ``It's sort of been ignored.'' Mike Shoemaker, assistant editor of Biblical Archaeology Review in Washington, D.C., isn't surprised. Though he considers the Bat Creek findings the ``best example of pre-Columbian contact'' in America, Gordon's and McCulloch's work has been ignored because it runs contrary to accepted theories, Shoemaker said. ``It's mostly ignored because it's so controversial,'' he said. ``The prejudice about the idea that anyone came before Columbus is so enormous it's practically impossible to overcome.''

DOC.HEAD: Professor Invents Lifesaving High-Altitude Gamow Bag
DOC.TEXT: At 21,000-plus feet on Mount Everest, Courtney Skinner knew he was in trouble. Every breath he drew was painful, as if he had a crushed chest. The Pinedale, Wyo., outfitter knew his only chance was to breathe in large amounts of oxygen quickly to counter the liquid that nearly filled his lungs, a symptom of acute mountain sickness. ``I was very critical,'' he said. ``Under my own motivation, I had no more power.'' Skinner, a member of the 1988 Cowboys on Everest expedition, became one of the first mountain climbers to test the Gamow Bag, a pressurized bag resembling a human-size cigar tube that combats the effects of illnesses such as acute mountain and decompression sicknesses. After 11 hours of inhaling oxygen in the bag, Skinner emerged with his lungs 90 percent clear, and he was able to resume his ascent. His alternative would have been abandoning the expedition and being carried to a lower altitude for lifesaving oxygen treatments. High-altitude illnesses, such as acute cerebral edema and acute pulmonary edema, are caused by a lack of oxygen in the blood. Early symptoms include shortness of breath, fatigue, dizziness and nausea. In later stages, the sometimes-fatal illnesses cause fluid to fill the lungs or the brain. Mountain climbers long have known that the cure for high-altitude sicknesses is descent _ the lower the altitude, the more abundant the oxygen. But descent isn't always possible, particularly for climbers who are too ill to move, or if the weather is bad. The Gamow Bag gives the effect of lowering altitude 1{ miles by pumping fresh air into the pressurized chamber. Zipped inside the bag, climbers fill their lungs with much-needed oxygen. ``When the pressure started, you could almost feel a warmth or a glow come over you,'' recalled Skinner. ``You were more comfortable, you weren't fighting for each breath.'' The bright red-and-yellow bag has been credited with saving about a dozen critically ill mountain climbers in the past three years, says its inventor, Igor Gamow, a professor at the University of Colorado. Now, he's looking at ways of using the bag to aid balloonists and pilots and even scuba divers suffering from decompression sickness. Gamow, who has a doctorate in biophysics and microbiology, recalled that a suggestion from Gary Ruggera, a former student, led to the development of the bag. ``He said, `Igor, if athletes can gain from the benefits . . . just think what would happen to mountain climbers,' '' Gamow recalled. At the time, Gamow was conducting high-altitude training tests on athletes who worked out on equipment inside an 8-foot pressurized bubble chamber. He fitted that technology into the portable bag, which weighs about 10 pounds. The spring of 1987 found Gamow stitching a length of polyurethane nylon on a sewing machine. ``It would take maybe two hours' sewing and 10 hours on your hands and knees sealing it with all sorts of sticky goop,'' he recalled. The first ``goop'' they used was a glue for repairing tennis shoes. Today, the bag, which is marketed by DuPont Corp., is sealed with a heat-seal process. It sells for $3,000. Ian D. Schokking, a volunteer physician at the Kunde Hospital in the 13,000-foot Sagamatha National Park in Nepal, wrote to Gamow this spring that the bag has saved the lives of at least two patients. ``Our location, and the expense of oxygen, makes your Gamow Bag the perfect technology for treating altitude illness within our treatment area, which extends two days' walk in four directions,'' Schokking wrote. After spending most of his life in research, Gamow is delighted with the turn his career has taken. He's traveled the world on behalf of his bag and makes annual educational trips to Nepal.

DOC.HEAD: Tot Born Deaf Is Learning To Hear
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old born deaf is learning to use an electronic device implanted in his ear to transmit sound and help him hear. Each time Bradley Drymon indicates he's heard a sound emitted from his therapist's computer, he thumps a blue box in front of him and a small, colorful ball of cereal rolls down a chute. He pops it into his mouth and waits for the next sound _ a beep. On June 28, the Sarasota tot had a tiny sound-transmitting electrode inserted into his ear canal during surgery at Tampa General Hospital. The surgery came one day after the Food and Drug Administration declared the procedure safe for children. The electrode, called a cochlear implant, replaces the natural sound-transmitting connection between the ear and the hearing nerve. The child didn't have that connection. After his incision healed, the three-part device had to be hooked up. He just started learning to use his electronic ear with the help of two audio therapists at the University of South Florida. ``It's going much better than expected,'' said Holly Skinner, a specialist who uses sign language to communicate with Bradley. She also dispenses the cereal. When Bradley first heard a beep, it was ``pretty traumatic,'' she said. ``He started crying and trying to rip off his head. We couldn't get him back in the room for an hour,'' Ms. Skinner said. The therapists work to tune the device so it will receive the volume and pitch the boy can hear. By watching his reactions, they determine the softest volume he can hear and the loudest he can stand. The 1{-inch wire winding in his ear has 22 electrodes, each of which picks up a variety of pitches and volumes. ``Every once in a while, his eyes will light up, and you'll know he's heard something,'' said his mother, Sylvia Drymon. ``He even picks up the beat on the radio.''
DOC.HEAD: Study Challenges Theory of Fifth, Sixth Forces of Nature
DOC.TEXT: The theory that more than four fundamental forces govern the universe is under attack again, this time from physicists who measured gravity inside holes drilled for nuclear weapons tests. The new study was published in the Sept. 3 issue of the journal Physical Review Letters by J. Thomas of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, and Peter Vogel of the California Institute of Technology. Physicists long believed there were four basic forces of nature: gravity; electromagnetism, which creates light, electricity, radio waves and microwaves; the strong force, which holds the centers of atoms together; and the weak force, which lets some atoms decay radioactively. But starting in 1985, a series of experiments raised the possibility there might be a fifth force, which slightly counteracts gravity, and a sixth force, which boosts gravity slightly. Those experiments were based on gravity measurements made inside a mine shaft, on a television tower, at the base of a cliff and in other locations. All the experiments found the strength of gravity differed slightly from what was predicted by Sir Isaac Newton's 300-year-old law of gravity. That law says the gravitational attraction between two objects decreases with the square of the distance between them. Thomas and Vogel analyzed gravity measurements made inside 10-foot-wide boreholes that extend down as much as 2{ miles at the Nevada Test Site, where U.S. nuclear warheads are detonated in underground tests. They found the strength of gravity at various depths in the holes also differed from what Newton's law predicted. While that might be interpreted as evidence for additional forces of nature, Thomas and Vogel came up with a much less exotic explanation: The measurements were flawed by variations in the density of rock surrounding the holes. Earlier experiments claiming to support existence of fifth and sixth forces of nature also are likely flawed by the same problem, they wrote. In 1988, a similar argument was made after gravity was measured inside drillholes in Greenland's ice sheet.
DOC.HEAD: More Evidence That Los Angeles Air Pollution Travels Far
DOC.TEXT: An industrial pollutant dumped into the Los Angeles Basin's smoggy air shows up one to two days later in Nevada and Arizona, a study says. Scientists traced the summertime movement of methylchloroform, an industrial solvent that helps deplete Earth's protective ozone layer and also contributes to global warming caused by the ``greenhouse effect.'' The chemical isn't produced by any natural source, allowing researchers to use it as an indicator of the path followed by manmade pollutants. They monitored levels of methylchloroform at Claremont in the Los Angeles Basin; at Cajon Pass, in the mountains above the basin; and at Spirit Mountain, Nev., and Meadview, Ariz., which are 185 miles and 250 miles northeast of the basin. The researchers found high methylchloroform levels in the Los Angeles Basin on weekdays, but low levels on weekends, when most industries that use it are closed. At the Nevada and Arizona sites, methylchloroform levels were highest Wednesday to Sunday, then lowest on Monday and Tuesday _ indicating a one- to two-day lag for wind to carry the pollutant from of the Los Angeles Basin. The study was conducted by Warren H. White and Edward Macias of Washington University in St. Louis; David Miller, David Schorran and Thomas Hoffer of the Desert Research Institute in Reno, Nev.; and David P. Rogers at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif. It was published in the July issue of the journal Geophysical Research Letters.
DOC.HEAD: Study Disputes Notion Volcanic Greenhouse Killed the Dinosaurs
DOC.TEXT: New research casts doubt on a theory that blames extinction of the dinosaurs on global warming caused by huge volcanic eruptions in what is now India. The study is part of the long-running debate on whether the demise of the dinosaurs and many other species about 66 million years ago was caused by an asteroid or comet striking Earth, by massive volcanic eruptions or by gradual climate change. Many supporters of the first two theories believe that either an asteroid or comet impact or large-scale eruptions could have kicked enough smoke and debris skyward to block out sunlight, plunging the Earth into a time of deadly cold. However, some volcano theory advocates argue that massive eruptions of basalt lava at India's Deccan Traps 66 million years ago could have emitted enough carbon dioxide to cause a ``greenhouse effect,'' trapping solar heat and making the climate too hot for dinosaurs and many other creatures. That theory was tested by Ken Caldeira of New York University's Earth systems group and Michael Rampino, who works for NYU and for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. They calculated the Deccan Traps eruptions _ similar to the floods of lava that produced the Pacific Northwest's Columbia River basalts _ couldn't have spewed out enough carbon dioxide to cause global warming and mass extinctions. The eruptions, occurring over several hundred thousand years, would have increased the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere by less than 75 parts per million, enough to raise global temperatures by less than 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit, Caldeira and Rampino estimated. ``This suggests that the . . . extinctions were not caused by drastic greenhouse warming resulting from carbon dioxide released during Deccan volcanism,'' they wrote in the August issue of Geophysical Research Letters.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Sept. 17

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Wish for More Oil Wells Might Get No Quick Response
DOC.TEXT: Companies that do most of the country's oil exploration say oil well investors need better tax incentives to meet President Bush's call for more production, but environmentalists are ready to fight any favors for the industry. Smaller oil companies, which do most of the exploratory drilling, say current taxes discourage investment in oil wells. But environmentalists who think conservation is the way to break America's dependence on foreign oil say they will oppose breaks for oil companies, particularly an opening of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska for drilling. ``It's clear that Bush cannot understand what conservation means. He still thinks it means freezing in the dark,'' said Dru Schmidt-Perkins, conservation analyst for the Energy Conservation Coalition in Washington. She was responding Wednesday to Bush's call for more oil production in a televised speech to Congress the night before. The president asked lawmakers to speed the development of oil reserves in Alaska and increase incentives for oil and gas exploration. The American Petroleum Institute said Bush's comments echoed some of what the industry has been asking for, but that doesn't mean Congress will go along. ``In general, he was saying what we would like to hear, because our industry is in the doldrums,'' said James Merna, spokesman for the Independent Petroleum Association of America. ``But he just didn't come up with the specifics.'' Environmental groups did not wait for specifics to blast Bush for indicating that oil companies should be allowed into the Arctic refuge, which is believed to contain the nation's largest untapped, on-shore reserve of crude oil. Ms. Schmidt-Perkins said Bush has a blind spot when it comes to conservation measures that would make more sense in the long run, such as requiring all cars to be made with greater fuel efficiency. Bush has opposed such a measure, and his calls for energy conservation have not been backed up with any concrete proposals for saving fuel, his critics point out. The Energy Department, expected to announce a new long-term energy plan toward the end of the year, reportedly has an inter-agency task force examining ways to boost development of renewable energy sources such as solar, wind and biomass. But Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said there was no indication from the president's speech that the administration was putting much emphasis in those areas. ``Never once did he mention renewable energy,'' Harkin said. The oil industry says more exploration is part of the answer to reducing America's addiction to overseas crude. But despite the rapid rise in oil prices that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, and the subsequent boycott of their oil, there has been no rush to find more oil. ``We'll have to look at prices today, plus what is a reasonable outlook for prices in two to five years and even longer,'' said Michael E. Thompson, a spokesman for Amoco Corp. ``Many of these projects are five- or 10- or 20-year projects.'' Major oil companies have not even been able to see yet what the Persian Gulf crisis will do to their earnings in the short run, he said. Smaller, independent oil companies drill about 85 percent of the nation's wells, according to IPAA, which represents smaller companies. Its members could use some tax breaks to get out of the economic slump that set in when the price of oil collapsed in the mid 1980s. Independent oil operators used to borrow cash for drilling, but many of the companies and the banks that loaned them money have now gone under, said Lloyd N. Unsell, acting president of IPAA. The number of independent producers has fallen from about 13,000 to 4,500 since the bust, and Unsell said tax incentives might be necessary before investors will decide to pump money into oil deals.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman's Son Sues Makers of Anti-depressant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT attribution.
DOC.TEXT: The son of a man who went on a shooting spree last year filed a lawsuit Wednesday against the makers of Prozac, saying the anti-depressant's side effects drove him to kill eight people. James T. Wesbecker, executor of Joseph Wesbecker's estate, filed the lawsuit in Jefferson Circuit Court. He seeks unspecified damages against Eli Lilly & Co. Inc., Dista Products Co. and his father's former psychiatrist, Dr. Lee Coleman. Lilly is an Indianapolis-based pharmaceutical company that manufactures Prozac, and Dista is a Lilly subsidiary. The lawsuit alleges that Lilly failed to adequately test Prozac and knew or should have known it wasn't safe for people to use to treat depression. It also alleges that Lilly failed to make known results of tests that the company possessed regarding the drug's adverse side effects, which, the lawsuit said, drove Joseph Wesbecker to commit ``homicide, suicide and assault.'' Wesbecker, carrying several semiautomatic weapons, fatally wounded eight people during a rampage at the Standard Gravure printing plant on Sept. 14, 1989, before killing himself. Five other parties involved in the shootings also filed lawsuits this week against Wesbecker's estate, Lilly and Coleman. Coleman has refused to discuss the case. Lilly spokesman Ed West noted that other drugs were found in Wesbecker's blood after his death. He also said more than 11,000 people participated in clinical testing of Prozac and more than 2 million patients worldwide have been treated with the drug in its 2{-year history. The company has previously said that fewer than 10 physical assaults and two murder-suicides have been reported among patients. ``Its safety and efficacy have been well-established through this extensive experience,'' West said.

The Congressional Budget Office predicted that 600 to 700 commercial banks will fail over the next 3{ years even without a recession, draining the government's deposit insurance funds by more than $20 billion. The projection Wednesday came just one day after a report that the government already is on the hook for at least $8 billion in as yet unreported losses from the collapse of Texas banks in the 1980s. The budget office assessment added to fears that banks, just like S&Ls, will require a multibillion-dollar taxpayer bailout.

Leaders of United Auto Workers union locals at General Motors Corp. facilities have been called to a meeting Monday in suburban Detroit, amid speculation that a national contract agreement may be near, local officials said. ``Why would they want us in Detroit if nothing's settled?'' Joe Garcia, secretary-treasurer of UAW Local 645 at GM's Van Nuys, Calif., plant, wondered Wednesday. A national UAW official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that while such a meeting could be called to discuss a strike, it was more likely that it would be used to describe details of a tentative contract.

Corroon & Black Corp., already planning to merge with fellow insurance broker Willis Faber PLC of Britain in a deal worth more than $750 million, received a higher cash offer from Aon Corp. Aon, the holding company for the insurance brokerage Rollins Burdick Hunter Group Inc., said Wednesday it would pay $40 a share, or about $804 million, for Corroon & Black.

A federal judge and a state judge called off a mass trial of 265 asbestos health liability cases after reaching out-of-court settlements in nearly all the claims. The cases resolved Wednesday stem from asbestos exposure at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard dating to the 1940s. They involved many severe illnesses and were viewed as a litmus test in a drive to clear court dockets nationwide of asbestos claims.

Farmers are harvesting a bumper corn crop estimated at a four-year high of 8.12 billion bushels, up 8 percent from last year's crop and 3 percent more than forecast a month ago, the Agriculture Department said. Last year's corn harvest was 7.53 billion bushels, and the department in its initial forecast Aug. 9 put this fall's harvest at 7.85 billion bushels. The September estimate of 8.12 billion bushels, made Wednesday, would be the largest corn output since 8.23 billion bushels were harvested in 1986.

ARCO Alaska Inc. and its parent company, Atlantic Richfield Co., will pay the state about $285 million under an agreement to settle part of a 13-year-old suit over oil royalties, Gov. Steve Cowper said. Alaska officials contend the state was shorted $902 million in royalties for oil from the Prudhoe Bay and Kuparuk River fields between 1977 and 1986. The state charged the oil companies often undervalued the North Slope crude, therefore paying the state less than it should have received. The settlement was announced Wednesday.

Lawmakers from energy-dependent states proposed legislation that would allow the president to prohibit unreasonable oil and gasoline price increases during a national emergency. The American Petroleum Institute, which represents the major oil industries, called the proposal Wednesday a thinly disguised effort to revive the price controls of the 1970s that led to long lines at gas stations. Under the proposal, the attorney general would have the power to investigate cases of alleged price gouging. Conviction could result in jail time and up to a $500,000 fine.

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said a plan for converting the Soviet Union to a market economy has been submitted simultaneously to the national parliament and those of the 15 republics. Gorbachev said Wednesday that the the entire country should be involved in this ``difficult choice.'' It was his first nationwide call for approval _ via the elected parliaments _ of a policy previously determined by the Communist regime's central government.

Moving to end allegedly unfair pricing by trans-Pacific shipping firms, the Federal Maritime Commission announced it has levied $20.5 million in penalties against nine companies. James J. Carey, the commission's acting chairman, said Wednesday the penalty settlement is by far the largest in the agency's 29-year history. The action is aimed at ending a practice in the shipping industry of filing tariffs with the commission, then privately paying rebates to attract cargo business.

The stock market advanced as traders kept watch on developments in the Middle East. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had drifted down 5.93 points in the week's first two sessions, rose 13.12 to 2,625.74. The dollar was mostly higher in New York after falling overseas. Treasury bond prices closed unchanged to slightly lower. Corn futures posted modest losses; soybean prices rose and wheat finished narrowly mixed; near-term cotton futures rose sharply; oil futures were mixed; precious metals advanced; cattle futures fell; and most pork futures rose.

DOC.HEAD: London's Market Is Star Performer During Gulf Crisis
Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The London stock market, typically a follower of New York and Tokyo, has managed to weather the Persian Gulf crisis better than its global rivals, key index figures show. Based on calculations over the six weeks of the Gulf standoff, London stocks are off 7.9 percent, compared with an 18.8 percent decline in Japan's key market index and a 10 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. Analysts said Wednesday that Britain has fared better because its shares were more realistically priced before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Britain also is the non-communist world's eighth largest oil producer, making its economy less vulnerable to oil supply disruptions and oil price hikes, they said. Stocks in Japan and West Germany, where the index has fallen 16.7 percent, had been particularly overpriced, analysts said. Both countries are heavily dependent on imported oil. West Germany also has suffered from the higher-than-expected costs of German unification, said Guenter Redeker, chief economist at Chemical Bank in Frankfurt. Fears that the crisis would seriously disrupt oil supplies sent oil prices soaring from below $20 a barrel to above $30. That heightened concerns about inflation, higher interest rates and recession, and sent stock prices plummeting worldwide. In addition to reflecting the performance of their component shares, stock indexes also are good barometers of economic expectations, which can affect economic performance itself. Trading volume has been low in the major markets during the global bear market, the analysts said. ``It's typical of (stock) markets generally that when they fall there tends to be relatively little turnover. It's characteristic in markets that when they are going up turnover tends to be higher than when they are going down,'' said Paul Turnbull, a British economist with the London investment firm Smith New Court PLC. Typically during times of turmoil, money goes on the move. Investors surprisingly haven't turned to the traditional safe havens of the U.S. dollar and gold, choosing the German mark instead. Redeker cited the attraction of relatively high German interest rates. Experts generally agree that the world's major industrialized nations are less vulnerable to ``oil shocks'' now than they were in the 1970s. ``We felt the U.K. should outperform,'' said Richard Kersley, an equity strategist at the London investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. ``It should continue and is justified.'' ``The U.K. had its feet more firmly on the ground in terms of what its expectations of the world were before the Gulf.'' The Gulf crisis has forced investors elsewhere to face up to poorer earnings prospects, which existed even before the invasion, Kersley said. Slowing economic growth and higher interest rates around the globe are to blame. ``Middle East developments have basically operated as a catalyst,'' Turnbull said. Values in Japanese and Germany, he said, ``needed to fall anyway and they still need to fall further.'' Britain stands to gain billions of dollars of extra oil revenue. The country, which is not a member of the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, produces some 2 million barrels a day in the North Sea. It has proven reserves about 4 billion barrels, according to the Paris-based International Energy Agency. However, higher oil prices likely will worsen Britain's already high inflation rate _ currently running just under 10 percent _ and likely delay a cut in its 15 percent interest rates. Here are how the four markets' main indexes have fared during the crisis: _ Britain's Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed at 2,142.3 Wednesday compared with 2,326.2 on July 31, a decline of 7.9 percent. _ The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial is off 10 percent from its July 31 close of 2,905.20. _ Germany's DAX index is off 16.7 percent at 1,598.34 from 1,919.1. _ Japan's Nikkei index of 225 stocks settled at 25,216.14 Wednesday from 31,036, a decline of 18.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached in Most Brooklyn Navy Yard Cases
DOC.TEXT: In an important settlement in the nation's biggest product liability issue, attorneys resolved almost all 265 asbestos lawsuits related to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, pleasing a judge who wants to clear court dockets nationwide. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein and New York state Supreme Court Justice Helen E. Freedman on Wednesday called off a joint trial in the cases, which stem from asbestos exposure at the old shipyard dating to the 1940s. The judges praised both sides for ``extraordinary efforts to dispose of these cases without expensive and time-consuming trials.'' Details on the amount of the settlements were not revealed. Weinstein has been leading an effort to reduce the nation's backlog of 90,000 asbestos lawsuits clogging state and federal courts. ``This is important to demonstrate that settlement of mass cases is possible,'' said Kenneth Feinberg, who was appointed by Weinstein in April to try to settle the cases out of court. Weinstein also is participating in the restructuring of the Manville trust, which handles some 130,000 pending settlement claims against Manville Corp. And he is overseeing creation of a class action to resolve lawsuits against asbestos manufacturers that cannot meet outstanding claims. In several court hearings in recent months, Weinstein has stressed the need for plaintiffs lawyers and defendant companies to reach out-of-court settlements. He also has criticized the amount lawyers have received for handling the cases. Asbestos trials routinely require redundant legal investigation of each claim of illness or death related to asbestos, the insulation material that was used widely at shipyards and other construction sites for decades. The Brooklyn trial had been expected to last six months. Attorneys in involved in the case said more than 200 of the 265 pending lawsuits had been settled. The judges said the remaining cases would proceed to trial separately in state and federal court, rather than in a joint trial. Settlement negotiations had whittled the number of Brooklyn Navy Yard cases down from 615 when Weinstein and Freedman announced consolidation into a single trial. Feinberg said negotiations would continue to resolve the remaining cases before opening arguments scheduled for next week. New York has been slow to resolve serious cases involving diseases such as lung cancer and other respiratory ailments because of a glitch in state law. Unlike most other states, New York's legislature had applied a statute of limitations that effectively prevented lawsuits against asbestos makers. Illness from inhaling asbestos fibers can take decades to appear, but the state had required suing close to the time of exposure. In 1986, the state lifted the ban, allowing claimants one year to file claims against asbestos manufacturers. Many of those claims, some of which were diagnosed as long ago as 20 years, only now are being resolved. The government shipyard in Brooklyn first opened in the 1780s and was known formally as the New York Naval Yard. Construction peaked during World War II, when 70,000 people worked there round the clock. The facility was ordered closed in 1964.

DOC.HEAD: Arby's Plans to Expand Program for Taking Payment by Credit Card
DOC.TEXT: Customers of company-owned Arby's restaurants will soon be able to pay for their sandwiches, shakes and fries with a credit card under a program the fast-food operator is launching with MasterCard International. Atlanta-based Arby's and other fast-food chains have been testing credit-card payment plans in specific markets for several years. But Arby's said Wednesday its move to take its program to all its company-owned stores would make it the first major fast-food chain to accept credit cards on a national scale. The company said it plans to start taking credit cards in early October at its company-owned stores in Portland, Ore., and later this year at company-owned stores in Toledo, Ohio; Salt Lake City, Utah; Memphis, Tenn., and West Palm Beach, Fla. In 1991, the program will be expanded to the other 17 cities where the company owns restaurants. There are 2,350 Arby's restaurants nationwide, but only 244 are owned by the company itself. The others are franchised and it is up to their owners whether to take credit cards. MasterCard and Arby's said they would spend $1 million over the next year to promote the program through advertising and signs in the stores. Rege Braun, director of research and development operations for Arby's Inc., said the company expects that by taking credit cards, sales will improve. In tests in about 100 Arby's restaurants in Cleveland, Pittsburgh, Phoenix and Youngstown, Ohio, the company found the average purchase with a credit card was $6 to $7 compared with an average of $3.80 for someone paying with cash. ``In many cases when you are using plastic, the natural tendency is to be freer with your money,'' Braun said. In addition, he said the chance to pay with a credit card could attract customers who may otherwise go home because they had too little cash to feed the family or go to a more expensive restaurant that accepts credit cards. Braun said that while the marketing campaign will mention only MasterCard, Arby's also intends to accept Visa credit cards. Jody Hancock, a MasterCard executive responsible for new market development, said the company is involved in similar test programs with seven of the top 10 fast-food restaurant chains, but that Arby's is the first to begin expanding nationally to all its company-owned stores. She said the system will use a payment technology that will allow customers to pay for their food in seconds without having to sign a receipt slip. The store owner will pass the card through a monitor that will screen out stolen or invalid cards in less time that it would take to pay cash and get change, she said. She said MasterCard has been intent on positioning itself as ``the best card for mainstream America'' and hopes to get movie houses, parking lots and convenience stores to begin accepting the credit cards as well. MasterCard is accepted at 8.2 million locations around the world, she said.

DOC.HEAD: After-Hours Plan Responds to Competition, But Not Everyone Happy
DOC.TEXT: Two after-hours trading sessions mark the New York Stock Exchange's first decisive response to eroding market share and competing technology in the United States and abroad, but not everyone is happy. Experts said the move risks alienating the NYSE's powerful specialists but is necessary to lure back large amounts of institutional stock trading that has defected to foreign markets, particularly London. ``The exchange is really trying to speed up the introduction of new technology and is using this after-hours trading as a way of getting it done,'' Hans Stoll, a finance professor at Vanderbilt University's graduate management school, said Wednesday. ``I view it as a political way to introduce things that some of the membership finds unpalatable,'' he said. The NYSE Tuesday announced sessions that would last until 5 p.m. and 5:15 p.m., beyond the market's normal 4 p.m. close. The sessions, designed for trading by large institutions and not individual investors, will provide much-desired trading anonymity now available in some foreign markets and on competing private networks in this country. ``It's an effort to both modernize and deal with the realities of the global trading system,'' said Jeffrey Tabak, a principal in the New York program trading firm Miller, Tabak Hirsch & Co. The London market, which is entirely electronic with no trading floor or specialists monitoring trades, is used widely by big institutions that conduct computerized program trades typically involving thousands of shares at once. In the week of Aug. 20-24, for instance, 16.4 percent of all program trading activity was conducted on foreign markets, exchange statistics show. Overall, the percentage of trades in NYSE-listed stocks handled by the Big Board slipped to 69 percent last year from about 85 percent in 1980. The NYSE plan would try to staunch some of that lost business. During the two after-hours trading periods, known as ``crossing sessions,'' buyers and sellers of stocks would be matched electronically. The sessions could start later this year pending Securities and Exchange Commission approval. They would bypass the NYSE floor specialists, who regulate trading, for the first time in the exchange's 198 years. The exchange envisions some night trading in 1991 with 24-hour trading by the year 2000 if members want it. Experts said declining revenue and new technology growth has pushed the Big Board into after-hours trading. Antagonizing specialists has long been a fear for the NYSE and their reaction was predictably chilly. ``It is a far cry from trading as anyone knows it,'' said one floor specialist who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It is a feeble response to the perceived competitive threat.'' The first after-hours session would run from 4:15 p.m. to 5 p.m. Traders would be able to enter into the exchange's computer system orders to buy or sell stock or orders in which buyers and sellers already are matched. At 5 p.m., the exchange would attempt to match and execute orders. Unmatched trades would be returned to customers. All orders would be executed at closing prices and trading in a company's stock would be halted for the session if any news developed affecting its price. The second session is designed to recapture program trading now done in London. It would last from 4:15 p.m. to 5:15 p.m. and would continue regardless of news developments. That session is expected to be crucial to big Wall Street program traders such as Morgan Stanley & Co., PaineWebber Inc. and Kidder, Peabody & Co., which regularly trade after hours in London. The most common of such trades now conducted in London involve converting stock-index futures contracts into the underlying stocks by selling the contract to a broker, who sells the shares to an investor. Stock-index futures are contracts based on market indexes such as the Standard & Poor's 500. The NYSE hopes to erase the factors that make London attractive. London's advantages include relaxed disclosure requirements, guaranteed execution of trades, no limitations on trading and cheaper costs. Under current Big Board rules, each part of a program trade involving a market index must be conducted separately with all stocks traded at current market prices. The new rules would allow an aggregate trade with prices based on the index level. Closing prices of individual stocks are not expected to be changed by the new sessions, but some market data will be affected. The NYSE said trading volume from the first session will be incorporated into the day's individual stock volumes and total volume. Volume and the total dollar value of trading in the second session will be reported separately. There will be no public disclosure of participants in the trades in either session, the exchange said, but NYSE regulatory guidelines will apply to the new trading.

DOC.HEAD: Global Survey Finds Consumers Rate Coca-Cola As Strongest Brand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Coca-Cola touts itself as the real thing in its advertising, and consumers worldwide appear to have bought that line. The soft drink finished ahead of Sony, Mercedes-Benz and about 6,000 other brands in a new survey by the image consulting firm Landor Associates. The San Francisco-based marketing firm interviewed about 10,000 people in the United States, Japan and Western Europe, asking them to rate brands according to how familiar they were and how highly they thought of them. Trailing the top three brands in the global rankings were Kodak, Disney, Nestle, Toyota, McDonald's, IBM and Pepsi-Cola, according to the survey results released Wednesday. Twenty-three of the top 50 brands in the global survey are from the United States, 17 are European, nine are Japanese and one is from a company based in the United States and Europe. Coca-Cola had led a similar Landor survey conducted in late 1988. Coca-Cola also was rated the most powerful brand among U.S. consumers and among European consumers when results for those groups were compiled separately. Sony was rated as the most powerful among Japanese consumers. Don Casey, president of Landor Associates, said the results demonstrated the importance of establishing an identity and sticking with it over the years. ``The guys who have paid their dues and have a consistent image have done quite well,'' he said. Casey said the results also indicate a contrast between realistic American tastes and the high aspirations of non-American consumers. On the U.S. list, Coca-Cola was followed by Campbell's, Disney, Pepsi-Cola, Kodak, NBC, Black & Decker, Kellogg's, McDonald's and Hershey's. The top 10 lists for European and Japanese consumers included brands such as Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Porsche and Rolls Royce.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Clears Way for Hearing on Bush's S&L Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A judge has cleared the way for a public hearing in the government's savings and loan case against Neil Bush, and Bush's attorney says ``the swords are drawn.'' An administrative law judge has denied Bush's request to dismiss the regulators' case against him for alleged conflict of interest in his role as a former director of a collapsed Colorado thrift. Judge Daniel J. Davidson rejected Bush's petition in an order issued Tuesday. The Office of Thrift Supervision, which is seeking to bar the president's son from working for any bank or savings and loan, made Davidson's decision public late Wednesday. Bush, 35, was an outside director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that failed in late 1988 at a cost to taxpayers estimated at $1 billion. In written arguments submitted to Davidson late last month, Bush said there was no possibility that he could continue the alleged abuses since Silverado already has been taken over by the government. Bush continued to deny any wrongdoing. The judge, in a one-page order, rejected Bush's argument, saying it was not supported by existing regulations or case law. ``The next step is to go to the hearing,'' Bush's attorney, James Nesland, said Wednesday from his Denver office. ``The swords are drawn.'' Davidson's decision clears the way for a public hearing that had previously been scheduled before the judge starting Sept. 25 in Denver. Sometime after the hearing, the judge is expected to make a recommendation to the director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, Timothy Ryan. In its response to Bush's request, the thrift agency had told Davidson in a brief filed Monday that Bush could become a director at another financial institution and repeat the conduct that harmed Silverado. ``Indeed, throughout these proceedings (Bush) has evidenced no willingness to consider that he has done anything wrong, nor even any understanding that he ever had potential conflicts of interest,'' the agency's brief said. The Office of Thrift Supervision said it was clear that Bush's conduct ``was contrary to generally accepted standards of prudent operation'' and could cause harm to any financial institution if continued. The regulators have accused Bush of conflict of interest for not disclosing his business ties to two big Silverado borrowers, developers Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters. Bush also could be a target of a negligence lawsuit that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering filing against him and other former Silverado directors. Bush and Nesland have maintained that the regulators' actions are politically motivated.

DOC.HEAD: Henkel, Ecolab Announce Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Ecolab Inc. and the West German chemical company Henkel KGaA plan to merge their European sanitizing and cleaning businesses, the two companies said. Under the joint venture announced Wednesday, Henkel would gain a 19 percent stake in St. Paul-based Ecolab, a $1.3 billion service company and owner of Chemlawn. Ecolab would acquire Henkel's cleaning businesses in 18 countries outside Europe. The agreement would eventually give Henkel the ability to own up to 30 percent of Ecolab. The alliance allows Ecolab to position itself for stronger international growth as the European Community moves toward a single market in 1992. Ecolab Chairman Pierson Grieve said a major motivation for the deal was to prepare the company for the economic unification of Western Europe. In the cleaning and sanitation industry, ``There are three (companies) larger than us in Europe ... and the chances of us catching any of them were very small. It would have required a lot of years, and money,'' he said. The combination with Henkel means that the joint venture will have the largest European market share in three of the joint venture's four product segments and the second-largest share in the remaining segment, he said. ``What we've done is to strategically position Ecolab so that over time in the 1990s we'll have shifted a lot of our marketing power, technical ability and investment into the rest of the world,'' he said. The announcement got generally favorable reviews from securities analysts and the stock market. Frank Rolfes, an analyst with Dain Bosworth of Minneapolis, said the deal appears to be a good one for Ecolab. ``It will dilute (Ecolab's) control and ownership, but I think that the strong competitive position they're acquiring will outweigh that,'' he said. In December, Ecolab issued $110 million of convertible preferred stock to Henkel as an initial step in the deal. The agreement includes the combination of the European cleaning businesses of both companies in a joint venture with each partner having a 50 percent interest. Henkel will serve as managing partner and headquarters will be in Dusseldorf, the companies said. In connection with the sale of non-European cleaning businesses to Ecolab, Henkel will receive about $74 million and 5.6 million shares of Ecolab's common stock. Henkel will receive an additional $110 million, reflecting its investment in the Ecolab convertible preferred stock, which will be retired when the deal closes, the two companies said. Henkel will be represented on Ecolab's board of directors. The primary change will occur in Europe with the creation of Henkel-Ecolab, owned jointly by both partners. Initially, this business will have approximately $750 million in revenues and about 3,500 workers, the companies said. Ecolab's purchase of most of Henkel's remaining worldwide cleaning and sanitizing operations will initially increase Ecolab's revenues by over $50 million in Asia and Latin America, Grieve said. He said the deal should not dilute Ecolab's 1991 per share earnings. For the year ended Dec. 31, Ecolab reported sales of $1.3 billion and earnings of $2.7 million, or 10 cents a share. Henkel had 1989 sales of $6.2 billion and net earnings of $217.2 million. Regulatory approvals are required in various jurisdictions. The deal is expected to be completed at the beginning of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Down at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were down slightly at midday Thursday on London's Stock Exchange as trading volume sagged. At midday, the broad-based Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 6.6 points at 2,135.7. Volume at midday was 180.2 million shares, compared to 267.9 million shares at midday Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Clears Tylenol Damage Case for Trial
DOC.TEXT: Families of seven people killed with cyanide-contaminated Tylenol capsules eight years ago have won the right to go to trial to seek damages against the manufacturer of the pain remedy. Circuit Judge Donald P. O'Connell on Wednesday rejected McNeil Consumer Products Inc.'s motion to dismiss the case for lack of sufficient evidence. O'Connell set trial for Oct. 19, but company lawyers said they will seek a continuance. Seven people died after taking capsules of Extra-Strength Tylenol in 1982 and investigators concluded that someone poisoned the capsules after they left the factory. No one has been charged with the killings. Even though the cyanide was put in the capsules after they left the company's control, McNeil was negligent in not providing tamper-resistant packaging, said Bruce R. Pfaff, a lawyer for families of two of the victims. ``In the three or four years preceding the poisonings, the company received over 200 complaints of individuals writing that something was wrong with their Tylenol,'' Pfaff said. ``Either capsules were missing, or some other medication was mixed in or there were foreign objects, pieces of metal and even fingernails.'' Pfaff said company investigations showed most or all of these complaints were traced to tampering after the medicine left the manufacturer. He said the issue of tampering was a common subject in trade journals of the packaging industry for 10 years or more before the Tylenol incident. The plaintiffs' attorneys will try to convince the jury that McNeil was negligent not merely in its packaging, but also in its decision to sell the remedy in capsule form, which is more subject to tampering that a tablet. ``Methods to deter tampering were well known and economically feasible,'' Pfaff said. He said when the company redesigned its packaging after the poisonings, ``It cost 2 cents a package to cure this problem.'' In accordance with Illinois law, the civil action against McNeil specifies no amount being sought, other than ``in excess of $15,000.'' ``Obviously, the losses are far, far greater than that,'' said Pfaff.

DOC.HEAD: Corporate Attorney Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Case
DOC.TEXT: An attorney who sold inside information to a stock broker about planned corporate takeovers pleaded guilty for his part in a multimillion-dollar scheme. Steven L. Glauberman, formerly with a prestigious corporate law firm, pleaded guilty on Wednesday before U.S. District Judge Miriam Cedarbaum to two counts of securities fraud and one of wire fraud. He faces a maximum fine of $250,000 and up to five years in prison on each count when sentenced Dec. 21. Glauberman, 39, of Manhattan, was charged last month by the U.S. attorney's office with four counts of conspiracy, securities fraud and wire fraud. Glauberman was an associate specializing in mergers and acquisitions at the firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom at the time at issue. The government alleged he leaked inside information about clients involved in some of the best-known takeovers of the 1980s to a stock broker, Eben Smith, who passed it along to others. The tips included information about Bristol-Meyers' 1985 bid for Genetic Systems, a 1985 management leveraged buyout of National Gypsum, Black & Decker's 1988 unsolicited bid for American Standard and Walt Disney Co.'s offer for Gibson Greetings. Last month, Glauberman settled a civil complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission, agreeing to pay back $221,000 in his alleged illegal profits. The SEC said the stock broker, Smith, paid Glauberman $50,000 for the information and also traded in a special account for Glauberman's benefit. Smith, 41, of Greenwich, Conn., faces criminal conspiracy and securities fraud charges.

DOC.HEAD: Sikorsky Announces 350 to Be Laid Off
DOC.TEXT: Sikorsky Aircraft will lay off 350 salaried employees Saturday, the helicopter manufacturer said. Sikorsky spokesman William Tuttle said Wednesday the white-collar layoffs are part of an effort to make the company more competitive. The Stratford-based company, the helicopter division of United Technologies Corp., will have a workforce of 11,300 after the layoffs, Tuttle said. The employees facing lay offs were informed Wednesday of the company's decision, he said. In addition to Stratford, Sikorsky has operations in Bridgeport, West Haven, Shelton and Trumbull, as well as Troy, Ala., and West Palm Beach, Fla. Tuttle said most of the layoffs will come from Sikorsky's Connecticut operations, but he did not provide further details. Some of those being laid off are engineers, he said, declining further comment on other classifications of employees being laid off. Sikorsky laid off 300 white-collar workers in February, citing defense budget cuts in the United States and foreign countries. Fifty hourly workers were laid off in March, and another 50 hourly jobs were cut through attrition that month. Tuttle said Sikorsky was scheduled to deliver 120 helicopters to U.S. military services in the 1990 fiscal year, down from 137 last year. Michael LaTronica, aerospace analyst for Labe Simpson & Co. in New York, said Sikorsky was ``trying to cut costs for a downturn in the defense budget, which will undoubtedly affect them.'' LaTronica said the layoffs were part of Sikorsky's strategy ``to size for the business that's out there.''

DOC.HEAD: UAW Can Pick and Choose Strategies
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union, whose influence in American labor shrank in the 1980s, can pick and choose from a variety of options as bargaining with General Motors Corp. enters its last days. Depending on the strategy chosen, the UAW could have a dramatic effect on the already sagging U.S. economy. In a nutshell, the union has three choices: reach agreement before the current contract expires at midnight Friday, extend the current agreement beyond then or stage some kind of strike. But such a decision may be moot if indications Wednesday prove true. Union officials in Detroit and elsewhere said there were indications that the union was moving toward a settlement before the midnight Friday expiration of the national UAW-GM contact. National UAW officials called local leaders to suburban Detroit on Monday amid speculation that national contract talks were heading toward a settlement rather than a strike. But they cautioned that progress could be derailed at any time. With a strike fund of about $770 million, the union has the fiscal flexibility to take a large number of the GM workers out of the company's plants for a long time. But the union may feel that a strike is unnecessary to demonstrate its dissatisfaction with GM. Ironically, the company's money-savings moves since the mid-1980s have given the union the means to drive home its points with GM. Because of a move to a ``just-in-time'' parts delivery system for its assembly plants, the union has regained some of the clout in garnered in the 1970s from its size _ 1.5 million members, mostly in the auto industry. GM's reliance, like other automakers, on the ``just-in-time'' system, which delivers parts to its assembly plants frequently a few hours before they are installed, cuts warehousing and inventory costs but leaves the automaker vulnerable to labor problems. The UAW demonstrated that last month, when it staged a walkout involving about 2,800 workers at GM's AC Rochester West plant in Flint, where fuel tanks and other parts of GM cars and trucks are made. When the supply of fuel tanks stopped, so did assembly plants. The strike was seen as a signal of what the union could do to the automaker if national talks broke down. By the time the six-day strike was over, seven assembly plants and portions of more than a dozen component factories had been shut down, temporarily idling more than 20,000 workers. Whenever an assembly plant shuts down, layoffs ripple out. Depending on how long production at an assembly plant is interrupted, effects can be felt throughout the auto supplier industry, including plastic, glass, rubber and steel makers. Labor negotiations in the auto industry come as the economy is slowing down and predictions of a recession are growing. The government recently reported that unemployment in August reached 5.6 percent, the highest level in two years; annual growth of the gross national product has dropped to 1.2 percent and many analysts project it to fall further; and orders for durable goods, including cars, have been flat. In 1970 an already-weak economy slipped into recession when the UAW struck GM for 69 days, said Donald Ratajczak of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta. At that time, he said, GM played a much larger part in the U.S. economy than it does now. ``Therefore, it (GM) by itself isn't going to take down the economy,'' Ratajczak said Wednesday. ``Although it's a negative. We're being hit by negatives all over the place.'' He said auto negotiations this year come ``at a bad time when consumer psychology is hurting anyway. You start to run up the unemployment rate (from a strike) and you'll kill Christmas.''

DOC.HEAD: Corroon & Black Gets Higher Bid From Aon Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Corroon & Black Corp.'s plans to merge with fellow insurance broker Willis Faber PLC of Britain were thrown into question by a higher cash offer from another insurer, Aon Corp. Aon, the holding company for the brokerage Rollins Burdick Hunter Group Inc., said Wednesday it would pay $40 a share, or about $840 million, for Corroon & Black. That tops the stock-swap merger agreement between Corroon & Black and Willis Faber valued at more than $750 million. In a terse statement Wednesday responding to the offer, Corroon & Black noted its prior agreement with Willis Faber and said it would respond to Aon after its board had time to study the bid. Willis Faber said today it remained committed to its agreement with Corroon & Black. Aon indicated it would not launch a hostile bid for Corroon & Black should its target spurn the offer. ``We are not interested in pursuing any transaction which is opposed by your board of directors,'' Aon chairman Patrick G. Ryan said in a letter to Corroon & Black chairman Richard H. Miller. In his letter, Ryan said that under terms of the Willis Faber merger, Corroon & Black can negotiate with and provide information to ``any third party which proposes a transaction with the board of Corroon.'' He also said Corroon & Black was free to end its merger deal with Willis Faber in favor of a higher offer. Corroon & Black shareholders were scheduled to vote on the merger with Willis Faber on Sept. 28. The stock-swap merger would give the shareholders 7.8 Willis Faber shares for each Corroon & Black share, or $33.49 at current market prices, in a deal valued at $754 million. Corroon & Black and Willis Faber are the world's fifth- and sixth-largest insurance brokerages, respectively. Ira H. Malis, an insurance industry analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore, said that while Aon had a higher bid on the table, ``strategically, the deal with Willis Faber makes more sense.'' Willis Faber was a wholesale insurance broker, while Corroon & Black worked on a retail level, Malis said. There was more overlap, and likely to be layoffs, in a marriage between Aon and Corroon & Black, he said. James Guenther, an analyst with Duff & Phelps, said he expected Corroon & Black management to stick with the Willis Faber deal. But he added that despite the deal's merits, the company ``will find it rather difficult to ignore this fairly significant premium.'' Investors bid up Corroon & Black stock Wednesday, hoping the company might accept the offer. Corroon & Black shares shot up $6.75 to close at $37.62{ in New York Stock Exchange trading. Aon shares declined _ a common response by investors to a company that has raised the possibility of taking on a heavy debt load to finance an aquisition _$1.50 to $33 on the NYSE. Willis Faber stock, which is traded on London's Stock Exchange, was not affected by the announcement of the Aon bid, which came after the close of trading in Britain. The stock did not trade early today in London. The Corroon & Black-Willis Faber merger, announced in early June, would allow both firms to expand in the other's home market and eventually move into continental Europe and the Pacific Rim. The new firm, Britain-based Willis Corroon PLC, was expected to have 1990 revenue of about $1 billion. It would create the world's fourth-largest insurance brokerage in terms of revenue. Corroon & Black also provides risk management advice, reinsurance brokerage and other services. Willis Faber handles insurance and reinsurance brokerage as well as risk management services. Corroon & Black has nearly all its business in the United States, while Willis Faber gets about 80 percent of its revenue from Britain. Corroon & Black sold its 29.9 percent interest in the British broker Minet Holdings PLC in February 1988. Aon has operations in the United States, Canada, Europe and the Pacific. Besides Rollins Burdick, its subsidiaries include Combined Insurance Co. of America and Union Fidelity Life Insurance Co. Malis said a combination between Corroon & Black and Aon would create the third-largest insurance company in the nation and the fourth or fifth largest in the world. Aon likely would have difficulty pursuing a hostile takeover because of laws in Delaware, where Corroon & Black is incorporated, have created obstacles to thwart many unwanted bids.

DOC.HEAD: ServiceMaster, Waste Management to Form Limited Partnership
DOC.TEXT: Officials from ServiceMaster and Waste Management Inc. have tentatively agreed to form a limited partnership. Under the agreement announced Wednesday, Waste Management will contribute its pest control and Tru-Green lawn-care businesses, together valued at $180 million. It will have a 22 percent interest in the partnership. ServiceMaster, in turn, will contribute its consumer services businesses, which includes the Service Master cleaning services, the Terminix termite and pest-control businesses. Also included are the Merry Maids business and the American Home Shield home-service warranty business. ServiceMaster, based in north suburban Downers Groves, will hold 78 percent of the new company's equity. The new partnership, if approved by both companies' boards, will be named ServiceMaster Consumer Services Limited Partnership. In addition to its 22 percent stake in the partnership, Waste Management will have a member on the new company's board of directors. ``They (Waste Management officials) won't really be involved in the day-to-day operations,'' said Roger Ervin, a ServiceMaster spokesman. ``We will be doing that.'' The two units of Waste Management involved in the partnership compose a small portion of the Oak Brook-based company, which last year had $4.5 billion in revenues.

DOC.HEAD: Trader's Attorney: Merc Rules Routinely Ignored
DOC.TEXT: Chicago Mercantile Exchange rules ``don't work'' and everyone ``from the top on down'' regularly ignores them, says an attorney at the trial of 14 Japanese yen futures traders. But Attorney Thomas Durkin, representing trader Sam Cali, told federal jurors hearing the case that technical rule violations don't add up to a racketeering conspiracy. ``It ain't a conspiracy when everybody's doing it,'' Durkin argued Wednesday in U.S. District Court. ``There may be something wrong, but it ain't a conspiracy.'' The Mercantile Exchange immediately issued a statement denying rules are routinely broken. ``These allegations are absolutely baseless,'' an exchange spokesman said. The case of the yen traders is the second trial in a wide ranging federal probe of corruption at the Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade. The first trial _ that of Swiss franc futures traders _ resulted in a hung jury on many of the counts. A third trial, involving several soybean traders and brokers at the Board of Trade, is set to begin Monday. On Wednesday, Durkin said two sets of rules are used at the exchange _ a cosmetic set for tourists in the Merc's viewing gallery and an illegal set for brokers and traders. Another defense attorney, Edward Genson, asked U.S. District Judge William Hart to declare a mistrial based on Durkin's remarks, saying Durkin suggested all of the defendants are guilty. Hart denied the motion. Prosecutors say the defendants routinely shifted personal financial liabilities of trading errors onto their customers. Attorneys say the trial could last up to six months.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Threatens Japan's Economic Boom, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Inflation sparked by higher oil prices resulting from the Gulf crisis is threatening Japan's long-term economic expansion, Japan's central bank governor said Thursday. But a quarterly survey showed most businessmen believe the economy is resilient enough to weather the crisis without a major setback. ``Rising price pressures and the new factor of current high oil prices require extreme caution,'' Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a convention of securities dealers. ``The price environment is severe.'' Mieno and other officials addressing the convention noted that the Gulf crisis had hit financial markets hard as investors reacted with concern over higher oil prices. The Tokyo Stock Exchange had stabilized during the summer after losing about one-quarter of its value during a prolonged correction this spring, but the Gulf crisis further eroded the value of its key index. On Aug. 23, the Nikkei Stock Average hit 23,737.63 points, 39 percent below its record 38,915.87-point close on Dec. 28, 1989. Since then, it has edged up in a series of volatile trading sessions. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 141.06 points to 25,075.08. Although the market has lost about 200 trillion yen, or $1.45 trillion, of its value since December, personal spending and corporate investment remain robust, Mieno said. The Bank of Japan's latest quarterly survey of business sentiment, released earlier this week, indicates that most executives remain fairly bullish about the economy despite the Gulf crisis, he noted. The central bank's business condition index edged down only slightly to 46 in August from 48 in May. The index is the percentage of the 691 companies surveyed that report favorable business conditions minus those who report they are unfavorable. Japan is in its 46th straight month of economic expansion. The central bank, however, has raised interest rates five times since May 1989 to help curb inflationary pressures generated by growth in the money supply and a labor shortage. The latest hike, on Aug. 30, raised the official discount rate by 0.75 percentage point to 6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Raises Fares for Second Time in Month, Blaming Fuel Prices
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines has announced its second fare increase in a month, blaming it on rising fuel prices resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis. The Atlanta-based airline said Wednesday its fares will go up 4.2 percent on Oct. 1. Delta raised its fares 5.3 percent on Aug. 30. Delta follows Pan American World Airways in making a second fare hike because of the fuel price increase. Pan Am said it would raise fares 4.4 percent next Tuesday. Other major carriers, some of whom made larger initial increases, said a decision to raise fares was under review. Most airlines raised their fare prices shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, sending oil prices upward. Delta said its fuel costs have risen 33{ cents a gallon since July 31, which amounts to $670 million a year.
