The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 10.89 points to 2,614.85 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by 3 to 2 in the early tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 322 up, 484 down and 489 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rises to 5.8 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Unemployment in Britain rose to 5.8 percent in August, the Department of Employment said Thursday. The jobless figure, adjusted for seasonal variations, was up from 5.7 percent in the previous month. Last week, the U.S. Labor Department reported that the U.S. unemployment rate had risen to 5.6 percent in August from 5.5 percent in July.

DOC.HEAD: New York Post and Daily News Trying to Hold On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9 ``Newsday reported...' with one graf confirming Times position. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `All four.... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: It's crunch time in New York's newspaper wars and thousands of jobs and some long journalistic traditions hang in the balance. The economy, combined with the competition, is threatening two of the city's tabloids. The no-holds-barred New York Post, which has suffered losses for years, says that the hemorrhaging must end and that it will shut down with Saturday's edition unless its unions agree to more than $19 million in concessions. At the money-losing Daily News, months-long labor negotiations appear stalemated. Management has made extensive preparations for a strike. The unions continue working but are urging advertisers to boycott the paper. ``There is an adequate market here for at least one (tabloid) paper, possibly two,'' said Ken Noble, a media analyst with Paine Webber. Which would be fine for the two newspapers if New York Newsday, a third tabloid also losing money, did not have a profitable parent, the Times Mirror Co., patiently waiting for the market to sort itself out. The city's fourth major daily, The New York Times, is profitable, though less so than a year ago. The Times also will seek concessions from the unions to the extent that they involve the same economic conditions that have affected the Post and News, said William Adler, a Times spokesman. All four newspapers are suffering from an unofficial recession slamming the Northeast that has retail advertising down. The Post _ founded in 1801 by Alexander Hamilton _ has the worst economic problems. Three owners in the past two decades have lost millions of dollars. Now its already slim ad linage is down. ``They're the most likely to go out of business,'' Noble said. On Sept. 4, Post Publisher Peter S. Kalikow told the paper's unions that he was losing $27 million a year on the tabloid and that he needed concessions from them of $17.4 million in payroll and $1.9 million in benefits. He set an 8 p.m. Friday deadline for an agreement. Otherwise, he said the paper would report in its Saturday editions that it was closing and 960 employees would be out of work. ``He did not want to read about the future of the New York Post in another newspaper,'' said Howard Rubenstein, a Post spokesman. With headlines like ``READ MY LIPS: I LIED'' and ``UP YOURS!'' to Saddam Hussein, and its all-time classic about a tavern killing _ ``HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR'' _ the Post strikes a chord that summons readers to newsstands. But its circulation is now about 505,000, down from 900,000 in the past decade. ``The New York Post has been very honest in coming to us with this economic problem,'' said George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella group representing nine unions at the Post. ``We're going to do everything possible to help the Post stay in business.'' The News too is claiming losses _ $115 million from 1979 to 1989 on revenues of $4 billion _ but also is trying to undo what it says are archaic work rules that result in overstaffing on the presses and among drivers. In the last decade, its circulation has dropped about 700,000 to 1,180,000. The News has said it needs new color presses to replace its 30-to 40-year-old equipment and stay competitive. While the unions, which represent about 3,000 workers, recognize the need for new presses, they claim the News' parent, the Tribune Co. of Chicago, is out to break them in order to sell the paper. Daily News unions point to the hiring of King and Ballow, a Nashville, Tenn., law firm they say has a reputation for union-busting; the hiring of replacement workers, and the training of management to run the presses if workers strike. Management at the News has already told the unions that it expects concessions equal to anything granted the Post. To put on the pressure, the unions are urging advertisers to boycott the News until a settlement is reached. ``It's a fight to the death over at the New York News right now,'' said Noble. New York Newsday, meanwhile, has trucks ready to roll if the News folds or goes on strike or if the Post expires, he said. Newsday, with its circulation of 225,000, ``would leap into the breach. They sure would,'' Noble said.

DOC.HEAD: Liquor Companies Propose Alternative To Advertising Ban
DOC.TEXT: France's major liquor manufacturers Thursday offered to contribute millions of dollars to alcoholism prevention programs if the government backed off a plan to prohibit liquor ads. The companies also proposed the creation of a commission representing the public and private sectors to regulate liquor advertising. The proposals were drafted by a group of executives from Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton, Pernod Ricard, Champagne de Venoge, Martini et Rossi France, Seagram France and other companies. Thierry Mantoux, chief executive of Champagne de Venoge, said the industry contribution would be in proportion to the amount of money each company spent on advertising. He predicted that tens of millions of francs would be generated for alcohol prevention. Parliament earlier this year approved a plan by Health Minister Claude Evin to ban tobacco and alcohol advertising starting in 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Hamilton Gets UK Approval To Tap North Sea Gas Reserve
DOC.TEXT: Hamilton Oil Co. and four partners plan to tap a giant natural gas reserve off the coast of Scotland, in a $2.85 billion deal that could create the largest gas project in the British North Sea. The United Kingdom Department of Energy agreed Wednesday to allow Denver-based Hamilton and its partners to drill a series of wells in the Bruce field, 240 miles northeast of Aberdeen, Scotland. The Bruce field is considered attractive because it also contains oil reserves that are expected to yield 80,000 barrels of crude a day when production reaches its peak. The field was discovered more than 10 years ago, but the Hamilton group only recently reached marketing agreements to sell the gas to two British power companies, British Gas and Corby Power Ltd. Hamilton officials hope to start drawing gas in October 1993. They said that when production reaches its peak in 1994, the field should produce 520 million cubic feet of gas a day, making it the largest such project in the region. Hamilton, an independent oil company, will pay about $450 million of the development costs and take a 16 percent stake in the project. Its partners include the French petrochemical companies Elf-Aquitaine and Total Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, as well as British Petroleum and London-based Ultramer Exploration Ltd. Hamilton began drilling in the North Sea with projects dating to 1975, and the company has been stepping up its exploration in the area in recent years.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 379.52 down 0.80 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Congress to Consider Hike in Depositor Insurance Premiums
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Greenspan testimony; picks up 5th graf pvs bgng: Greenspan's testimony . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said today the fund that protects bank depositors will likely ``remain under stress for some time to come,'' but he cautioned Congress against hastily passing legislation that would only make the situation worse. Greenspan noted that the reserves in the Federal Deposit Insurance Fund now stand at their lowest level ever as a string of near-record bank failures has depleted FDIC reserves. ``There remain all too many problems in the banking system, problems that have been growing of late as many banks, including many larger banks, have been experiencing a deterioration in the quality of their loan portfolios, particularly real estate loans,'' Greenspan told a House committee. ``It thus seems clear that the insurance fund likely will remain under stress for some time to come,'' Greenspan said. ``Moreover, pressures would intensify if real estate market conditions were to weaken further or a recession were to develop in the general economy.'' Greenspan's warning was similar, although less specific, than reports earlier this week from the congressional General Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office. Both agencies warned that one large bank failure or a further downturn in the economy could wipe out the remaining $13.2 billion in the FDIC insurance fund and force taxpayers to provide a bailout. It was the depletion of a separate insurance fund for deposits in the savings and loan industry that prompted legislation last year that is expected to cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars over the next 30 years. Members of Congress, alarmed by the reports that the FDIC fund is also in trouble, have rushed to introduce legislation to boost its resources and thus avert a similar bailout for the bank fund. Greenspan cautioned that while ``reform is needed. So is caution.'' He spoke against proposals to reduce the insurance limit from $100,000 and said it would be difficult to administer a law which limited the number of deposits each individual could have. He also said lawmakers should not be too aggressive in boosting the premiums banks must pay for deposit insurance and run the risk of making the industry uncompetitive. Greenspan's testimony before the House Banking Committee followed two days of hearings this week by the Senate Banking Committee on the state of the deposit insurance fund. Comptroller Charles A. Bowsher of the General Accounting Office said Tuesday that the FDIC fund, currently with $13.2 billion in resources, is dwindling so rapidly that it could be wiped out by a recession or a single big bank failure. Taxpayers would be forced to cover the costs. Bowsher's dire warning was followed by testimony Wednesday in which the Congressional Budget Office predicted that even without a recession some 600 to 700 commercial banks will likely fail over the next 3{ years, draining $20 billion out of the FDIC insurance fund. Both reports heightened fears in Congress that banks, just like savings and loan associations, could require a multibillion-dollar taxpayer bailout unless something is done. Responding to the reports, lawmakers introduced bills to uncap the deposit insurance premiums and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady indicated that the Bush administration would soon offer its own proposal to raise premiums. The FDIC now charges banks 12 cents a year for every $100 the agency insures. Under the S&L bailout law passed last year, the premiums will automatically rise next January to 15 cents per $100 of insurance. The FDIC has proposed raising the assessment to 19.5 cents. But even with the larger increase, the GAO said insurance funds would still have insufficient reserves to cover possible losses to bank depositors during a recession without an infusion of taxpayer dollars. Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald Riegle, D-Mich., introduced legislation Wednesday that would allow the FDIC to raise its reserves by $25 billion to $35 billion. Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., introduced a similar bill in the House. Other members of Congress on Wednesday proposed limiting deposit insurance to $100,000 per individual depositor. The FDIC now insures each account up to $100,000 with no limit on the number of insured accounts a single depositor may have. In his testimony, Congressional Budget Office director Robert Reischauer said he foresaw trouble for the FDIC fund if the declining real estate values now plaguing the Northeast spread to other parts of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Up in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices were higher in early trading here today, following a strong performance in Europe where investors responded to tight supplies. On the New York Mercantile Exchange late this morning, light sweet crude was up 33 cents to $31.30 per barrel for October delivery. Unleaded gasoline was up .66 cent to 94.50 cents per gallon on October contracts, while home heating oil was up 1.76 cents to 84.35 cents on October contracts. Natural gas was trading at $1.545 per 1,000 cubic feet, up from Wednesday's close of $1.543. Crude had opened up about 50 cents, then slacked off a bit on the basis of a report that Iran might not help Iraq try to evade international trade sanctions after all. On Wednesday, traders had responded to news that Iran might trade food and medicine for Iraqi oil, but Iranian officials were quoted today as saying that would not happen.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Income Up in Drought Recovery
With PM-Farm Income-List
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 5th-6th grafs, ``The states . . . to restore dropped matter. Picks up 7th graf, The department's . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: New Agriculture Department figures show net U.S. farm income increased overall last year, but the gains were limited to about two-thirds of the states. The department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday that recovery from the 1988 drought varied according to region, with Midwestern states showing the sharpest year-to-year increases because they were hit so hard by the drought. Net farm income increased in 34 states, averaging 21.1 percent higher than in 1988, the report said. The other 16 states showed a decline averaging 9.8 percent. Nationwide, the increase was 10.7 percent. ``The states with the largest percentage increases were the ones hit hardest by drought in 1988,'' a report said. ``North Dakota's net farm income rose by 75 percent from 1988 to 1989. Illinois, Indiana, Iowa and Minnesota also registered substantial increases.'' The department's figures cover only farming operations and exclude earnings from non-farm jobs held by family members. As defined by the agency, net farm income is the difference between gross farm income and total expenses. ``Additions to inventories are treated as income,'' the report said. ``Non-money items such as depreciation, the consumption of farm-grown food, and the net imputed rental value of operator dwellings are included.'' Nationally, net farm income in 1989 was reported at $46.5 billion, up 10.7 percent from about $42 billion in 1988. This year's may be in the range of $47 billion to $52 billion, analysts said. California and Texas remained the top states in net farm income last year, although each showed a decline from 1988. Florida continued in third place. Kansas and Arkansas dropped from the top 10 and were replaced by Wisconsin and Illinois in 1989. Regionally, states in the Corn Belt, Great Lakes and Northern Plains generally rose in net farm income rankings, while the Southeast, Appalachian and Mississippi Delta states tended to fall. Overall, the top 10 states accounted for $23.6 billion or 50.9 percent of U.S. net farm income, down from 53.5 percent in 1988, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Qualified Indications of a Tentative Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, A GM . . . to CORRECT Stempel title to chairman sted vice chairman. Picks up 13th graf pvs, Before the . . .
DOC.TEXT: There were indications today that a settlement may be near in United Auto Workers union negotiations with General Motors Corp., but both sides are quick to say that things could unravel. The two sides are working against the midnight Friday expiration of a labor contract covering 300,000 active GM workers. The deadline is the same for contracts between the UAW and Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. In all, more than 450,000 active unionized workers are covered by the three agreements. The UAW has scheduled a meeting of its GM bargaining council for a suburban Detroit hotel on Monday. UAW local leaders and a national union source said it was likely the meeting was called to discuss tentative contract provisions. However, there still were two full days of bargaining left in the life of the current agreement and the talks could sour during that time, they said. This morning, a UAW official who didn't want to be identified said progress was being made but unresolved issues included job security, wages, pensions and health care. Tentative agreements have been reached on a variety of matters, including health and safety in factories and grievance procedures, he said. On Wednesday, UAW local leaders indicated the bargaining council meeting was an indication of progress in the talks. ``Why would they call the meeting and why would they want us in Detroit on Monday? Why would they want us in Detroit if nothing's settled?'' asked Joe Garcia, secretary-treasurer of UAW Local 645 at GM's Van Nuys, Calif., car assembly plant. He said the meeting was set for the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Dearborn. A hotel worker who did not identify himself confirmed that the UAW had reserved rooms for a large meeting. A national UAW official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday that while such a meeting could be called to discuss a strike, it was more likely that it would be used to describe details of a tentative contract. Top-ranking UAW and GM executives met Wednesday morning to discuss outstanding contract issues, said another UAW official, who requested anonymity. He declined to say what the issues were, but it was nearly certain that one of them was job security, the union's pet issue in this set of talks. A GM statement said only that Chairman Robert Stempel and labor Vice President Alfred Warren met with UAW President Owen Bieber and Vice President Stephen Yokich, who is leading the union's bargaining effort with GM. Before the union puts any tentative settlement up for a ratification vote by its membership, leaders typically brief local union presidents and bargaining committee chair people. Those officials make up bargaining councils of the union's GM, Ford and Chrysler departments. David Fenwick, president of UAW Local 933 in Indianapolis, also said Wednesday he had been called to the Monday meeting of the GM bargaining council. ``I don't see why they would schedule it (the meeting) for us on the 17th if we were going out,'' Fenwick said. ``I would say they must be very close. They must be calling us up there to inform us'' of contract terms. Earlier Wednesday, one of the UAW officials said talks were ``percolating'' after bogging down Monday principally over job security. ``Things are moving,'' the official said. At GM, negotiators have been focusing on economic issues in the final days of talks. UAW officials have said tentative agreements have been reached on nearly all non-economic issues _ legal assistance and military leave provisions for example.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Extends Bond Buyout Offer
DOC.TEXT: Southland Corp., owners of the 7-Eleven convenience chain, extended its deadline Thursday for an offer to exchange $1.8 billion in publicly held debt for a new package of securities. This is the third extension of the offer, first announced in March, as Southland tries to reduce its interest expense and raise $430 million in new capital. The offer has been extended to Sept. 25. It was set to expire at midnight Thursday. Southland said 50 percent to 95 percent of different classes of bonds have been turned over. ``Over the past two weeks, we've succeeded in identifying the vast majority of Southland security holders who have not yet tendered their securities,'' said chief financial officer, Clark Matthews. ``Over the next eight days we will intensify our efforts to communicate with them, to explain the merits of the proposed restructuring and to urge them to tender their securities. Under the exchange offers, Southland bondholders and preferred stockholders are being offered new debt securities and about 25 percent of newly issued Southland common stock. Southland's Japanese partners, Ito-Yokado and Seven-Eleven Japan would purchase 70 percent of the stock for $430 million in cash. The current owners, the Thompson family of Dallas, would retain a 5 percent stake in the recapitalized company. Southland incurred $4.9 billion in debt following a leveraged buyout of the company on 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Unveils New High-Speed Printing System
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. on Thursday unveiled a new printing system that will allow personal computer users to hook up with high-speed printers traditionally reserved for mainframe computers. The system, called Lionheart, will print documents up to nine times faster than conventional desktop printers, the company said. It will also allow users to get sets of finished reports _ sorted, stapled and hole-punched _ without leaving their desks. ``There are lots of high-speed printers around, but the ability to go directly from the PC to the printer is unique, the first in the industry,'' said Charles L. Trowbridge, general manager of Kodak's Copy Products Division. ``The magic is in the software and connection between the PC and the system,'' he said. The system is priced at $250,000 and is targeted at the high end of the business systems market, Trowbridge said. Trowbridge said the system will allow personal computer users to get documents printed at speeds of up to 92 pages per minute, compared to 8 to 10 pages per minute for standard desktop printers. The centerpiece of the new system is an Ektaprint high-speed printer that has been on the market for several years.

DOC.HEAD: Union Says French-US Drug Company Plans Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc., a newly formed French-American company, plans to lay off 400 workers in France through a combination of early retirement and payroll cutbacks, a union said Thursday. The company declined to comment, but noted that its governing board meets Friday in Paris. It plans a news conference next week. The Confederation Francaise Democratique du Travail said the company, created in July through the merger of Rhone-Poulenc's human health division and Rorer Group Inc. of Pennsylvania, planned cuts at a variety of sites. These included plants in Hauts-de-Seine and Seine-Maritime, as well as six factories of the Propharm SA unit. The union said two research centers would lose a total of 180 employees as part of a plan to transfer research programs to the United States. Rhone-Poulenc has been divesting non-essential assets in an attempt to offset the $2 billion cost of acquiring Rorer. Most recently, the group sold its Spanish polyvinyl chloride business to Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, while a group of French banks bought Rhone-Poulenc's headquarters. Chairman Jean-Rene Fourtou told a news conference that asset sales for all of 1990 could give the chemicals and pharmaceuticals group up to 1.5 billion francs, or $282 million, in fresh cash. French stock analysts have questioned the timing of the Rorer purchase, suggesting that a slowing U.S. economy will affect anticipated earnings. The company also received a blow in August from U.S. regulators, who ruled that a planned venture with Procter & Gamble Co. to distribute its over-the-counter pharmaceutical products in the U.S. market violated antitrust regulations.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Weigh Cigarette Tax as Optimism Prevails
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with White House comment; picks up 6th graf pvs, bgng: On Wednesday . . . Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: White House and congressional budget bargainers are considering new taxes on cigarettes and petroleum products as participants say they sense an approaching deal despite daunting remaining obstacles. Negotiators began a seventh consecutive day of talks late this morning cloistered at Andrews Air Force Base, just outside the capital city in Maryland. They had worked until shortly after midnight as bargainers tried to close in on a package of tax increases and spending cuts saving $50 billion in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 and $500 billion by 1995. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said today he remained optimistic about the talks, even though thorny disputes remain over taxes and spending. ``There's no single issue that's holding it up,'' Foley told reporters. ``There are a lot of tough issues. They're all difficult.'' At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater suggested that progress toward a budget breakthrough was hard to assess at this time. ``Everybody wants to keep the pressure on. We're still hopeful,'' Fitzwater said. On Wednesday, the negotiators tackled the question of whose taxes will be increased. They already have agreed to raise taxes and federal fees by $25 billion next year and $130 billion over the next five years. Participants said they discussed boosting the 16-cents-per-pack cigarette tax, perhaps doubling it, which would raise $2.8 billion next year. They continued their efforts to agree to higher taxes on alcoholic beverages, an idea both sides have suggested. In response, Anheuser-Busch, the nation's largest brewer of malt beverages, has been running ``Can the Beer Tax'' advertisements. Walker Merryman, vice president of the Tobacco Institute, said cigarette manufacturers have chosen a lower-profile effort against any increase, contending that a rise in tobacco taxes would hurt the poor disproportionately and cause job layoffs. White House budget chief Richard Darman suggested slapping a 1 percent tax on all petroleum-containing products except livestock feed, one official said, a proposal that would cover items ranging from gasoline to cosmetics. It would reap the government $800 million next year and $7 billion over five years. He also proposed a lower-cost version of a tax on luxury items the Democrats have advanced. Goods subject to the levy under both proposals include expensive cars, private planes and boats, jewelry, furs and electronic equipment. But one of the thorniest remaining hurdles is also a tax proposal: President Bush's proposal to lower the capital gains tax rate. The levy is charged when property and other investments are sold at a profit. Republicans say a cut would stimulate more sales and thus bring in more tax revenue. But Democrats, complaining that the idea would merely fatten the wallets of the rich, say they won't accept it without a proposal of their own: a boost in income taxes on the wealthy. Republicans reject that idea. The parties also remain at odds over spending totals for domestic programs. GOP negotiators want domestic programs _ ranging from benefit programs like Medicare to general government efforts like road-building _ to be slashed by $130 billion over the next five years. Democrats want to hold the reduction to $90 billion. ``We had to get to the tough questions, and now we're there,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee. One further complication was added when New York's 34 members of the House signed a letter promising to vote against any deal that limits the deductibility on federal income taxes of state and local income taxes. Officials from states with high income taxes, like New York, fear that the idea _ under consideration by the bargainers _ would make it harder for states to raise taxes in the future. ``It would kill New York,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., who circulated the letter. ``It would cause the exodus of many, many people.'' The negotiators have discussed boosting Medicare premiums for better-off recipients. They also are nearing agreement on a deal to limit next year's military budget to about $295 billion, $11 billion below the amount needed to keep up with inflation. Officials believe that the deficit will likely exceed $250 billion _ a record _ in the upcoming fiscal year unless something is done. Without a budget agreement by Oct. 1, the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will shrink the $1.2 trillion budget by $100 billion, an amount that would disrupt most federal programs.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Starts Energy Conservation Effort; Critics Say Not Enough
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Tops with 12 grafs, Picks up 4th graf pvs. Addressing a ... Edits throughout to shorten. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration unveiled a revised program today to ease the shortfall in oil, but Energy Secretary James Watkins said worldwide shortages could linger at near 1 million barrels a day through the winter. Watkins said he believed the shortfall can be ``managed'' through conservation efforts and additional domestic production. He left open the possibility of drawing oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in the coming months if conservation and increased production efforts fall short of expectations. But he reiterated it was too soon to use the reserve, which holds nearly 600 million barrels. ``That's a cherished reserve that has a finite life ... and we don't want to use it too early,'' Watkins told the Senate Energy and Natural Resource Committee. He said he was ``comfortable'' that the department would be ready to take oil from the reserve in short notice if needed. The department outlined a revised combined program of energy conservation and oil production measures that officials said was aimed at cutting the oil supply shortfall in the United States by about 1.1 million barrels a day. The new program, including a radio advertising campaign urging conservation, came amid increasing criticism that the administration's efforts to ease the country's reliance on foreign oil have been more rhetoric than substance. ``The president should give more than a speech. He should give us a program,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said Wednesday in response to Bush's call for increased energy conservation in light of the Persian Gulf crisis. Watkins rejected such criticsm, saying the administration's efforts to increase production and get Americans to conserve oil are ``substantive ... We do not think they are trivial.'' Much of the department's program announced today mirrored the response plan announced shortly after the Mideast crisis developed, including calls on motorists to conserve fuel by properly inflating tires and various measures to expand production from existing domestic oil fields. But Watkins said as much as 165,000 barrels of day also could be saved by fuel switching and urged that regulatory and other barriers be eased to promote switching. He said there are 37 natural gas pipeline proposals awaiting federal or state approval. The plan also included tax incentives for oil and gas production, expanded production from Alaska and opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil exploration _ all proposals announced previously. Watkins said current crude oil stocks were well above levels at the same time last year, but he said there was a 3.6 million barrel worldwide production shortfall in September and that the shortfall was expected to be gradually reduced to about 1 million by next January and slightly lower in the succeeding months. The United Nations economic embargo imposed on Iraq slashed available production from Iraq and occupied Kuwait by 4 million barrels a day. Addressing a joint session of Congress on the Middle East crisis Tuesday night, Bush asked lawmakers to enact measures to increase domestic oil and gas production and said conservation is ``essential to keep our energy needs as low as possible.'' But environmentalists and some members of Congress say the administration has been slow in developing an energy plan and is giving only scant emphasis to energy conservation, while emphasizing expanded drilling, possibly in environmentally sensitive areas. ``Never once did he mention renewable energy,'' Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, said of Bush's speech. But since returning from their August recess, members of Congress also have been short on specific proposals. The exception has been House and Senate legislation calling for dramatic increases in automobile fuel economy. Legislation sponsored by Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., would require automakers to improve the average fuel economy of new cars to 40 miles per gallon by 2001. On Wednesday, Bryan and other sponsors said the measure would cut the demand for petroleum by 2.8 million barrels a day by the turn of the century. But the White House has opposed the measure and a recently circulated policy memo suggested that the president likely would veto it.

Dealers said aggressive dollar selling followed comments by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan that if a credible U.S. budget-deficit reduction accord is reached, the central bank might encourage lower interest rates. Falling U.S. interest rates make the dollar less appealing to foreigners, cutting their potential returns on dollar-denominated investments. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 137.65 Japanese yen from 138.30 yen at Wednesday's close. It was the lowest closing level in Tokyo since Aug. 3, 1989, when the dollar finished at 136.40 yen. DOC.HEAD: Atrium Pioneer's Reputation Takes a Blow in Debt Crisis
LaserPhoto AX1
DOC.TEXT: Financing difficulties brought on by debt have delivered a blow to John C. Portman's reputation, but the Atlanta architect-developer's lieutenants say obituaries are premature. Despite the recent series of emergency meetings with creditors over Portman's unsecured loans, officials of The Portman Cos. maintain their operation is strong and its ventures are moving full steam ahead. ``We've been in business 30 years and will be in business 30 more. The financing on our major projects is firmly in place. There is no threat to the concrete and steel buildings of the Portman Companies,'' executive vice president Sam Williams said Wednesday, following the latest session with creditors. Williams said the focus of the meetings is to create a pool of collateral to back the company's unsecured loans - those that are not supported by assets or other collateral. He said he expected an agreement to be reached within two weeks. Williams said Portman has no intention of backing out of any of his current projects, though some, notably a 60-story office tower in downtown Atlanta, are going up under less than ideal circumstances. The Atlanta venture, to be called One Peachtree Center and designed as the tallest skyscraper in the South, has been launched amid a period of rising vacancy rates in the city's office buildings. Williams argued that the severity of the downtown office vacancy situation has been inflated because most calculations have factored in two other skyscraper projects that have since been abandoned. Another major Atlanta office building, 191 Peachtree Tower, is under construction now and nearing completion. Williams contends that the Portman project, currently in its early stages of construction, will be in a prime position as the newest kid on the block when it opens in 1991. ``In essence, we now have the market position of the only new office tower in downtown Atlanta with space available,'' Williams said. ``Real estate, like any other business, goes in cycles. ... Who's to say what cycle we will be in in the third quarter of 1995? Our crystal ball is not that good but we've been through real estate storms before.'' Portman, who declined to be interviewed for this article, has been on the defensive before, though rarely for his business acumen. His architectural style, marked by streamlined exteriors and expansive indoor atriums, have tended to be popular among the masses but maligned by critics, who accused Portman of building urban fortresses. Portman has steadfastly defended his modernist architecture as ``for people and not things.'' After building his Peachtree Center cluster of office towers, hotels and trade marts in downtown Atlanta, Portman went on to major projects in cities including New York, San Francisco and Singapore. As the real estate market began to slump over the last three years, however, Portman borrowed heavily and refinanced existing projects to launch new ventures. Among his new developments are the $300 million One Peachtree Center; the $155 million Inforum technology mart, which opened last year in Atlanta; the $90 million San Francisco Fashion Center, which opened during the summer; and the $195 million Shanghai Center, an office-hotel-retail complex opening next month in China. Portman's operation is private and does not release financial data, though his current debt load has been reported to be more than $1.6 billion. He has been sued recently by DG Bank Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank for allegedly failing to make a $3 million loan repayment. And on Sept. 1 he stopped making payments to one of his main creditors, Equitable Life Assurances Society of the United States, on a $332.6 million mortgage for his flagship Peachtree Center complex in Atlanta. Williams said the company's problems are only with unsecured creditors, who hold about 5 percent of the company's loans. A spokesman for Equitable this week declined to comment on the talks with Portman, though two other creditors, CitiBank and Swiss Bank Corp., said ``positive progress'' was made at the latest meeting. The 65-year-old Portman has made some bold architectural and business decisions during his career, but publicly has maintained a reticent image. He makes few public appearances, except to announce new developments. Yet the talks with creditors have made him a reluctant front page item over the last month. It is a position, say some who are close to Portman, that the businessman doesn't like. Insurance executive Jesse Hill Jr., a friend of Portman, charged that much of the media coverage has been based on speculation and has weakened Portman's position in negotiating with the bankers. ``The man is obviously restructuring his finances,'' said Hill, president of Atlanta Life Insurance Co. ``He's in negotiations and if somehow the press wouldn't give him this terrible beating, he has the assets and under normal circumstances he could work it out.'' Hill said he was especially offended by those who have grouped Portman with New York developer Donald Trump and other high-flying 1980s entrepreneurs whose debt-financed empires have taken a dive in the new decade. ``There is some constant effort to compare John Portman to Donald Trump,'' Hill said. ``Trump is no John Portman, and Portman is no Trump. ``Portman is a Horatio Alger story. He didn't have a Rockefeller Center - he built one. The man is in a class by himself.'' B. Eugene Griessman, a professor in the college of management at Portman's alma mater, Georgia Tech, profiled the architect-developer for a 1987 book on achievers. He said it is Portman's nature to brush aside such obstacles when he has his mind set on a project. ``He's a risk taker. His next project is always his favorite,'' said Griessman. Williams said Portman's current problems stem from tightened banking regulations that have followed the real estate slump and the savings and loan crisis. Banks are requiring lenders to come up with stronger backing for loans, he said. ``Almost every real estate company in America will have to deal with it,'' he said.

For Release PMs Thursday, Sept. 13
DOC.HEAD: What A Summer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS release day to Thursday PMs from Friday PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Economically speaking, this year will be remembered for its summer. Until that time, business economists thought they were dealing with a somewhat dull, understandable, rather tragic but predictable year. Then, as July ended and August began, said David Seiders of the National Association of Home Builders, ``all hell broke lose.'' A rather unscientific description, but it comes close to describing the sensation. First off, the Commerce Department went through three years of statistics on gross national product, most basic of all economic indicators, revised the numbers and revealed the economy really was weaker than believed. For those who rely on such numbers, as professional economists do, the news was traumatic. It was right after this that a slew of brand new forecasts emerged from Wall Street, all mentioning the likelihood of recession. Then came the July employment report, the first major indicator of economic activity for the third quarter. It showed employment falling and the jobless rate rising, particularly in manufacturing and construction. Very bad news. Then Iraq invaded Kuwait, world energy prices leaped, inflation fears rose, billions of dollars of value disappeared from stocks and bonds, Congress was unable to reach a budget compromise, the savings and loan crisis seemed to worsen each day, and the banking situation was found to be almost as bad. The latest blow was the revelation by Charles Bowsher, comptroller general of the General Accounting Office, that there might be insufficient cash in the Bank Insurance Fund to pay depositors of banks expected to fail. Bowsher told Congress, already trying to figure out how to handle $130 billion in costs from bailing out savings and loan associations, that 35 banks with $45.1 billion in assets would fold this year. All this _ and, of course, additional billions of dollars to support the military interdiction in the Mideast _ was presented within two months to a nation and its Congress already at an impasse over budget deficits. What happened this summer has changed every economic forecast of business and government, and probably the spending plans of most American households. While economic insecurity had been growing, its pace has quickened. Household insecurity is greater after the sharp decline in securities, the increase in energy prices, the slowdown in housing and the deterioration of the job market. The latter is in far worse condition than indicated by the 5.6 percent jobless rate. Factory jobs fell by 45,000 in August, bringing to 455,000 the number of such jobs lost since early last year. Construction employment in some areas is in a depression; employment fell by 40,000 in August. Now, according to Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, ``only health services and state and local government are sustaining a strong pace of job creation,'' and that suggests higher taxes. Perhaps the most pronounced attitudinal change resulting from the negative news is a feeling that the economy mightn't be able to stumble through problems as it has done before. Horizons have shrunk; it is difficult to look far ahead. Those who have experienced such periods recognize, however, that the picture can change remarkably fast; gloom can fade and hope can bloom _ if, for example, Mideast problems were resolved. Edward Yardeni, chief economist for Prudential-Bache Securities, agrees for example that the financial system is rotten, but says it's not ``rotten to the core, and it's not too late to fix it.'' And stock market guru James Dines wonders if stocks haven't fallen so low that bargains might soon begin to appear. He has just issued what he calls an ``interim warning bulletin'' entitled ``Approaching An Important Buy Signal?'' But whether the economic news continues to worsen and the gloom to deepen, or whether it takes a more positive turn, nobody is likely to forget these past two months any more than they can forget being mugged.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Portman Bjt
John Portman At a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at architect-developer John C. Portman Jr., who is meeting with creditors over his company's debt:

MAJOR DEVELOPMENTS: Peachtree Center, a cluster of skyscraper offices, hotels and trade marts in downtown Atlanta; the Marriott Marquis in New York; the Embarcadero Center in San Francisco; Marina Square in Singapore.

RECENT PROJECTS: Inforum, a $155 million technology mart opened in Atlanta in 1989. The $90 million San Francisco Fashion Center oened during the summer. One Peachtree Center, a $300 million 60-story office building that will be the latest addition to his Peachtree Center complex, is under construction.

DOC.HEAD: ABB to Buy Cincinnati Firm's Robot Business
DOC.TEXT: ABB Robotics Inc. has signed a letter of intent to buy the industrial robot business of Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the two companies announced. The division includes a Greenwood, S.C., plant and its 200 employees. Cincinnati Milacron said Wednesday the transaction is still subject to federal regulatory approval and is yet to be finalized. The companies declined to reveal the sale price. ABB Robotics, based in New Berlin, Wis., is a worldwide supplier of industrial robot systems. The company is part of the ABB Asea Brown Boveri Group, headquartered in Zurich, Switzerland. ABB Robotics said it plans to continue operating the industrial robot business, fulfilling current contracts and providing customer services. The company said it plans to retain a substantial number of the division's employees. Cincinnati Milacron said the sale would have little effect on 1990 earnings. Daniel J. Meyer, Milacron's president and chief executive officer, said his company is selling the business as part of a reorganization to concentrate on core businesses, including products for metalworking and plastics processing. ``Selling our robot business is a difficult decision, but we are pleased to have found such a strong buyer,'' said Christopher C. Cole, Milacron's group vice president for machine tool products. Cincinnati Milacron was an early developer of computer-controlled industrial robots and has developed robotic automation for industry. The company began research in industrial robots in the 1960s and introduced its first model for commercial sale in 1977. The company had 1989 sales of $851 million. Its products include machine tools, plastics machinery, computer controls, grinding wheels and metalworking fluids.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 214,133 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 177,973, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, when 211,051 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 136,828 cars this week, compared with 111,873 a week ago and 141,423 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 77,305, compared with last week's 66,100 and last year's 69,628. Canadian automakers were to build 22,052 cars this week, up from 20,857 a week ago and from last year's 19,661. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 17,924, compared with 13,780 a week ago and 20,566 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Deal On Offshore Oil Development to be Signed Friday
DOC.TEXT: Federal and provincial officials are expected to announce a $5.2 billion ($4.4 billion U.S.) deal Friday to develop the Hibernia oilfield off the coast of Newfoundland, the largest offshore development in Canada and a boon for its poorest province. The project, which has been in the works for a decade, will go after the estimated 522 million barrels of oil in the field 200 miles east of St. John's on the Grand Banks. Scheduled to appear at a news conference Friday in St. John's are federal Trade Minister John Crosbie, Energy Minister Jake Epp, Newfoundland Premier Clyde Wells and provincial Energy Minister Rex Gibbons. The federal government is providing $1 billion Canadian in cash and $1.7 billion Canadian in loan guarantees to the project being developed by Mobil Oil Canada Ltd., Chevron Canada Resources Ltd., Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. and Petro Canada. The Hibernia field represents about 5 percent of Canada's known oil reserves and long has been touted as the savior of the Newfoundland economy, which is based on the troubled fishing industry. Hibernia is expected to produce 110,000 barrels of oil a day for 20 years. ``I don't want to create the impression that it is going to turn Newfoundland into an economic Shangri-La,'' Wells told the St. John's Telegram. ``It is not.'' The project is expected to provide up to 3,000 jobs during the five-year construction period before production begins in 1996, then 1,600 jobs during the 20-year life of the oilfield. That is important to a province with a 17 percent unemployment rate. On Thursday, the government approved plans to develop the Cohasset Panuke oilfield off the coast of Nova Scotia. That project, scheduled to enter production in 1992, will produce 6 million barrels a year through 1997.

DOC.HEAD: Fiat Subsidiary Agrees to Buy Stake in Spanish Truckmaker
DOC.TEXT: Fiat Group's Iveco truck subsidiary has agreed to buy a 60 percent stake in the state-owned Spanish truck maker Empresa Nacional de Autocamiones SA, also known as Enasa, it was announced Thursday. Spain's state holding company, National Institute of Industry, selected the Italian company's offer over a bid from Daimler-Benz AG of West Germany. Fiat's Iveco agreed to pay 1.2 billion pesetas, or about $12 million, in cash for the stake, according to the National Institute's president, Jordi Mercader. He said Iveco also agreed to spend another 12 billion pesetas, or $120 million, on buying new Enasa shares that will be offered in January. Iveco, Europe's second-largest truckmaker after Daimler, will have a six-year option to purchase the remaining 40 percent of Enasa shares that remain under the National Institute's control, he said. Mercader told Spanish National Radio that the state holding company had accepted Fiat's offer because it was superior to that made by Daimler. Mercader did not elaborate on the latest Daimler offer. ``This decision strengthens Enasa as it faces the tough times up the road ahead,'' Mercader told national radio. A key part of the sale agreement includes Iveco guarantees for all 5,700 current jobs at the company's three plants and Enasa's top-line heavy truck brand name Pegaso. Attempts by National Institute of Industry officials to salvage an earlier proposed sale to Daimler-Benz reportedly floundered on the giant German truckmaker's insistence on more job cuts, state subsidies and a plant closure. In a statement released in New York, Fiat said it hoped to take steps to enable Enasa to broaden its product range in both light and heavy vehicle markets and to become more competitive. ``This transaction is a further step in the internationalization of Fiat Group after the recently-signed agreements with Ford vis-a-vis the farm equipment business and Nippondenso for the joint production of car air conditioners and heaters,'' Cesare Romiti, president and chief executive of Fiat Group and chairman of Iveco. Last November, the Spanish government chose a joint bid by Daimler-Benz and Man AG of West Germany to buy an 80 percent stake in the Spanish company. In doing so, it passed over other offers by Fiat's Iveco, Anglo-Dutch truckmaker DAF NV and AB Volvo of Sweden. But the Daimler-Man joint takeover collapsed last July. The government subsequently sought to get Daimler to take a majority stake alone or with another European partner or to entice Fiat to come in. Enasa reported sales of more than 11,000 light and heavy trucks last year and earned 240 million pesetas, or $2.47 million. It was the first time Enasa had posted an annual profit in years. But analysts said the confusion this year over Enasa's future owners and slowing demand for trucks has produced losses through the first six months of 6 billion pesetas, or $60 million. The industrial vehicles division of Fiat preoduced 139,300 vehicles last year. Iveco had operating income of about $486 million on revenue of $6.4 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Fall On Bigger Corn Crop Estimate
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell across the board Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, paced by a sharp drop in the corn market after the government raised its estimate of 1990 corn production. In a crop report released after Wednesday's close, the Agriculture Department estimated the 1990 U.S. corn crop at 8.12 billion bushels, up 8 percent from last year's harvest and 3 percent more than the government's August forecast. The projection exceeded most analysts' expectations. The government left its soybean crop estimate unchanged at 1.84 billion bushels, as expected, which was initially considered neutral for soybean prices. But some traders may have been unwilling to accept the USDA's prediction for continued strong soymeal export demand and sold contracts despite the report, said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Other analysts said soybeans rallied earlier this week in anticipation of the report, leaving the market vulnerable to profit-taking. DOC.HEAD: Kodak Introduces New Printing System
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. on Thursday introduced a printing system that will let personal computer users hook up with high-speed printers previously reserved for mainframes. The company billed the system, called Lionheart, as ``the most dramatic advance in office productivity since the mouse.'' Industry analysts were less effusive, in part because of the system's $250,000 price tag. The system uses new software with an enhanced version of Kodak's existing Ektaprint 1392 printer, which can print documents at speeds of up to 92 pages per minute. Standard desktop printers turn out about eight to 10 pages per minute. Users can also get sets of finished reports - sorted, stapled and hole-punched - by selecting options at their desktop computer, instead of filling out requests at their company's central copy center. Charles L. Trowbridge, general manager of Kodak's Copy Products Division, said Lionheart is the division's ``first step in a transition to digital imaging in the office.'' The system is targeted at companies that make or print 500,000 copies a month, such as government agencies and big law firms, officials said. ``It doesn't sound like a really big deal to me,'' said industry analyst Peter Enderlin of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. ``How many places are going to want to spend $250,000 a pop? You have to have a heck of a lot of personal computers to make it worthwhile.'' ``I don't know if I would go so far as to say it's as big as the mouse,'' said another analyst, B. Alex Henderson of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``The 1392 is a very good printer. But certainly you're not going to see one on every desktop.'' Kodak plans to bring out other versions of Lionheart and other digital products sometime in the next year, Trowbridge said. He said the company hopes to introduce its next new product in early 1991. Introduction of the division's new line has already been delayed several months. Enderlin said the latest expectation had been that the new products would be out in October or November. Michael J. Murray, Kodak vice president and general manager of marketing, said the Lionheart system is compatible with Ethernet, IBM Token Ring and AppleTalk networks, and accepts electronic floppy disk input.

DOC.HEAD: CBOT Says It Will Fight Ferruzzi Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: Chicago Board of Trade officials announced plans Thursday to fight two lawsuits they say seek to interfere with the board's ability to protect the integrity of the market. Ferruzzi Group, an Italian company accused last year of trying to corner the soybean futures market, filed a lawsuit Wednesday in U.S. District Court seeking to block a Board of Trade disciplinary hearing. The lawsuit said that the Board of Trade has a financial stake in finding Ferruzzi at fault. Ferruzzi also has filed a $30 million lawsuit seeking damages against the Board of Trade, accusing it of manipulating the market and conspiring to force prices lower when it issued an order forcing Ferruzzi to liquidate most of its soybean holdings. ``The CBOT will resist these lawsuits to the fullest extent of the law,'' Board of Trade Chairman William F. O'Connor said Thursday in a release. ``We will not permit them to interfere with our responsibility to protect the integrity of the market through our disciplinary process.'' The Board of Trade's business conduct committee has a hearing scheduled Monday to consider allegations that Ferruzzi tried to manipulate the market in July 1989 and committed other violations. The Board of Trade issued an emergency order July 11, 1989, directing all holders of July soybean contracts to liquidate their positions down to 1 million bushels. ``Ferruzzi was the largest position holder in that market and also held a clear majority of the soybeans that were deliverable on that contract,'' said Mark Prout, a spokesman for the exchange. A situation like the one Prout described puts the squeeze on other contract holders. Thomas R. Donovan, president of the exchange, said the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the General Accounting Office conducted separate investigations of the emergency action and both concluded that there were no conflicts of interest by the Board of Trade.

DOC.HEAD: Final Touches Put On Soviet-U.S. Trade Agreement
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Soviet trade officials said Thursday they put the final touches on a maritime trade agreement signed by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev during the June summit. Details of the agreement were worked out during a series of meetings this week in New Orleans. ``I would like to stress that this is not a one-sided agreement,'' said Vadim Kornelov, chief of foreign relations for the Soviet Union's merchant marine ministry. ``One shouldn't think that the Soviet Union due to this agreement is getting something that American interests won't get from the Soviet Union.'' Capt. Warren Leback, maritime administrator for the U.S. Department of Transportation, said the agreement protects American interests. It addresses U.S. shippers' concerns about Soviet ships' new freedom to not only deliver goods to U.S. ports, but also pick up cargo for delivery to Europe. ``We not see the predatory practices that occurred in the 70s recurring in the 90s,'' he said. The agreement lasts five years beginning Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: The Next Wave? Patenting Financial Innovations
DOC.TEXT: Imagine a certificate of deposit tied to the price of oil _ or a new kind of junk bond. Now imagine that you own the patent to such an innovation and everyone who wants to market it is beating a path to your door and forking over big bucks. One Washington law firm thinks patenting financial innovations may be the wave of the future in an era of financial uncertainty, shrinking markets and global competition. The firm, Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan, has issued a memorandum to its clients suggesting patents could be ``the most promising means for obtaining exclusive rights to a type of financial product or service for a significant period of time.'' But others in law and finance are skeptical. Noting that few such patents have been secured in the past, they think the idea may be patent nonsense. ``Our legal people indicate that it's very hard to patent or copyright (financial products) and probably it wouldn't be protected anyway, so I really haven't looked into it much more than that,'' said American Stock Exchange Chairman James R. Jones. ``I see a lot of lawsuits proliferating from this,'' added John Damgard, president of the Futures Industry Association, a Washington-based trade association. ``Maybe there's a real reason for it but at the moment it hasn't been demonstrated to me.'' ``I think its a novel twist, but I'm not ready to say its a major revolution yet,'' said Jack Coffee, a securities law expert and professor at Columbia University's law school. Stressing that his field is not patent law, Coffee added: ``This is the intersecton of securities law and patent law and I'm not sure either side understands the full dimensions of it.'' Several government agencies and congressional offices have expressed interest in reviewing the Sutherland, Asbill memo, although no hearings or studies are planned. In his 26-page note, Peter Trzyna, an associate at Sutherland, Asbill summarized the tools available for protecting financial innovations, copyrights, patents and trademarks, and concluded that all have strengths in certain circumstances. But he said patents, while expensive and difficult to obtain, may be the most effective. A patent is the exclusive right to exclude others from making, using or selling a device for 17 years, explained Oscar Mastin, a spokesman for the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, which last year issued a record 102,712 patents for all sorts of devices. He could not say how many financial patents have been applied for in recent years because patent applications are confidential by law. It takes about 18 months to obtain a patent after a review by one of the government's 1,400 patent examiners. The cost ranges from $6,000 and $20,000 for filing and legal fees, Sutherland, Asbill's memo estimated. ``Patents have the potential for causing the greatest reverberations in the financial industry,'' the memo stated. ``Competitors could well find themselves foreclosed from marketing a product or class of products for 17 years, or perhaps could do so only by paying royalties under a license. Courts are not timid about damage awards.'' But obtaining a patent isn't simple, explained patent attorney Thomas P. Dowling, of the New York firm Morgan & Finnegan. ``You can't patent an idea. You have to patent a tangible,'' he said. Dowling said a particular financial product can't be patented, only the mechanical system that operates it or makes it different from other products. Explained Dowling: ``Let's say there's a certificate of deposit with a return that's indexed to the price of oil and somebody starts to market the CD with some trade name as a means for hedging against the inflationary effects of oil prices. ``Now if they come up with a novel and unobvious system for creating that particular instrument, for maintaining it, for providing access to the subscribers and all of the other back office operations involved, they can get a patent on the system.'' But he said that won't stop someone marketing a similar product through a different system. Let's say someone patents a tamper-resistant automated teller machine that uses a magnetic encoded strip to recognize customers' bank cards, and someone else comes along with an ATM that reads optical encoding, such as a hologram. The patent-holder of the magnetic-strip system ``can't stop the second guy from also providing ATM services but using a different technique,'' said Dowling. So far, there have been few instances of financial service companies obtaining patents for new products. One of the first was Merrill Lynch & Co., which patented its Cash Management Account (CMA) in August 1982 and successfully defended it against PaineWebber Inc. ``We have negotiated license fee arrangements with several of our competitors,'' said Frank Macioce, assistant general counsel at Merrill Lynch. He said Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. agreed to pay a $1 million fee, while PaineWebber and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. have agreements that keep the amount they pay confidential, he said. Stephen B. Judlowe, the outside counsel who assisted Merrill Lynch in patenting the CMA, said he has no explanation for why few other firms have patented their new products. But he said, ``I think you're going to see more of it rather than less.''
