DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose $474.2 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds rose $474.2 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise, to $407.01 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $770 million drop in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. Fund assets hit an all time high of $408.0 billion in the week ended Aug. 22, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 255 general purpose funds rose $118.0 million to $143.8 billion, assets of 105 broker-dealer funds increased $608.2 million to $165.57 billion, and assets of 162 institutional funds declined $252.0 million to $97.64 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds was unchanged in the week ended Tuesday at 7.47 percent, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.48 percent from 7.49 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 47 days, up from 46 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.05 percent as of Wednesday from 6.06 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.02 percent from 5.03 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.69 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.71 the previous week. Yields were 7.84 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.85 percent; 7.93 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 7.92 percent; and 8.05 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged from the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Gains
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Sept. 3, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,316.4 billion from $3,303.7 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,103.4 billion from $4,092.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $820.0 billion from $815.6 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 5.2 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3.290.1 billion, a 2 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4.078.6 billion, up 0.9 percent, while M1 rose 4.4 percent to an average of $812.1 billion. In other reports: - The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $427 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $760 million the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Scandinavian Airlines Closes Continental Deal
DOC.TEXT: Scandinavian Airlines System completed a $50 million deal Thursday that makes it the largest shareholder of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. and puts Frank Lorenzo out as Continental chairman. Lorenzo will get $30 million through the arrangement, approved a day earlier by the Transportation Department, but a Continental spokesman said the money is not all coming from the SAS purchase. ``Mr. Lorenzo's $30 million is paid out over a period of time through the company,'' spokesman Art Kent said. ``It's not like he's getting a lump sum.'' SAS said it paid Lorenzo $17 million to buy out his employment contract and to obtain vested options he had in Continental stock, although Lorenzo retains options on 783,333 shares. Lorenzo remains as a Continental director. As part of the deal, SAS purchased Jet Capital Corp., which Lorenzo and partners used as a holding company for their shares of Continental. SAS also bought 2.25 million newly issued shares of Continental for $14 per share. Continental, based in Houston, Texas, and SAS, based in Stockholm, Sweden, issued a joint statement Thursday evening that also announced several appointments to the 15-member Continental board. As previously announced, the former president of Delta Airlines, Hollis L. Harris, of Atlanta, becomes president and chief executive of Continental. Harris also joins the board. Long-time Continental director Carl Pohlad, of Minneapolis, was elected chairman. Robert Garrett, of New York, was elected chairman of the executive committee. SAS said it would appoint three members to the Continental board, including Jan Carlzon, of Stockholm, president and chief executive of SAS Group. The other SAS appointees are Lars Bergvall, of Stockholm, chief operating officer of SAS; and Roberto Mendoza, of New York, vice chairman of J.P. Morgan.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Shows Upswing in Quality of U.S. Goods
By EVE EPSTEIN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The quality of U.S. manufactured goods is on the rise, according to a Boston University study on manufacturing competitiveness based on a survey of company executives. The good news for manufacturers is that the improvement rate on the quality of goods has increased in the last two years. But the report also found new product development and cost as possible trouble spots on the U.S. manufacturing front. ``To get ahead of European and Japanese manufacturers, Americans must hold strong on quality and improve on new product development and cost,'' said Jeffrey Miller, a professor at Boston University's School of Management Miller and Professor Jay Kim drew conclusions about manufacturing based on surveys of nearly 200 executives of large U.S. manufacturing firms. The study was released by the Manufacturing Roundtable at Boston University. In the study, ``Beyond the Quality Revolution: U.S. Manufacturing Strategy in the 1990s,'' researchers found that in 1989, quality improved at an annual rate of 7 percent over 1988. However, cost and new product introduction time improved only 2{ to 3 percent per year over the two-year period. Kim said the survey found that more than half the respondents start their process engineering activities after most of the product engineering is finished. ``This results in longer lead time for new product development, higher costs and missed opportunities in rapidly changing markets,'' Kim said. The study found that American manufacturers do not view the introduction of new products by competitors as a serious threat. Miller said that's a dangerous misperception. ``The nationwide emphasis on quality, and the previous success of these firms in improving it, may be distorting their perception of competitive realities,'' he said. Work has begun on an international report to compare similar data for Japan and Europe, Kim said. James Howell, an economist who runs his own consulting firm and formerly worked as an economist for the Bank of Boston, said the report may reflect the fact that manufacturers - as well as deans of engineering schools - became concerned that other countries were doing a better job of maintaining high quality. ``This is the area where the Japanese have been just beating our pants off,'' Howell said. But he said there are better ways to gauge quality improvement than asking manufacturing executives. ``You really should ask the production engineer on the floor who is really trying to maintain quality production,'' Howell said. The survey asked executives to weigh a number of factors in determining quality, including defect rates, liability and customer satisfaction, Kim said. He said the numbers for quality improvement are significant because executives gave their companies lower marks for improvement in other areas. Still, Howell remained skeptical. ``No executive has ever found anything wrong with his quality,'' Howell said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Files Sentencing Report Under Seal
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors filed a sentencing report Thursday about financier Michael Milken that is believed to allege numerous uncharged crimes, but it was not made public pending challenges from the news media. An attorney for Milken said he would oppose release of the papers before the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond executive is sentenced on Oct. 1 for his guilty plea to six securities and tax fraud counts. The sentencing memorandum reportedly contains details about Milken's alleged conduct unearthed by the government but never made public because of the plea agreement reached in April. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood gave attorneys for members of the media until Monday to argue why the document should be released before Milken is sentenced. Under the plea deal, Milken's lawyers agreed not to contest the release of the sentencing memo or the inclusion of conduct outside the plea. They can, however, seek to block release prior to the date of sentencing. Assistant U.S. Attorney John K. Carroll said the government did not object to releasing a version of the report before sentencing but would delete references to unindicted co-conspirators and confidential information related to an ongoing grand jury investigation. The government normally does not release such memos, which contain arguments for or against the severity of a sentence, until the day of sentencing. Defense lawyers also can file a sentencing report. Milken's lawyers are expected to oppose early release of the report on the grounds that prejudicial publicity about Milken could threaten his right to a fair sentencing. High public interest generated by the case is one argument for early release. ``We want this case treated in terms of sentencing the way other defendants are treated in this court and not different,'' Milken attorney Martin Flumenbaum said at a hearing. ``There have always been high visibility cases in this court and the practice (of withholding reports until sentencing) has been invariably followed,'' he said. ''We bargained for it to be publicly disclosed at the date of sentencing.'' Richard Tofel, an attorney for Dow Jones & Co., which owns The Wall Street Journal, said he would file a motion arguing in favor of early release. Flumenbaum was given until Wednesday to respond. Prosecutors said a version of the sentencing report deleting the sensitive information could be prepared within 48 hours of a judge's release order. Tofel said the newspaper would seek to have the full report released publicly, either before or at sentencing. Earlier this year, U.S. District Judge Pierre Leval refused to admit a sentencing report alleging that former Wall Street arbitrager Robert Freeman committed 20 crimes in addition to a single insider trading count he admitted. That is not an issue in this case because Milken's lawyers agreed that the government could raise at sentencing conduct not included in the plea deal. Milken faces up to 28 years in prison. He originally was indicted in March 1989 on 98 counts of fraud and racketeering in the biggest securities fraud case in history.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Fall Broadly After USDA Report
DOC.TEXT: Corn and wheat futures prices fell as expected Thursday following a government forecast for increasing supplies of those grains, but a drop in the soybean market surprised some observers. On other commodity markets, crude oil futures rose slightly; precious metals were mixed; cattle were mixed; and pork futures retreated. Wheat futures settled 3\ cents to 7 cents lower on the Chicago Board of Trade with the contract for delivery in September at $2.59} a bushel; corn was 5{ cents to 8{ cents lower with September at $2.33\ a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 5 cents lower with September at $1.07 a bushel; soybeans were 7\ cents lower to 1 cent higher with September at $6.23 a bushel. In a crop report released after Wednesday's close, the Agriculture Department estimated an 8 percent increase in U.S. corn production this year to 8.12 billion bushels. The government also raised its projection for the nation's Aug. 31, 1991, corn stockpile to 1.38 billion bushels from last month's estimate of 1.21 billion. Similarly, the USDA boosted its wheat production estimate to 2.76 billion bushels, 35 percent more han last year, and raised its forecast for the May 31 wheat stockpile to 946 million bushels from last month's projection of 846 million. Those unexpectedly big numbers explained Thursday's decline in corn and wheat prices, analysts said. But soybean prices also slipped, despite the government's forecast for a 5 percent decline in soybean production this year to 1.84 billion bushels and a reduction in the USDA's Aug. 31, 1991, soybean stockpile projection to 200 million bushels from last month's estimate of 225 million. Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said some, but not all of Thursday's soybean selling reflected an overflow of bearish sentiment from the neighboring corn and wheat pits. She said additional pressure may have stemmed from skepticism about the government's logic in predicting that a decline in the amount of soybeans harvested in Brazil next spring will lead to an increase in world consumption of U.S. soybeans during the 12 months that began Sept. 1. ``A case could be made for a smaller Brazilian crop based on lower plantings but the impact on U.S. usage from a smaller South American crop would more likely be felt in the 1991-92 crop year,'' Frick said. Other analysts said traders who bought soybean contracts earlier in the week in anticipation of a lower USDA forecast for Brazilian soybean production took profits Thursday after the report confirmed their expectations. Crude oil and heating oil futures rose but near-term gasoline fell Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in a lackluster trading session muffled by a shortage of news from the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude oil settled unchanged to 38 cents higher with October at $31.07 a barrel; heating oil was .89 cent to 1.27 cents higher with October at 83.48 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .48 cent lower to .84 cent higher with October at 93.36 cents a gallon. Gold futures edged higher while silver futures slipped on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold settled 40 cents to 80 cents higher with September at $382.90 a troy ounce; silver was 2.8 cents to 3 cents lower with September at $4.773 a troy ounce. Profit-taking pressured live cattle futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange but feeder cattle advanced, helped by the drop in corn prices. Hog futures retreated in line with weaker cash prices while pork bellies succumbed to profit-taking after Wednesday's strong gains. Live cattle settled .15 cent to .37 cent lower with October at 78.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .60 cent higher with September at 88.20 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .48 cent lower with October at 50.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent to 1.6 cents lower with February at 53 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty in Counterfeit Computer Chip Scam
DOC.TEXT: A Cincinnati man pleaded guilty Thursday to federal charges that he made counterfeit computer chips and sold them for half a million dollars. Dennis Wayne Hayes, 48, pleaded guilty to charges of money laundering and criminal infringement of a copyright, among others, said U.S. Attorney D. Michael Crites. U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel released Hayes on a $50,000 cash bond pending sentencing. Hayes faces up to 26 years in prison and a $775,000 fine. The Internal Revenue Service said Hayes sold about 5,000 sets of counterfeit Macintosh 128K ROM computer chips between 1988 and 1990, giving him gross receipts of about $500,000. The IRS and FBI said they began a joint investigation after receiving information that Hayes was involved in illegally making and selling computer chips, and was structuring large currency transactions at Cincinnati-area banks in an apparent effort to avoid currency transaction reporting requirements. Authorities said Hayes obtained cashier's checks at the banks and had them made payable to a Swiss bank account. To counterfeit the chips, Hayes purchased blank chips and removed the manufacturer's name. He then had the chips silk-screened with the Apple Computer Inc. logo, copyright information and parts numbers to make them appear genuine. Hayes sold the chips for $95 to $130 per set, federal authorities said. Apple Computer does not authorize reproduction of these chips. During a raid of Hayes' home, IRS and FBI agents said they seized sophisticated computer and other electronic equipment, more than $180,000 in cash, $2,000 in traveler's checks and weapons including four Uzi semiautomatic guns. Hayes' Piper Comanche airplane and a car were also seized.

DOC.HEAD: Strikes Breaking Out at Canadian Paper Mills
DOC.TEXT: A potentially nasty split is looming among Canadian pulp and paper workers over whether to agree to concessions or go on strike in hopes of a better contract offer. About 800 workers were off the job Thursday at a Canadian Forest Proucts Ltd. mill in Dalhousie, New Brunswick, after rejecting an offer which the union said followed the so-called pattern settlement reached this summer with Stone-Consolidated Inc. CP Forest's largest mill in Gatineau, Quebec, was also shut down by a strike. One local representing 1,105 workers at the Gatineau mill voted against the offer while another local with 238 members voted for the deal. But 1,100 workers at the company's plants in La Tuque, Quebec, and Trois-Rivieres, Quebec, voted for the proposal and remained on the job. ``It wasn't because we were satisfied, but we're in a recession and the industry is in a slump,'' union local spokesman Pierre Bellerive said in a telephone interview from Cap-de-la-Madeleine, near Trois-Rivieres. ``People just didn't think it was the right time for a strike,'' he said. A spokesman for the Montreal-based Canadian Paperworkers Union declined comment except to acknowledge ``we have a difficult situation.'' CP Forest is Canada's second largest producer of newsprint after Abitibi-Price Inc. of Toronto, which has 3,800 workers on strike at mills in Stephenville and Grand Falls in Newfoundland; Chandler, Quebec; Iroquois Falls, Ontario; and three mills in Thunder Bay, Ontario. Talks between Abitibi-Price and the union collapsed Tuesday and union negotiators urged members to reject the company's offer. Abitibi-Price workers voted Thursday on the deal and results were not yet known. In Beaupre, near Quebec City, however, the 450-member local at the Abitibi-Price plant has already accepted the offer and is on the job. In the case of both companies, the sticking points with workers have been demands to operate on two more statutory holidays in return for premiums of up to five times the basic rate of pay, and calls for greater flexibility in assigning skilled tradesmen. ``We're shutting down the mill because our members don't want to give up anything on those issues,'' said Gilles Sabourin, a union spokesman at the CP Forest mill in Gatineau. The union says allowing greater trade flexibility would cost jobs. Those two concessions were the hallmark of the pattern agreement reached earlier this summer with employees of Montreal-based Stone-Consolidated. That agreement contained a 16.5 percent wage increase over three years. Every three years, the union chooses a ``target company'' and negotiates what is called the pattern settlement, which is supposed to serve as the industry model. But this year, although the wage increase was seen as generous by some industry observers in light of the plummeting profits of paper plants, the pattern deal with Stone-Consolidated roused the ire of workers elsewhere. The concessions proved so unpopular the union said it would back any locals that wanted to fight them. Abitibi-Price says it has offered employees a 16.5 percent wage increase over three years as well as all other gains negotiated by the Stone-Consolidated mills. The average base rate for a mill worker is $15.37 ($13.25 U.S.) an hour. Some industry analysts have predicted that any strike over non-monetary issues would not last long. Separate negotiations are being conducted at CP Forest's plants in Dryden and Thunder Bay. Workers at those two plants will be in a strike position at the end of September, said a union spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Bass Thrift Acquisition Called Worst Ever for Taxpayers
DOC.TEXT: Billionaire Robert Bass' purchase of a failed California thrift is saving taxpayers money, a Bass associate said Thursday, challenging a study's conclusion that the buyout was the worst of the 1988 Southwest Plan bailouts. The study, prepared for the U.S. House Banking Committee, suggests the government will end up paying $4.37 billion to bail out the thrift, more than double original estimate of $1.7 billion, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported Thursday. The newspaper said investigators also concluded that it would have been cheaper to liquidate American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton at a cost of $3.3 billion than to pump federal money into it. But Bass Group principal Bernie Carl, who was lead negotiator in the thrift purchase, said that while the study was based on accurate figures from when the thrift was sold in December 1988, they have not been correctly interpreted. Also, Carl said, the $3.3 billion liquidation fee, while correct at the time of the sale, would have ballooned to $4.4 billion had the thrift actually been liquidated. In total, he estimated, it would have cost the government $5 billion to liquidate the thrift. Jake Lewis, a staff member of the House Banking Committee, said he would not address any specific figures or analysis of the study until after a hering on it Friday. ``The best we can tell is that it is not any document from this committee,'' Lewis said. ``We do have some staff analysis but we have not made any release of any study from here.'' Carl said American Savings was actually $1 billion deeper in debt than estimated when regulators assessed the $3.3 billion liquidation fee. ``The bank board didn't understand how deep the hole was, and I'm not sure they could have,'' Carl said Thursday, breaking longstanding policy not to comment on Bass dealings. After the sale, American Savings was divided into two financial institutions: a healthy $15 billion-asset thrift named American Savings Bank and a ``bad bank,'' called New West Federal Savings, with a $22 billion portfolio of troubled assets. Carl said that under the Bass tenure, $14 billion in troubled assets from New West have been liquidated at $700 million above the appraised value, reducing the government's exposure to less than $3.7 billion. If the remainder of the troubled portfolio is liquidated with the same success, he said, the $700 million figure would climb to approximately $1 billion. When the government's 30 percent share in American Savings is considered, Carl said, the taxpayers' cost in the bailout is $1 billion lower than initially estimated. ``What these numbers really show is the deal didn't cost the taxpayers $1 billion, it probably saved them that much,'' Carl said. The study of 27 Southwest Plan deals was prepared for a Banking Committee hearing Friday in Washington. Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-San Antonio, is reviewing the deals made in 1988 under the Southwest Plan. He is focusing on American Savings, as well as the deals behind Southwest Savings of Dallas and First Gibraltar Bank. Gonzalez has characterized most of the 94 transactions involving 196 institutions as ``sweetheart'' deals that were overly generous to wealthy investors and too costly to taxpayer. The overall cost of the savings and loan bailout has been estimated at $500 billion. Carl claimed the hearing is designed to take the heat off politicians and place it on those who bought insolvent banks. ``It's much easier to find a scapegoat than face up to the fact that they created the thrift mess to start off with,'' he said. In an article this week, the publication American Banker termed the American Savings purchase a possible prototype for future government action. The publication lauded the deal, which involved little federal assistance. Bass, of Fort Worth, pumped $400 million into the thrift.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Money Manager Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A former money manager pleaded guilty Thursday to trading on inside information about a pending merger that was passed along by an attorney at a prestigious New York law firm. Peter H. Jeffer, 44, of Manhattan, pleaded guilty to one count of wire fraud for purchasing 7,000 shares of stock in Spectro Industries Inc. in April 1985 after receiving a tip from a stockbroker. Jeffer faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine at sentencing Jan. 4, 1991, before U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cederbaum. The government alleged Jeffer received the information from stockbroker Eben P. Smith, who in turn was tipped off by Steven L. Glauberman, an attorney formerly with the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Glauberman, 39, of Manhattan, pleaded guilty Wednesday to two counts of securities fraud and one count of wire fraud. Smith, 41, of Greenwich, Conn., faces criminal conspiracy and securities fraud charges. In addition to Jeffer, whose money management firm Jeffer Management Corp., now is defunct, Stanley P. Patrick of Old Lyme, Conn., was charged criminally with making trades on information from Smith. Glauberman was charged with leaking information about clients involved in some well-known takeovers of the 1980s. The indictment alleges that Jeffer Management made $1.75 million on transactions involving tips about pending mergers or takeovers from Smith in several deals. Jeffer was charged only in connection with the possible merger of Spectro Industries and McKesson Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Salomon Brothers Executive Nominated To Head Industry Group
DOC.TEXT: A top executive at the brokerage firm Salomon Brothers Inc. was nominated Thursday as chairman of the securities industry's leading trade group. Gedale B. Horowitz, 58, was tapped as the next head of the Securities Industry Association in 1991, succeeding Robert N. Downey, a partner with Goldman, Sachs & Co. Horowitz is a former director and treasurer of the trade association. His nomination is to be approved Nov. 30 at the SIA's annual convention. SIA President Edward I. O'Brien said Horowitz's experience in the industry and in Washington will be valuable ``because of the many critical issues facing the industry, particularly at the federal level.'' Horowitz is in charge of government relations at Salomon, which he joined in 1955 and became a general partner in 1967. He currently is executive director of the brokerage and an executive vice president and director of its parent company, Salomon Inc. Horowitz also is a past chairman of the Public Securities Association, another industry trade group, and the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, which wrote the first rules for that sector of the industry.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CLARIFY that September silver contract was down.
DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slide Tied to Greenspan Comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar sank against all its major foreign counterparts Thursday in a slide triggered by widespread speculation about lower U.S. interest rates. Trading volume was heavy. ``The dollar came under intense pressure,'' said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at the Amsterdam Rtterdam Bank's office in New York.``We saw a pretty substantial selloff. Volume was very, very heavy. I would characterize it as brisk with a capital `B'.'' The setback for the dollar came after Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said that if a credible U.S. budget-deficit reduction accord is reached between White House and Congressional negotiators then the central bank would be inclined to relax its monetary policy. An easing in Fed policy would lead to lower U.S. interest rates, a development that would be bearish for the dollar. A decline in U.S. rates - especially after Japan pushed up its rates - would make the dollar less appealing to investors because it would reduce returns on dollar-denominated holdings. Many analysts have been urging the Fed to follow an easier monetary policy to reinvigorate the failing economy. The dollar started its trading day in Tokyo by stumbling against the Japanese yen. It fell in the Japanese capital to a closing 137.65 yen from 138.30 yen at Wednesday's close. It was the lowest closing level in Tokyo since Aug. 3, 1989, when the dollar finished at 136.40 yen. In London, the dollar fell to 137.25 yen. It continued to lose ground in later New York dealings, ending the session at 136.25 yen, down from 138.075 yen late Wednesday. The dollar didn't fare any better against the German mark. It tumbled to 1.5680 marks in late New York dealing from 1.5915 marks late Wednesday. In European trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5740 marks, down from Wednesday's late level of 1.5860. The British pound benefitted from the dollar's weakness. In London, the pound rose to $1.8770 from $1.8650 late Wednesday. A pound fetched $1.8825 late in New York, compared to $1.8590 a day earlier. Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late quotes Wednesday, included: 1.3025 Swiss francs, down from 1.3290; 5.2520 French francs, down from 5.3303; 1,170.00 Italian lire, down from 1,187.75; and 1.16175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16355. Late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared Wednesday's late levels, were: 1.3130 Swiss francs, down from 1.3225; 5.2710 French francs, down from 5.3180; 1.7740 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7875; 1,174.00 Italian lire, down from 1,184.25, and 1.1640 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1623. Gold prices posted modest gains on world markets. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for September delivery picked up 80 cents to settle at $382.90. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $384.00 an ounce, $2.50 higher than Wednesday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $384.00 a troy ounce from $381.75 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to $383.40 an ounce from $381.75 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.62 an ounce to $381.82. Silver had a mixed day. The metal fell on New York Comex with the contract for September delivery closing at $4.773 a troy ounce, down from Wednesday's settlement of $4.801. Silver bullion was unchanged in London at a late bid of $4.82 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: GM Recalls School Buses, Vans for Fuel Hose Repair
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is recalling 30,700 1990 vehicles, including 1,700 Chevrolet and GMC school buses, to repair fuel hose connections that could break, the company said Thursday. The gasoline-powered school buses and about 29,000 Chevrolet Astro and GMC Safari vans with 4.3-liter or 2.5-liter engines, may have fuel-return hoses that could break at crimped couplings and let fuel leak into the engine compartment, GM said. Fire could result if the fuel were ignited by hot engine parts, GM said, though it said it hadn't been notified of any accidents or injuries resulting from the problem. Owners of the vehicles are being notified by letter, and GM dealers will install properly crimped fuel-return hoses at no charge, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Sues Five for Stock Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Five people and three companies have been charged in a $26 million stock fraud scheme, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Thursday. In a civil complaint, the SEC charged the defendants sold $57 million in unregistered securities, through a now defunct company known as Governmental Financial Services. The governmnet said 800 investors bought the securities between 1983 and 1987. Before GFS filed for bankruptcy law protection only $31 million had been paid back to investors. The complaint, filed at federal court in Baltimore, alleged the defendants were engaged in a ``Ponzi'' scheme. Investors were told their money would go to buy equipment leases that furnish regular income, when in fact the money was used to pay back earlier investors. Those named in the complaint, filed Tuesday, were: GFS President Charles A. Oglebay III, of Marlboro, Md.; Ralph E. McKittrick, Rye, N.Y., a shareholder of GFS; Thomas L. Oglebay, Pleasant Town, Md.; Harold M. Covert Jr., Allentown, Pa.; Glenn E. Dawson, Woodstock, Md. Also named were three companies: McKittrick & Briggs Securities Inc., a New York-based brokerage; Harold M. Covert & Associates Inc., an Allentown, Pa., investment adviser and Reliance Leasing Co., a New York company. Thomas Crowe, a Baltimore attorney who has represented Charles Oglebay in the past, said he had not reviewed the complaint and could not comment.

DOC.HEAD: Hilton Says Tough Vegas Competition Will Cut Profits by Half
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. said Thursday it expects its third-quarter profit to fall by 50 percent, mainly because competition has kept gamblers away from the Las Vegas Hilton. The recently opened Excalibur and Mirage hotels have lured foot traffic away from other hotels in Las Vegas. The Hilton has been hurt particularly hard by the Mirage because both hotels cater to well-heeled clients. ``It's more competitive for the high rolling business because of the Mirage,'' said Michael G. Mueller, an analyst who follows hotels for Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ``The Mirage is always full.'' In the third quarter of 1989, Hilton earned $30.5 million, or 63 cents per share.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chairman of Small Thrift Indicted
DOC.TEXT: The former chairman of a small Los Angeles savings and loan was indicted by a federal grand jury Thursday on charges of using $1.24 million of the thrift's own money to help buy a controlling interest in it. Oliver A. Trigg Jr. joined the board of Family Savings & Loan Association in 1986, bought 51 percent of its stock in August 1987 and resigned as chairman in May 1988 under pressure from regulators. Trigg, 39, of Los Angeles, faces 15 counts of conspiracy, bank fraud, tax fraud, money laundering and lying to federal regulators. He has agreed to surrender and is scheduled for arraignment on Sept. 14 before U.S. Magistrate Robert M. Stone, said the federal prosecutor on the case, Maurice A. Leiter. Trigg intends to plead innocent and contest the charges, said his lawyer, Arthur Barens. He said Trigg had cooperated fully with the government and testified for several hours before the federal grand jury about a year ago. Trigg faces a maximum prison sentence of 94 years and a fine of up to $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: President's Strategic Oil Reserve Powers Extended
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Tops with 6 grafs of Senate passage; picks up 3rd graf pvs: ``The agreement;'' SUBS grafs 3-4 pvs, now grafs 7-8, to clear garble and clarify that Senate and House were approving a conference committee report. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congress on Thursday extended for another four years President Bush's authority to tap the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to stave off higher oil prices even though Bush has not used it in the Iraqi takeover of Kuwait. The bill, which also would authorize increasing the size of the reserve from 580 million to 1 billion barrels of oil, was approved by the Senate on a voice vote and sent to the White House The House earlier passed the bill 391-0. Democrats have widely criticized Bush's refusal to draw upon the reserve to moderate the 50 percent increase in crude prices since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in early August. The administration has said it will use the reserve only if shortages develop, contending it was never intended to influence prices - a contention some analysts dispute. A United Nations embargo against Iraqi-Kuwaiti oil has reduced world supplies by about 4.3 million barrels, of which about 600,000 barrels went to the United States. The agreement from a House-Senate conference committee reauthorizes the reserve through 1994. Without action, authorization to operate the reserve would have expired on Saturday. It also increases the amount of oil that the Energy Department may purchase and store, from the current 750 million barrels to 1 billion barrels. The bill originally passed by the House extended the authority but did not increase the size of the reserve. The Strategic Petroleum Reserve is a stockpile of crude oil established in response to the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. The oil is stored in salt caverns along the Louisiana-Texas coast and has been accumulated at a cost of more than $20 billion over the last decade. The system, with its current actual stockpile of 580 million barrels, could now replace 80 days of oil imports, according to congressional committees, should it be needed in an oil emergency. That cushion has fallen from 110 days in the middle 1980s because of growing U.S. dependence on foreign crude. The measure also authorizes a test program for establishment of a stockpile of refined oil products, such as gasoline and home heating oil. Congress and the administration have battled over the last 18 months over whether to increase the reserve to 1 billion barrels. President Bush has opposed increasing the reserve.

DOC.HEAD: Crew May Miss Some Pleasures, But Wouldn't Miss Going on This Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to DELETE extraneous `along.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PN1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bernd cq in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Bernd Zabel says there are some things he'll miss while he's gone from this world for two years: ``Going to a Saturday night movie, going to a bar, having dinner. Having a beer.'' But all in all, the 41-year-old electrical engineer from Munich, West Germany, won't mind forgoing such pleasures. For he'll be in another, special world: a giant terrarium known as Biosphere II. His closest neighbors will be seven fellow environmental pioneers, or ``biospherians,'' who will live with 3,800 varieties of plants, animals and insects inside the 2{-acre glass-and-steel dome designed to duplicate Earth's ecosystem. The $30 million privately funded Biosphere is a prototype for sustaining life in space and and a laboratory for solving environmental problems such as pollution. The world-within-the-world will consist of the crew members' habitat plus six others: an agricultural area, desert, fresh and saltwater marshes, ocean, savannah and rain forest. All food will be raised inside, from 150 crops rotated seasonally to small goats, chickens, pigs and fish. Air, water and wastes will be recycled. Only electricity will link the ecological system with the outside. Computers and telephones will provide communications with the rest of the world. Crew members will be able to leave via airlocks in an emergency. The crew members, named Wednesday, have worked together for at least three years on the project, which begins Dec. 5. ``I'm working five years toward the aim of the two-year closure, and the closer the day comes, the more excited I get,'' said Zabel, 41, the crew captain. The other crew members, all single, are Abigail K. Alling, 31, a marine biologist; Dr. Roy Walford, a gerontologist and nutritionist and professor of pathology at the UCLA School of Medicine; Linda Leigh, 38, scientific director; Sally Silverstone, 35; Taber K. MacCallum, 26; Jane Elizabeth Poynter, 28, and Mark Van Thillo, 29. Poynter, of Surrey, England, said the biospherians have been practicing their farming, and several also have learned how to butcher animals. ``Nothing will be a surprise when we go in, in terms of growing our own food,'' she said. Alling acknowledged that everyone involved with the project has given some thought to the possibility that a crew member might go stir-crazy in the Biosphere's confines. ``My response is, I've spent quite a lot of time at sea,'' including a stint on a research ship off Antarctica, she said.
